description: Markdown is a alternative to other markup languages such as HTML. There is a version that is a little more 'fancy' called GitHub Flavored Markdown. In this series, you will find out what GitHub-Flavored Markdown is as well as how to accomplish quick format tasks that simplify creating structure and some styling.

In this series, you will find out what GitHub-Flavored Markdown is as well as how to accomplish quick format tasks that simplify creating structure and some styling.
name: Learn GitHub Flavored Markdown
subtitle: Easy Document Formatting

WEBVTT

I need to know how to make headings,

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrate getting set up to write markdown files. This setup is going to make getting immediate rendering feedback a breeze.

use for a particular file packet?

00:10:00.200 --> 00:10:05.110
Preview mark down, but
if you type just mark down, you can see,

181
00:10:05.110 --> 00:10:09.570
open preview to the side Open Preview,
change Preview Security Settings.

182
00:10:09.570 --> 00:10:11.290
You could definitely take a look at those.

183
00:10:11.290 --> 00:10:12.490
And then refresh Preview.

184
00:10:12.490 --> 00:10:16.655
If for some reason things aren't
refreshing like you expect them to,

185
00:10:16.655 --> 00:10:20.770
Control-Shift-P or Command-Shift-P on Mac,
hyphen mark down, and

186
00:10:20.770 --> 00:10:22.180
you'll see these options.

187
00:10:22.180 --> 00:10:24.380
Once you select them with the arrow and

188
00:10:24.380 --> 00:10:29.370
it will also tell you, if you wanna do
this, just hold shift command v on Mac,

189
00:10:29.370 --> 00:10:34.580
and for Windows and Linux platforms it
will give you the corresponding shortcut.

190
00:10:34.580 --> 00:10:42.310
So I'm gonna open the preview and it opens
in a totally new kind of document, right?

191
00:10:42.310 --> 00:10:45.840
So you'll notice,
hey this looks just like text.

192
00:10:45.840 --> 00:10:47.150
But this text looks different.

193
00:10:47.150 --> 00:10:50.950
This, when it's rendered,
this is how this will look, all right?

194
00:10:52.270 --> 00:10:54.790
So how do I get out of this?

195
00:10:54.790 --> 00:10:57.050
Or maybe you want a side by side preview.

196
00:10:57.050 --> 00:10:58.190
You just close that document.

197
00:10:58.190 --> 00:10:59.238
The preview is done.

198
00:10:59.238 --> 00:11:02.230
And then if I come here,
open preview to the side.

199
00:11:02.230 --> 00:11:09.220
And now if I come and I just type, you'll
notice, this updates as you're typing.

200
00:11:09.220 --> 00:11:14.310
So this is a great way to iterate,
to kinda go, what is that doing?

201
00:11:14.310 --> 00:11:17.340
I'm typing things,
is that rendering correctly?

202
00:11:17.340 --> 00:11:21.660
And by using this, our editor is very,
very helpful to us, and

203
00:11:21.660 --> 00:11:24.650
allows us to say, I typed this,
what's going on over here?

204
00:11:24.650 --> 00:11:26.480
Cool.
I typed this, what's going on over here?

205
00:11:26.480 --> 00:11:27.660
Cool.

206
00:11:27.660 --> 00:11:31.210
One thing I do wanna see about these
text editors that are kind of rich text

207
00:11:31.210 --> 00:11:34.000
editors, if you come to the file menu and

208
00:11:34.000 --> 00:11:37.580
this is kind of ubiquitous
across all of these.

209
00:11:37.580 --> 00:11:39.280
You will notice there's no print.

210
00:11:40.800 --> 00:11:43.660
There's no print whatsoever.

211
00:11:43.660 --> 00:11:46.430
And that's because it's
expecting you to transform or

212
00:11:46.430 --> 00:11:48.490
use some other method of printing.

213
00:11:48.490 --> 00:11:51.650
It's like, that's not my game,
I'm not here to help you print.

214
00:11:51.650 --> 00:11:54.930
There are other tools that will help that,
okay?

215
00:11:54.930 --> 00:12:00.060
So if you want to transform Markdown,
you can save as HTML, someone use that.

216
00:12:00.060 --> 00:12:03.030
There's some other conversion tools or
you just give your Markdown and

217
00:12:03.030 --> 00:12:04.300
it will give you a PDF.

218
00:12:04.300 --> 00:12:08.730
And well let me cover those near the end
of this series after we get some

219
00:12:08.730 --> 00:12:12.130
idea of what these individual
pieces of syntax mean.

220
00:12:12.130 --> 00:12:12.690
But for now.

221
00:12:12.690 --> 00:12:15.270
As long as we have our editor good,
we're good to go.

222
00:12:15.270 --> 00:12:16.980
>> So
we know what we need to right markdown.

223
00:12:16.980 --> 00:12:19.730
Right?
We even got an editor recommendation from

224
00:12:19.730 --> 00:12:20.520
you there Justin.

225
00:12:20.520 --> 00:12:22.490
Is there anything else
that we need to know?

226
00:12:22.490 --> 00:12:24.880
Anything else we need in place for
markdown?

227
00:12:24.880 --> 00:12:25.770
>> I think for now.

228
00:12:25.770 --> 00:12:31.250
As long as you have editor and, well,
you have an active keyboard that works.

229
00:12:31.250 --> 00:12:33.120
That's pretty much all we need, right?

230
00:12:33.120 --> 00:12:34.050
We need to be able to open and

231
00:12:34.050 --> 00:12:38.660
close files, create files,
type around, and we're good to go.

232
00:12:38.660 --> 00:12:42.750
Now, eventually, your mark down workflow
may get a little more complicated,

233
00:12:42.750 --> 00:12:47.510
especially if you choose to, I want to use
Emacs and all these other pipeline builds.

234
00:12:47.510 --> 00:12:51.060
That's up to you, but, for now, we're just
going to stick with Visual Studio Code.

235
00:12:51.060 --> 00:12:53.160
If you have it installed,
you're going to open files.

236
00:12:53.160 --> 00:12:54.160
We're good to go.

237
00:12:54.160 --> 00:12:55.440
>> All right.
A lot of great information.

238
00:12:55.440 --> 00:12:56.710
Thank you for getting us up and running.

239
00:12:56.710 --> 00:13:00.490
When it comes to markdown, we appreciate
having you here, Justin, in the studios.

240
00:13:00.490 --> 00:13:01.670
We appreciate you, the viewer.

241
00:13:01.670 --> 00:13:05.080
Hopefully, you've enjoyed, how to get
started in Markdown, but keep in mind,

242
00:13:05.080 --> 00:13:08.350
we've got a lot more to come but
it's gonna require you to stay tuned.

243
00:13:08.350 --> 00:13:11.120
Signing off for DevProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

244
00:13:11.120 --> 00:13:11.910
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

245
00:13:11.910 --> 00:13:13.532
>> And we'll see you next time.

246

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrates how you can use GitHub-flavored markdown to italicize text in your writing.
episodes.title: Italicizing Text

1

That's right, we're gonna be

how are you today?

There's some things that we need

can you tell us a little bit about that?
>> Well, I've kinda envisioned this,

12

because this is something that
I've had trouble with, right?

13
00:00:40.780 --> 00:00:42.730
When we're learning how
to type Markdown or

use Markdown rather than writing
READMEs or writing notes.

Or even, I've heard of people writing

There's other tools that'll make

17
00:00:54.390 --> 00:00:57.300
Well, there's a lot of times I forget.

18

Now, how do I do that one thing again?

19
00:00:59.480 --> 00:01:03.390
So kind of what I've envisioned is,

See the insides and

And in particular,

So yes, Wes?

Markdown, right?

I know there are many different types,

many different if you

Now, what are we gonna be

>> Well, for

this entire series we're always gonna

And that adds a little bit on top, but

a lot of the things you will learn will

31

Now, flavors not like grape, or orange, or

32
00:01:32.560 --> 00:01:35.800
anything like that, but
what is available to you?

33
00:01:35.800 --> 00:01:39.180
Now, italicizing text,
it's pretty ubiquitous.

34

Whether you're using
GitHub Flavored Markdown or

35

some of the other Markdown flavors.

I almost chuckle when I

But any of those other ones,

38

So let's go ahead and

39

let's see how we can italicize text.

40
00:01:54.960 --> 00:01:57.950
So I'm in my Visual Studio code editor.

And right inside this GitHub-markdown
folder is just a folder that I have open.

I'm gonna create a new file.

If you use .md that will make sure

00:02:16.910 --> 00:02:20.095

Markdown, right next to the smiley face.

If yours isn't a smiley face, that

00:02:25.915 --> 00:02:26.800
But that's all right.

And then, let's make this a little

50

So I've zoomed in and

51

Now, I've typed some text,

And let's say, I'm writing this in a

00:02:46.996 --> 00:02:51.770
whatever it may be, if I save this and

If I open the Markdown preview,

00:02:56.380 --> 00:02:58.350
This is just paragraph text.

56
00:02:58.350 --> 00:02:59.970
That's it, that's all you got.

57
00:02:59.970 --> 00:03:01.312
There's nothing special.

00:03:01.312 --> 00:03:05.542
And if you've ever come from another

00:03:05.542 --> 00:03:09.100

00:03:09.100 --> 00:03:13.830
Well the entire impetus of Markdown is,
everything you write has a reason for

00:03:13.830 --> 00:03:15.270
existing, okay?

62
00:03:15.270 --> 00:03:19.860
So if I come in front of this and I put

00:03:19.860 --> 00:03:20.820
I put an underscore.

64
00:03:22.160 --> 00:03:26.750
And you say, you notice inside of

65
00:03:26.750 --> 00:03:28.645
And this is why I like VS Code.

66

Adam actually does this fairly well,
there's a couple of other ones.

00:03:31.361 --> 00:03:35.600
And I come over here,
you'll notice that is now italicized.

68
00:03:35.600 --> 00:03:37.560
So it's very, very simple.

69
00:03:37.560 --> 00:03:40.490
Now, one of the common gotchas is,
well, I need to write underscores,

70
00:03:40.490 --> 00:03:42.360
but I don't want italicize.

71
00:03:42.360 --> 00:03:43.490
Well, that's easy.

72
00:03:44.800 --> 00:03:49.370
You can put a slash, right, and that's a,
I always get those mixed up, Wes.

73
00:03:49.370 --> 00:03:51.417
Do you know if that's a backslash or
a forward slash?

74
00:03:51.417 --> 00:03:52.430
>> I think that's a backslash.

75
00:03:52.430 --> 00:03:55.727
>> Okay, for some reason I always wanna

76
00:03:55.727 --> 00:03:59.162
like make those different.
>> The only reason I know this is because

77
00:03:59.162 --> 00:04:03.119
I personally use the backslashes for
UNC pass browsing the network shares.

78
00:04:03.119 --> 00:04:05.553
So I know it's a backslash.
>> [LAUGH] Okay, okay.

79
00:04:05.553 --> 00:04:09.070
So backslash,
if you're like what is a backslash?

80
00:04:09.070 --> 00:04:13.410
It's the slash above your enter or
return key typically on your keyboard.

81
00:04:13.410 --> 00:04:14.644
>> Justin I was just gonna ask,

82
00:04:14.644 --> 00:04:17.833
what's the purpose of putting a backslash
in front of the characters that

83
00:04:17.833 --> 00:04:18.382
you use?
>> So

84
00:04:18.382 --> 00:04:22.395
the backslash is actually going to
allow us to escape these characters,

85
00:04:22.395 --> 00:04:25.840
and now,
the Markdown syntax will no longer apply.

86
00:04:25.840 --> 00:04:30.499
And we will talk about over the course
of the series, where can I use this,

87
00:04:30.499 --> 00:04:34.990
how are they used, what are the things to
watch out for before it tell us in text.

88
00:04:34.990 --> 00:04:39.050
You always wanna make sure that
you want to escape the opening and

89
00:04:39.050 --> 00:04:40.450
the ending, right?

90
00:04:40.450 --> 00:04:43.596
So if you try to not italicize,
but instead you want underscores.

91
00:04:43.596 --> 00:04:44.576
And there maybe times,

92
00:04:44.576 --> 00:04:47.480
if you're running a technical
document there underscores in names.

93
00:04:47.480 --> 00:04:51.700
Or you have a very particular name
of some other like reference.

94
00:04:51.700 --> 00:04:54.570
Or maybe you're referencing a file,
you may have underscores.

95
00:04:54.570 --> 00:04:55.560
And if you come here,

96
00:04:55.560 --> 00:04:58.420
you'll notice that those underscores
are now available to you.

97
00:04:59.420 --> 00:05:04.630
But they're not used in
modifying the view of the text

98
00:05:04.630 --> 00:05:07.640
when you actually render the Markdown.
>> So if I wanna make sure that

99
00:05:07.640 --> 00:05:09.722
a special character, Justin,
if I understand this right.

100
00:05:09.722 --> 00:05:12.490
I wanna make sure that that special
character makes it into my text, and

101
00:05:12.490 --> 00:05:16.760
that Markdown doesn't interpret it as
some kind of modification of the text.

102
00:05:16.760 --> 00:05:21.060
You have to make sure that you escape it.
>> Exactly, escape it wholeheartedly.

103
00:05:21.060 --> 00:05:23.450
Now, that is something to remember.

104
00:05:23.450 --> 00:05:27.483
Now, what if you want to italicize

105
00:05:27.483 --> 00:05:32.221
the underscores that you've escaped?

106
00:05:32.221 --> 00:05:34.700
Well, now it gets a little iffy, right?

107
00:05:34.700 --> 00:05:38.810
So if I come out here, and I look,
and I put another underscore, and

108
00:05:38.810 --> 00:05:39.590
another underscore.

109
00:05:39.590 --> 00:05:43.640
Notice, I have an underscore,
and then a backslash underscore.

110
00:05:43.640 --> 00:05:45.050
And then, what are you doing?

111
00:05:45.050 --> 00:05:49.380
And then, another backslash underscore,
and then another underscore, right?

112
00:05:49.380 --> 00:05:52.190
So I've only escaped one
set of those underscores.

113
00:05:52.190 --> 00:05:56.210
If I save and I come back,
I now have an italicized

114
00:05:56.210 --> 00:06:00.470
set of underscores at the beginning and
end, so I can use these together.

115
00:06:00.470 --> 00:06:03.270
So you can kind of compound those.

116
00:06:04.400 --> 00:06:08.924
Now, what's interesting is
Markdown allows us sometimes to

117
00:06:08.924 --> 00:06:13.187
use other characters if it's
a convention for us, okay?

118
00:06:13.187 --> 00:06:18.080
We've seen underscores provide
the ability to italicize something.

119
00:06:18.080 --> 00:06:22.700
If I come back, we're now back to
regular text, but if I put an asterisk,

120
00:06:23.810 --> 00:06:30.930
and then, another asterisk here, then I
should get, as you see an italicized text.

121
00:06:30.930 --> 00:06:32.420
So an underscore at the beginning and
the end,

122
00:06:32.420 --> 00:06:34.340
and an asterisks at the beginning and
the end.

123
00:06:34.340 --> 00:06:40.500
Both allow italicizing, I was getting
ready to make up a word there.

124
00:06:40.500 --> 00:06:44.799
And then likewise,
if you wanted to not have this, but

125
00:06:44.799 --> 00:06:49.386
instead use the asterisk as
a special character, right?

126
00:06:49.386 --> 00:06:52.701
Something that you're gonna put in the
documentation because it's important for

127
00:06:52.701 --> 00:06:54.055
the documentation.

128
00:06:54.055 --> 00:07:00.500
You'ill put backslashes in front of those,
notice we have regular text, right?

129
00:07:00.500 --> 00:07:06.200
And then, we still have those
respective asterisks, okay?

130
00:07:06.200 --> 00:07:08.850
So if we come back here and
everything looks good.

131
00:07:08.850 --> 00:07:14.085
And then, if I wanted those to be
italicized, I could even combine these.

132
00:07:14.085 --> 00:07:18.638
And say well, I want the asterisk,
but I want those to be italicized, but

133
00:07:18.638 --> 00:07:21.600
I want the asterisk to actually be there.

134
00:07:21.600 --> 00:07:23.240
You can combine those as well, and

135
00:07:23.240 --> 00:07:28.510
then you can see,
how are you doing in an italicized manner.

136
00:07:28.510 --> 00:07:33.794
So in order to italicize text,
it's a single underscore at either end,

137
00:07:33.794 --> 00:07:36.406
or a single asterisk at either end.

138
00:07:36.406 --> 00:07:41.341
And you can combine those as well as use
escape characters as we've seen here, to,

139
00:07:41.341 --> 00:07:46.064
well, I want the asterisk to be there not
to apply a style like Markdown normally

140
00:07:46.064 --> 00:07:46.580
would.

141
00:07:46.580 --> 00:07:48.680
So the backslash is great for escaping.

142
00:07:48.680 --> 00:07:54.050
And as far as italicizing text,
that is a good place to start.

143
00:07:54.050 --> 00:07:56.900
Pretty easy, but
there are a couple of gotchas.

144
00:07:56.900 --> 00:08:00.340
If you want those characters to be there,
have to use the escape character.

145
00:08:00.340 --> 00:08:03.220
Otherwise, Markdown's gonna
remove those apply styles

146
00:08:03.220 --> 00:08:05.306
in your rendered final product.
>> All right,

147
00:08:05.306 --> 00:08:08.119
Justin, that's a lot of great information
on some of the things that we can

148
00:08:08.119 --> 00:08:10.546
do with Markdown to start manipulating and

149
00:08:10.546 --> 00:08:13.708
To make that text the output
that we're previewing look

00:08:13.708 --> 00:08:15.329

Does look like we're coming to
the end of another episode, and

00:08:19.290 --> 00:08:21.870
Justin, you got any final words that

>> Well, definitely stay tuned cuz these

are nice little bite size where how do

158
00:08:29.302 --> 00:08:32.220
And we appreciate you, the viewer,
watching here at DevProTV.

159
00:08:32.220 --> 00:08:34.070
Signing out,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

160
00:08:34.070 --> 00:08:34.770
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

161
00:08:34.770 --> 00:08:36.708
>> And we'll see you next time.

162
00:08:36.708 --> 00:08:41.863
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrates how you can use GitHub-flavored markdown to emphasize text in your writing.
episodes.title: Bolding Text
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.833 --> 00:00:14.008
Hello, and welcome to DevProTV.

3
00:00:14.008 --> 00:00:16.070
I 'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.070 --> 00:00:19.520
And in today's episode, we got
an exciting show for you in store today.

5
00:00:19.520 --> 00:00:21.760
We're gonna be looking at markdown and

6
00:00:21.760 --> 00:00:24.200
some of the things that we can
do to manipulate our text.

7
00:00:24.200 --> 00:00:27.010
And joining us in the studios is
none other than Mr.Justin Dennison.

8
00:00:27.010 --> 00:00:29.550
Justin, how we doing today, sir?
>> I am doing fantastic, Wes, and

9
00:00:29.550 --> 00:00:31.130
how are you today?
>> Man, I'm doing great.

10
00:00:31.130 --> 00:00:34.070
Over the last couple of episodes, you've
shown us some of the things that we can

11
00:00:34.070 --> 00:00:38.150
do in markdown in order to modify
the way the output of our text looks.

12
00:00:38.150 --> 00:00:42.000
And I can only imagine that we're gonna
be continuing along here in this episode.

13
00:00:42.000 --> 00:00:43.750
So what do we have in store for us today?
>> Well,

14
00:00:43.750 --> 00:00:48.690
I think if we can italicize then
we should be able to bold, right?

15
00:00:48.690 --> 00:00:51.300
Italicize, maybe that's
a level of emphasis,

16
00:00:51.300 --> 00:00:55.090
bold is also a level of emphasis but
maybe they're not quite the same level.

17
00:00:55.090 --> 00:01:00.120
Bold is like, look at this, italicize is,
you should probably pay attention but

18
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:01.990
maybe it's not quite so in your face.

19
00:01:01.990 --> 00:01:06.570
And along with that there is a couple
of things where maybe I want bold and

20
00:01:06.570 --> 00:01:07.850
italicized.

21
00:01:07.850 --> 00:01:09.570
And well how do we handle that?

22
00:01:09.570 --> 00:01:13.570
And I think the best way is,
just start putting things on the page and

23
00:01:13.570 --> 00:01:14.300
see how they render.

24
00:01:14.300 --> 00:01:16.070
So let's take a look
at the screen here and

25
00:01:16.070 --> 00:01:17.880
I'm just inside of my Atom text editor.

26
00:01:17.880 --> 00:01:23.166
I'm gonna come over here and
create a new file called boldingtext.md.

27
00:01:23.166 --> 00:01:28.486
Now md is yypically, always going to
provide you with a, and if you don't have

28
00:01:28.486 --> 00:01:33.510
a space there, notice how I put a space
there and I get a weird little icon?

29
00:01:33.510 --> 00:01:35.400
That means it's a standard text.

30
00:01:35.400 --> 00:01:40.200
My text editor doesn't recognize it as
a markdown file and thus it will not

31
00:01:40.200 --> 00:01:43.660
give me markdown syntax highlighting and
give me a little bit of help.

32
00:01:43.660 --> 00:01:45.279
So, I'm gonna rename that quickly,

33
00:01:45.279 --> 00:01:47.718
cuz I'm pretty sure I accidentally
hit a space and I did.

34
00:01:47.718 --> 00:01:51.899
And now I get the markdown
designation as well

35
00:01:51.899 --> 00:01:56.100
as down here I get
the markdown designation.

36
00:01:56.100 --> 00:02:03.780
So if we have some text here is
something important, all right?

37
00:02:03.780 --> 00:02:07.800
So I'm thinking if I wanna
bold something I need to

38
00:02:07.800 --> 00:02:09.710
have something important to bold.

39
00:02:09.710 --> 00:02:12.520
Please do not bold your
entire markdown file.

40
00:02:12.520 --> 00:02:15.301
It's kind like,
its bold all caps and italicized.

41
00:02:15.301 --> 00:02:18.100
I immediately don't read those.

42
00:02:18.100 --> 00:02:23.330
That's just me, but if I see something
bold I go uh-huh there we go.

43
00:02:23.330 --> 00:02:25.640
That I need to zoom in on that,
remember that, that's important.

44
00:02:26.930 --> 00:02:28.070
So, how do I do that?

45
00:02:28.070 --> 00:02:33.260
Well, let's open this up and I noticed
sometimes I get a little carried away Wes.

46
00:02:33.260 --> 00:02:36.866
I use little shortcuts that
maybe you're not aware of.

47
00:02:36.866 --> 00:02:39.190
On Mac that's Cmd+Shift+P to open this.

48
00:02:39.190 --> 00:02:41.280
On all other platforms just Ctrl+Shift+P.

49
00:02:41.280 --> 00:02:43.802
And that is inside of Visual Studio Code.

50
00:02:43.802 --> 00:02:47.873
And then the only thing I'm gonna do
is type in MARK, open markdown and

51
00:02:47.873 --> 00:02:50.230
this will give me that preview section.

52
00:02:50.230 --> 00:02:53.890
So we'll render whatever
I'm seeing in the preview.

53
00:02:53.890 --> 00:02:56.000
So I come back over here.

54
00:02:56.000 --> 00:02:58.780
Well, we know how to italicize.

55
00:02:58.780 --> 00:03:03.730
Let's say that this important
Portion is what we want to bold.

56
00:03:05.060 --> 00:03:06.150
How do I do that?

57
00:03:06.150 --> 00:03:08.120
Well we can always use these inline.

58
00:03:08.120 --> 00:03:11.380
And I can actually bold
this entire section.

59
00:03:11.380 --> 00:03:13.950
So let's do that,
see how we can move those inline.

60
00:03:13.950 --> 00:03:19.240
So if I come here and I put two asterisks
and then two asterisks like that.

61
00:03:19.240 --> 00:03:22.350
Notice that my text editor says hey,
those are blue.

62
00:03:22.350 --> 00:03:23.350
Why is it doing that?

63
00:03:23.350 --> 00:03:28.170
Because it's recognizing this is
markdown well syntax for something.

64
00:03:28.170 --> 00:03:32.060
If I come back over here,
notice this is now bold,

65
00:03:32.060 --> 00:03:35.730
that's two asterisks before and after.

66
00:03:35.730 --> 00:03:39.290
Now if I don't want,
if let's say I want two asterisks,

67
00:03:39.290 --> 00:03:41.930
just as a reminder I'm
gonna put slash slash.

68
00:03:41.930 --> 00:03:46.650
I'm gonna skip each one of those,
and it is no longer bold but

69
00:03:46.650 --> 00:03:48.900
actually has the two asterisks before and
after it.

70
00:03:49.950 --> 00:03:52.584
Now along with that markdown
supports another syntax.

71
00:03:52.584 --> 00:03:56.626
To do this, and
that is not asterisk asterisk, but

72
00:03:56.626 --> 00:03:59.639
not a parentheses is not part of that.

73
00:03:59.639 --> 00:04:03.645
Underscore underscore and
underscore underscore just like that and

74
00:04:03.645 --> 00:04:05.310
notice it turns blue again.

75
00:04:06.310 --> 00:04:07.120
All right?

76
00:04:07.120 --> 00:04:10.320
That kinda deep blue and now it is bold.

77
00:04:10.320 --> 00:04:13.270
So it's either two underscores
followed by two underscores or

78
00:04:13.270 --> 00:04:16.040
two asterisks followed by two asterisks.
>> Now Justin,

79
00:04:16.040 --> 00:04:17.650
I got a question on this one.

80
00:04:17.650 --> 00:04:21.490
If you're going to use one or
the other, do you have your preference?

81
00:04:21.490 --> 00:04:26.789
Or is there a recommendation?
>> So actually provide my recommendation,

82
00:04:26.789 --> 00:04:30.760
keep in min this is bias this
is kinda how I think about it.

83
00:04:30.760 --> 00:04:32.599
You can definitely choose this.

84
00:04:32.599 --> 00:04:37.190
What I do for
bolding is I use the asterisk.

85
00:04:37.190 --> 00:04:41.720
So asterisk, asterisk, asterisk, asterisk.

86
00:04:41.720 --> 00:04:43.650
I use that for bold.

87
00:04:43.650 --> 00:04:47.540
Likewise, because this could be easily
confused with italicize in the previous

88
00:04:47.540 --> 00:04:50.780
episode, we saw the underscores,
and single underscores and

89
00:04:50.780 --> 00:04:56.040
single asterisk could provide Italicizing,
right?

90
00:04:56.040 --> 00:05:01.540
The reason I used two asterisk for
bolding is now if I want to mix these,

91
00:05:01.540 --> 00:05:06.720
I can go underscore and
come here and underscore save, and

92
00:05:06.720 --> 00:05:09.490
now I have bold and italicized.

93
00:05:10.890 --> 00:05:15.530
And I find this easier to read
than something like this.

94
00:05:15.530 --> 00:05:20.870
Three underscores,
three underscores, just like so.

95
00:05:20.870 --> 00:05:22.930
It's still bold and italicized but

96
00:05:22.930 --> 00:05:26.230
at a quick glance I may not
know that those are three.

97
00:05:26.230 --> 00:05:30.514
Now you could definitely
flip flop that but

98
00:05:30.514 --> 00:05:34.710
I use double asterisks for that reason.

99
00:05:34.710 --> 00:05:37.410
But also if I'm scanning
through my document,

100
00:05:37.410 --> 00:05:41.790
my roll markdown document I can
quickly look and go, that's bold.

101
00:05:41.790 --> 00:05:46.168
These other things are,
those are italicized and

102
00:05:46.168 --> 00:05:52.590
thn like this one that's an underscore and
asterisk, that's bold and italicized.

103
00:05:52.590 --> 00:05:54.250
And it gives me a visual cue.

104
00:05:54.250 --> 00:05:56.310
So that's my recommendation.

105
00:05:56.310 --> 00:06:02.580
You're more than welcome to do things like
this, three asterisk or three underscores.

106
00:06:02.580 --> 00:06:05.110
And you will still get the same
results because both of those

107
00:06:05.110 --> 00:06:08.720
characters are counted, they're paired
up like two and two, boom-bold.

108
00:06:08.720 --> 00:06:10.530
One and one, italicized.

109
00:06:10.530 --> 00:06:12.580
And then it just kinda parses those apart.

110
00:06:12.580 --> 00:06:16.620
Now, something further that I want to,
you can mix and match these.

111
00:06:16.620 --> 00:06:19.870
Let's say that I want this
entire section in bold,

112
00:06:19.870 --> 00:06:22.000
because this entire section is important.

113
00:06:22.000 --> 00:06:25.960
But I only want a subsection
of this to be italicized.

114
00:06:25.960 --> 00:06:31.810
I can come here, and say underscore
underscore around important.

115
00:06:31.810 --> 00:06:36.040
And if I come back I now have
an entire bolded section but

116
00:06:36.040 --> 00:06:39.060
then a subsection that is italicized.

117
00:06:39.060 --> 00:06:40.540
Likewise I can flip that around.

118
00:06:41.670 --> 00:06:45.720
So I can make this underscore,
make this one underscore

119
00:06:47.630 --> 00:06:53.060
and the bold the interior
section just like so, right?

120
00:06:54.270 --> 00:06:57.310
So now I have an italicize and
a subsection bolded.

121
00:06:57.310 --> 00:07:01.470
So do keep in mind, even though I'm
typically showing these small snippets of

122
00:07:01.470 --> 00:07:04.510
texts, it can be internal
to whatever you're writing.

123
00:07:04.510 --> 00:07:06.630
I can say, I just want this section.

124
00:07:06.630 --> 00:07:10.840
Wherever I open and close those
respective sections, there we go.

125
00:07:10.840 --> 00:07:11.780
All right?

126
00:07:11.780 --> 00:07:18.240
Now the final thing, let's say that this
important is like a programmatic term.

127
00:07:18.240 --> 00:07:21.730
I know that when I'm programming or
writing README documents for

128
00:07:21.730 --> 00:07:25.380
repos, that there are times
where the underscore or

129
00:07:25.380 --> 00:07:28.540
the asterisk is actually
part of the syntax.

130
00:07:28.540 --> 00:07:34.230
It's something that I wanna draw
attention to, escape is the backslash.

131
00:07:34.230 --> 00:07:35.830
Backslash, right, Wes?
>> That's right.

132
00:07:35.830 --> 00:07:37.320
It's a backslash.
>> All right,

133
00:07:37.320 --> 00:07:38.320
I'm glad he's here.
>> [LAUGH]

134
00:07:38.320 --> 00:07:40.670
>> Because I mess that up all the time.

135
00:07:40.670 --> 00:07:44.394
So if I put a backslash there,
I now have a bolded section,

136
00:07:44.394 --> 00:07:47.740
but the bolding actually
doesn't also italicize.

137
00:07:47.740 --> 00:07:51.710
I'm saying, hey I don't want to use
the underscores as part of my format.

138
00:07:51.710 --> 00:07:53.880
I wanna escape just those.

139
00:07:53.880 --> 00:07:59.258
So don't get too hung up on,
if I put an escape

140
00:07:59.258 --> 00:08:04.518
character here and
an escape character here.

141
00:08:04.518 --> 00:08:05.603
You have to be careful,

142
00:08:05.603 --> 00:08:09.680
you have to escape every character that
you want to not be part of the formatting.

143
00:08:09.680 --> 00:08:11.360
So do remember that.

144
00:08:11.360 --> 00:08:15.070
And if you use an editor,
rich text editor, the S Code, Atom,

145
00:08:15.070 --> 00:08:18.700
a lot of times they'll give
you these nice visual cues.

146
00:08:18.700 --> 00:08:21.650
As you're typing in your markdown
about what's gonna happen.

147
00:08:21.650 --> 00:08:25.760
Here if I see this dark blue,
hey I'm still bolding the text.

148
00:08:25.760 --> 00:08:29.650
But if I see this orange,
the backslash and

149
00:08:29.650 --> 00:08:33.790
the character right after it are both
orange so I'm escaping those characters.

150
00:08:33.790 --> 00:08:35.430
So something to keep in mind.

151
00:08:35.430 --> 00:08:37.330
But you can combine these.

152
00:08:37.330 --> 00:08:41.740
Pretty easy to bold, my recommendation
is use asterisks for bolding and

153
00:08:41.740 --> 00:08:45.910
underscores for italicizing, and
that allows you to keep your

154
00:08:45.910 --> 00:08:50.697
separation concerns appropriate.
>> Yeah, I know that when I used markdown

155
00:08:50.697 --> 00:08:54.602
myself the three asterisks on both
sides does get a little bit confusing.

156
00:08:54.602 --> 00:08:58.975
So as far as a recommendation it's for
the visibility of your raw markdown versus

157
00:08:58.975 --> 00:09:03.880
what you're seeing in the preview.
>> Exactly, and it helps me.

158
00:09:03.880 --> 00:09:08.510
Again, I use double asterisk for
bold, underscores for italicized.

159
00:09:08.510 --> 00:09:11.790
You could easily say, well I want
double underscores for bold and

160
00:09:11.790 --> 00:09:14.220
single asterisk for italicized.

161
00:09:14.220 --> 00:09:18.293
Just having a different character, and
I think to some extent that's why they're

162
00:09:18.293 --> 00:09:21.335
there, allows you,
like you said in your raw markdown to go.

163
00:09:21.335 --> 00:09:23.750
Okay, these are the conventions
that I have adopted.

164
00:09:23.750 --> 00:09:26.100
It's all good to go and, well, Wes,

165
00:09:26.100 --> 00:09:28.640
that is all we need to know
about bolding thus far.

166
00:09:28.640 --> 00:09:32.510
These will continue to build upon each
other,but hopefully that's a nice little

167
00:09:32.510 --> 00:09:33.710
take away for you.
>> All right,

168
00:09:33.710 --> 00:09:35.610
a lot of great information, Justin, here.

169
00:09:35.610 --> 00:09:39.910
We appreciated having you in the studios
with us on how you can put some emphasis

170
00:09:39.910 --> 00:09:43.130
on your text and look forward to seeing
the episodes that are yet to come.

171
00:09:43.130 --> 00:09:45.960
So we appreciate again,
like I said having you here, and

172
00:09:45.960 --> 00:09:48.140
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

173
00:09:48.140 --> 00:09:51.420
Signing out here at DevProTV remember
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

174
00:09:51.420 --> 00:09:52.760
>> And I'm Justin Minsen.

175
00:09:52.760 --> 00:09:54.317
>> And we'll see you next time.

176
00:09:54.317 --> 00:09:58.354
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin demonstrates how you can use GitHub-flavored markdown to strikethrough text in your writing.
episodes.title: Striking Through Text
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.709 --> 00:00:15.560
Welcome to DevPro.TV,
I'm your show host Wes Bryan, and

3
00:00:15.560 --> 00:00:18.250
in today's episode we got
a great show in store for you.

4
00:00:18.250 --> 00:00:21.824
That's right we're gonna come back with
more of that markdown, and showing us how

5
00:00:21.824 --> 00:00:24.529
to put a little bit of emphasis on
our text is none other than Mr.

6
00:00:24.529 --> 00:00:25.365
Justin Dennison.

7
00:00:25.365 --> 00:00:27.856
Justin, how we doing today sir?
>> I am doing fantastic Wes and

8
00:00:27.856 --> 00:00:29.700
how are you today?
>> Man, I'm doing great.

9
00:00:29.700 --> 00:00:33.552
Over the last couple of episodes you've
shown us some different ways that we can

10
00:00:33.552 --> 00:00:35.287
do things like italicize our text.

11
00:00:35.287 --> 00:00:38.869
We can also bold our text, right, but
we have some others that have yet

12
00:00:38.869 --> 00:00:42.300
to be discovered and you're gonna
help us out with those, right?

13
00:00:42.300 --> 00:00:44.835
>> Well, I plan to, we'll see it goes.

14
00:00:44.835 --> 00:00:48.380
[LAUGH] Who knows what'll happen,
but let me set the scene for you.

15
00:00:48.380 --> 00:00:50.737
We have some bolding, some italicizing,

16
00:00:50.737 --> 00:00:53.424
we've seen tose in the past
ocuple of episodes.

17
00:00:53.424 --> 00:00:56.200
But there are times,
especially in documentation for

18
00:00:56.200 --> 00:01:00.493
some kind of technical procedure, or
even, I'm a developer, so documentation.

19
00:01:00.493 --> 00:01:04.464
No one likes to write documentation,
but you should, and what'll happen is,

20
00:01:04.464 --> 00:01:07.470
your documentation will change over time.

21
00:01:07.470 --> 00:01:10.700
Something you said originally
may no longer be true, but

22
00:01:10.700 --> 00:01:14.960
it might be helpful if you're like, I need
to reference this, keep this in here.

23
00:01:16.450 --> 00:01:18.390
So here's my recommendation.

24
00:01:18.390 --> 00:01:22.439
If you have some kind of technical
documentation that has a change,

25
00:01:22.439 --> 00:01:24.711
a tiny little piece of it has changed,

26
00:01:24.711 --> 00:01:29.257
instead of erasing it you can use
strike-throughs to make a modification,

27
00:01:29.257 --> 00:01:33.752
but that way you can say, this is what
it used to be, here's what it is now.

28
00:01:33.752 --> 00:01:38.371
Now, don't go crazy with this, but
this is something that may be helpful.

29
00:01:38.371 --> 00:01:39.794
So, what do I mean by strike-through?

30
00:01:39.794 --> 00:01:41.589
Well, it's just a line through the text.

31
00:01:41.589 --> 00:01:46.658
It's saying it was there, but disregard
it, and maybe here's the follow-up.

32
00:01:46.658 --> 00:01:48.818
I enjoy this because I don't have to go,

33
00:01:48.818 --> 00:01:53.282
but that says something different than it
used to, I can't remember what it says.

34
00:01:53.282 --> 00:01:56.797
If it's striked through it
allows me just to do a quick

35
00:01:56.797 --> 00:01:59.440
comparison.
>> I work heavily with certification

36
00:01:59.440 --> 00:02:03.070
exams, and there are times when those
certification exams will change,

37
00:02:03.070 --> 00:02:07.106
will update to reflect a new feature, and
I know it is very, very handy, Justin,

38
00:02:07.106 --> 00:02:10.790
when I have to say, okay, what's
the correlation with the old exam versus

39
00:02:10.790 --> 00:02:14.800
what we're seeing now, and those
strike-throughs they really come in handy.

40
00:02:14.800 --> 00:02:17.785
So I'm with you there, being able
to instantly see what was old and

41
00:02:17.785 --> 00:02:20.095
what is the new, and
being able to compare the two.

42
00:02:20.095 --> 00:02:21.518
>> And maybe you only keep this for

43
00:02:21.518 --> 00:02:22.893
one version change, right?

44
00:02:22.893 --> 00:02:25.093
If you're like, I'm gonna strike
through this, here's the new one.

45
00:02:25.093 --> 00:02:29.447
If there's an additional change, go remove
the old strike-through, because it's

46
00:02:29.447 --> 00:02:33.323
way in the past now, strike-through
what you had and add the new change, but

47
00:02:33.323 --> 00:02:36.740
we've provided impetus, but
how do we actually accomplish that?

48
00:02:36.740 --> 00:02:39.172
So let's go and
come to the screen here and take a look.

49
00:02:39.172 --> 00:02:43.031
So I'm gonna create a new document
inside of my GitHub markdown folder, and

50
00:02:43.031 --> 00:02:44.820
I'm gonna say strike-through.

51
00:02:44.820 --> 00:02:50.775
I'm not in my in my, [SOUND] I'm not being
real creative today, but that's all right.

52
00:02:50.775 --> 00:02:56.711
So, Here is some documentation,

53
00:02:56.711 --> 00:03:01.623
all right, to provide, and

54
00:03:01.623 --> 00:03:05.103
then, let's say,

55
00:03:05.103 --> 00:03:11.464
You should start the app with start.

56
00:03:11.464 --> 00:03:15.708
Horrible, nonsensical, but
maybe a little more applicable than,

57
00:03:15.708 --> 00:03:17.618
here's some documentation.

58
00:03:17.618 --> 00:03:19.540
So here, you should start the app.

59
00:03:19.540 --> 00:03:23.010
Now, if we open our preview, again,
I'm gonna open up that Quick Menu,

60
00:03:23.010 --> 00:03:27.570
which is CMD+Shift+P for Mac users,
Ctrl+Shift+P for other users.

61
00:03:27.570 --> 00:03:29.700
That nice little menu bar.

62
00:03:29.700 --> 00:03:30.690
That's all I have, right?

63
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:34.920
Well, if I wanna keep this, but say,

64
00:03:34.920 --> 00:03:39.430
you should start the app with go,
now I have a decision to make.

65
00:03:39.430 --> 00:03:45.190
Do I mark out this entire thing,
or do I just mark out start?

66
00:03:45.190 --> 00:03:46.510
My recommendation is, just for

67
00:03:46.510 --> 00:03:51.270
comparison, it would be a little easier if
I did a strike-through on this portion,

68
00:03:51.270 --> 00:03:56.460
and then right down below it, or
right next to, it wrote my replacement.

69
00:03:56.460 --> 00:03:57.515
Now how do I strike-through?

70
00:03:58.690 --> 00:04:04.070
Well I have ~~ and
let's see if that actually comes out.

71
00:04:04.070 --> 00:04:08.066
Notice it is now struck through,
all right, so what is ~~?

72
00:04:08.066 --> 00:04:10.677
Well, ~ is usually right
next to your 1 key.

73
00:04:10.677 --> 00:04:14.570
It's shift, you do the back tick
that's something different, but

74
00:04:14.570 --> 00:04:16.460
it's the little squiggle.

75
00:04:16.460 --> 00:04:20.711
Because of my background,
that means a whole bunch of stuff,

76
00:04:20.711 --> 00:04:25.123
and depending on the context,
but here, if I write two of them,

77
00:04:25.123 --> 00:04:29.375
that means strike through, and
let's say you replace that,

78
00:04:29.375 --> 00:04:34.979
you should start the app with go, all
right, and this is very context specific.

79
00:04:34.979 --> 00:04:36.690
Notice you should to
start the app with go.

80
00:04:36.690 --> 00:04:38.308
That's right next to it.

81
00:04:38.308 --> 00:04:39.940
So this is what it used to be.

82
00:04:39.940 --> 00:04:41.640
This is what it is now.

83
00:04:41.640 --> 00:04:43.873
This is handy for comparison.

84
00:04:43.873 --> 00:04:50.174
Now there's nothing that limits this to
only having all of this entire thing.

85
00:04:50.174 --> 00:04:54.112
What if I, instead for my use case, I was
like, you know what, I'm not gonna rewrite

86
00:04:54.112 --> 00:04:58.560
this you should start the app with start,
I'm gonna rewrite this, I don't want that.

87
00:04:58.560 --> 00:05:02.030
I just want to strike out start and
replace it with go.

88
00:05:02.030 --> 00:05:05.580
Well does this work in line to the text?

89
00:05:05.580 --> 00:05:09.880
I'm a big proponent of let's
try it out and find out.

90
00:05:09.880 --> 00:05:12.197
Spoiler alert, I know the answer.

91
00:05:12.197 --> 00:05:14.391
[LAUGH] So if I add a tilda threre,

92
00:05:14.391 --> 00:05:19.285
I can actually strike through only
sub-portions of a section of text.

93
00:05:19.285 --> 00:05:25.716
So ~~, and then until it finds another ~~,
that's what's gonna be struck through.

94
00:05:25.716 --> 00:05:27.940
So I can strike through sub-portions.

95
00:05:27.940 --> 00:05:33.000
I can come over here, rewrite go, and
I should probably add a space there, and

96
00:05:33.000 --> 00:05:36.330
now I should, you should start
the app with not start, but go.

97
00:05:36.330 --> 00:05:38.620
That is another possibility.

98
00:05:38.620 --> 00:05:41.440
I can also combine these with
previous things that I've seen.

99
00:05:42.920 --> 00:05:47.768
What if I want go to be bolded?

100
00:05:47.768 --> 00:05:51.696
Well, there's bold,
there's bold, but in order for

101
00:05:51.696 --> 00:05:55.970
these to stay consistent,
maybe I had a bold start, right?

102
00:05:55.970 --> 00:05:59.040
That's a command,
I want that to jump out at you.

103
00:05:59.040 --> 00:06:00.670
Does this still work?

104
00:06:00.670 --> 00:06:04.230
Well, it is now bolded, but
it is also still struck through, and

105
00:06:04.230 --> 00:06:06.110
let me just zoom in there a little bit so
you can see.

106
00:06:06.110 --> 00:06:12.307
You should start the app with start,
still struck through, and then there's go.

107
00:06:12.307 --> 00:06:14.200
So that's incredibly handy.

108
00:06:14.200 --> 00:06:19.807
Now what I would be careful
about is if you go kind

109
00:06:19.807 --> 00:06:26.080
of ridiculous on it,
and add these, like so.

110
00:06:26.080 --> 00:06:29.634
So we have bold and italicized,
one of them struck through,

111
00:06:29.634 --> 00:06:32.224
and we come back over here,
it still works.

112
00:06:33.974 --> 00:06:36.630
But I would adopt a convention.

113
00:06:36.630 --> 00:06:39.420
If you're going to strike-through
something that is bold and italicized,

114
00:06:39.420 --> 00:06:43.950
the strike-through's on the outer part,
and then your formatting's on the inner,

115
00:06:43.950 --> 00:06:48.150
so you can totally enclose that section.

116
00:06:48.150 --> 00:06:50.726
Likewise, I would adopt
some convention internally,

117
00:06:50.726 --> 00:06:54.670
whether it's you writing documentation, or
your team, or something where you go if

118
00:06:54.670 --> 00:06:58.319
you have a bold in italics, it should
be italicized, then your bold section.

119
00:06:58.319 --> 00:07:02.880
If you're mixing these two things.

120
00:07:02.880 --> 00:07:05.360
Now, we've seen this before, right?

121
00:07:05.360 --> 00:07:08.960
What if I just leave off
one of these tildes.

122
00:07:08.960 --> 00:07:12.272
Let's see what happens there, because,

123
00:07:12.272 --> 00:07:17.884
in the last two things it was,
well one means this, two means this,

124
00:07:17.884 --> 00:07:22.668
I don't know,I don't know, and
I now actually get a tilde,

125
00:07:22.668 --> 00:07:27.280
so a single tilde by itself is
not a reserved character set.

126
00:07:27.280 --> 00:07:28.670
It just gives me a tilde.

127
00:07:28.670 --> 00:07:30.392
Why would that be?

128
00:07:30.392 --> 00:07:37.770
And well, from my background,
this takes approximately seven minutes.

129
00:07:37.770 --> 00:07:42.670
So you may see the tilde used
as an approximation symbol, and

130
00:07:42.670 --> 00:07:45.820
if the single symbol was the
strike-through symbol, then you're gonna

131
00:07:45.820 --> 00:07:51.040
get weird behavior, like well, you haven't
ended the symbol yet, where does it go to?

132
00:07:51.040 --> 00:07:56.520
So intentionally it's tilde,
tilde that is the strike-through portion.

133
00:07:56.520 --> 00:08:00.020
If by chance you really
wanted to emphasize that

134
00:08:00.020 --> 00:08:03.810
it's approximately seven minutes,
then if you put tilde, tilde,

135
00:08:03.810 --> 00:08:08.330
let's see what happens there, and
there we go, we haven't ended it.

136
00:08:08.330 --> 00:08:11.772
It still doesn't pair up.

137
00:08:11.772 --> 00:08:16.744
The only time you would need an escape
character here is if you wanted to

138
00:08:16.744 --> 00:08:22.647
surround these with tilde, tildes, but
you didn't want the strike-through and

139
00:08:22.647 --> 00:08:26.738
you would have to escape
these individual pieces here.

140
00:08:26.738 --> 00:08:30.598
Notice I escaped everyone of them just
to make sure I come back over here and

141
00:08:30.598 --> 00:08:32.588
now I have tilde tilde, tilde tilde,

142
00:08:32.588 --> 00:08:35.115
and we're all good to go.
>> You know Justin in some

143
00:08:35.115 --> 00:08:38.481
of the other episodes you showed
us with setting an italicised, or

144
00:08:38.481 --> 00:08:42.287
if you're talking about bolding your text,
you have a couple of options.

145
00:08:42.287 --> 00:08:45.091
You've got some variations and
it's up to you which one you use.

146
00:08:45.091 --> 00:08:48.080
Do we have that with the strike-through?
>> This is one of

147
00:08:48.080 --> 00:08:49.854
those kind of more edge cases.

148
00:08:49.854 --> 00:08:54.320
Strike-through, as far as I know Wes,
I'm not saying it's not out there,

149
00:08:54.320 --> 00:08:59.290
I've looked a great deal, tilde,
tilde is the strike-through operator.

150
00:08:59.290 --> 00:09:02.680
It's not a common one so,
and a lot of times,

151
00:09:02.680 --> 00:09:07.330
if I'm being completely transparent, the
reason we have two characters for bold and

152
00:09:07.330 --> 00:09:10.170
italicize is so
you can mix and match them.

153
00:09:10.170 --> 00:09:13.170
Strike-through is it what it is.

154
00:09:13.170 --> 00:09:14.515
That's it.

155
00:09:14.515 --> 00:09:20.010
So ~~, ~~, do keep in mind we're
talking about GitHub flavored markdown.

156
00:09:20.010 --> 00:09:24.341
If I'm not mistaken this is one of
those that, in other markdown flavors,

157
00:09:24.341 --> 00:09:27.917
you may get different behaviors with ~~,
and either side,

158
00:09:27.917 --> 00:09:30.964
maybe not a strike-through,
but something else.

159
00:09:30.964 --> 00:09:32.910
So do remember that.

160
00:09:32.910 --> 00:09:36.096
All GitHub flavored markdown for
all the things we're showing you here.

161
00:09:36.096 --> 00:09:36.602
>> All right,

162
00:09:36.602 --> 00:09:39.847
a lot of great episodes there when it
comes to placing emphasis on your text.

163
00:09:39.847 --> 00:09:41.980
We hope that you have enjoyed it.

164
00:09:41.980 --> 00:09:44.360
Now Justin it does look we're coming
to the end of another episode, but

165
00:09:44.360 --> 00:09:47.200
before we do, do you have any additional
words maybe you'd like to impart to

166
00:09:47.200 --> 00:09:51.790
the viewers before we sign out?
>> Well the entire impetus of this is

167
00:09:51.790 --> 00:09:55.460
I need to learn enough to
write a markdown document, and

168
00:09:55.460 --> 00:09:59.270
then it can be output to a more
kind of nice, pretty document.

169
00:09:59.270 --> 00:10:02.430
The really key point about
markdown is it's just plain text,

170
00:10:02.430 --> 00:10:05.364
until it goes through some
kind of transformation step.

171
00:10:05.364 --> 00:10:07.740
I can hand this to Wes,
he can open it on his computer.

172
00:10:07.740 --> 00:10:10.730
I can hand it to some of the production
team, they can open it on their computer,

173
00:10:10.730 --> 00:10:12.990
with just a standard text editor.

174
00:10:12.990 --> 00:10:17.123
It's not like other formats that
are specific to an application, and

175
00:10:17.123 --> 00:10:19.795
have encoding embedded in them and
whatnot.

176
00:10:19.795 --> 00:10:24.414
So, learning markdown, you're like,
why do I need to learn this when I have

177
00:10:24.414 --> 00:10:29.534
Microsoft Word, or LibreOffice, or,
this allows you the nice transportability,

178
00:10:29.534 --> 00:10:32.332
but also has a lot tooling
to make things nice.

179
00:10:32.332 --> 00:10:36.995
As I said in our previous episode,
I can get a PDF, an HTML, I can get a pub,

180
00:10:36.995 --> 00:10:41.732
a Moby, all kinds of output formats and
only have to know one markdown syntax

181
00:10:41.732 --> 00:10:46.691
with a couple of edge cases, cuz there
are a different flavors among those, but

182
00:10:46.691 --> 00:10:51.390
whatever you adopt, and when you have
that, you just write in plain text.

183
00:10:51.390 --> 00:10:55.590
You don't have to worry about selecting,
and it's very fine grain, and then you can

184
00:10:55.590 --> 00:11:00.780
just output as many types of information
or types of documents as you need.

185
00:11:00.780 --> 00:11:04.893
I find it incredibly handy, and really
versatile, and that's kind of my spiel for

186
00:11:04.893 --> 00:11:06.454
markdown.
>> All right Justin,

187
00:11:06.454 --> 00:11:09.919
as always we appreciate having you
in here in the studios with us, and

188
00:11:09.919 --> 00:11:12.331
we appreciate having you
the viewer watching.

189
00:11:12.331 --> 00:11:16.120
Hopefully we're helping you increase your
productivity when it comes to markdown,

190
00:11:16.120 --> 00:11:19.926
but until we see again, signing out for
DevPro.TV, I've been your host Wes Bryan,

191
00:11:19.926 --> 00:11:20.724
>> And I'm Justin Dennison,

192
00:11:20.724 --> 00:11:22.628
>> And we'll see you next time.

193
00:11:22.628 --> 00:11:28.114
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrate creating a link to an external site.
episodes.title: Adding an External Link
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.961 --> 00:00:14.425
Hello to all our viewers out there.

3
00:00:14.425 --> 00:00:17.520
Welcome back to DevProTV,
I'm your host Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:17.520 --> 00:00:21.565
And in today's episode, we are continuing
through our series in Markdown.

5
00:00:21.565 --> 00:00:23.956
And that's right, we're gonna be
looking at adding external links.

6
00:00:23.956 --> 00:00:27.372
And joining us back in the studios for
this very endeavor is none other than Mr.

7
00:00:27.372 --> 00:00:28.225
Justin Dennison.

8
00:00:28.225 --> 00:00:31.065
And, Justin, how we doing today sir?
>> I am doing fantastic, Wes, how are you?

9
00:00:31.065 --> 00:00:32.165
>> Hey, I'm doing great.

10
00:00:32.165 --> 00:00:36.690
We've kind of kicked off Markdown, and
we've looked at various topics, right?

11
00:00:36.690 --> 00:00:38.500
But when it comes to
adding external links,

12
00:00:38.500 --> 00:00:41.860
I have to tell you, I'm really
not exactly sure how to do that.

13
00:00:41.860 --> 00:00:44.446
So I'm hoping that you're
gonna take over from there.

14
00:00:44.446 --> 00:00:45.533
>> Well, here's hoping,

15
00:00:45.533 --> 00:00:48.340
because I definitely thought you
were gonna host this episode.

16
00:00:48.340 --> 00:00:50.623
But we'll wing it and
we'll see what happens.

17
00:00:50.623 --> 00:00:52.550
No, I jest, I jest.

18
00:00:52.550 --> 00:00:54.730
So external links,
what do I mean by external links?

19
00:00:54.730 --> 00:00:59.040
Well, it's a hyperlink to
an external site, that's all I mean.

20
00:00:59.040 --> 00:01:02.790
Now, the external site could be
actually another site that you own.

21
00:01:02.790 --> 00:01:05.310
Or another site that's some where else.

22
00:01:05.310 --> 00:01:10.536
Or if you're actually on GitHub,
or another website that renders

23
00:01:10.536 --> 00:01:15.781
Markdown into HTML, it can link
to other Markdown pieces, okay?

24
00:01:15.781 --> 00:01:18.520
So it's gonna be hard to show but

25
00:01:18.520 --> 00:01:23.580
you'll have to take a leap of faith on me,
just for that.

26
00:01:23.580 --> 00:01:27.025
Now, eventually, we may circle back around
and do a little more set up here, but

27
00:01:27.025 --> 00:01:28.560
I really wanna focus on the syntax.

28
00:01:28.560 --> 00:01:30.463
And not so much the setup of, well,

29
00:01:30.463 --> 00:01:34.399
this is how you put Markdown on GitHub,
or on Bitbucket, or on GitLab, or

30
00:01:34.399 --> 00:01:38.170
any of those other plethora of
sites that render Markdown as HTML.

31
00:01:38.170 --> 00:01:41.920
That's not the goal, I just wanna
show you how to make external links.

32
00:01:41.920 --> 00:01:42.970
I will tell you Wes,

33
00:01:42.970 --> 00:01:47.500
the first thing to show you is probably
gonna be a little underwhelming.

34
00:01:47.500 --> 00:01:49.840
But that's all right,
you've been forewarned.

35
00:01:49.840 --> 00:01:51.530
Let's go ahead and
take a look at the screen here.

36
00:01:51.530 --> 00:01:56.670
And I have my editor open, and let's just
create a new file called external links.

37
00:01:56.670 --> 00:02:01.733
Now, do remember,
having that Markdown syntax is important,

38
00:02:01.733 --> 00:02:04.720
so .md, don't forget that.

39
00:02:04.720 --> 00:02:07.880
And then, I’m just gonna close
this out real quick, all right?

40
00:02:07.880 --> 00:02:11.740
So let’s say that I want to
link to GitHub, all right?

41
00:02:11.740 --> 00:02:14.150
That’s very appropriate, because well,

42
00:02:14.150 --> 00:02:17.660
we’re going to use
GitHub Flavored Markdown.

43
00:02:17.660 --> 00:02:21.760
Now, this should work in most
of the other Markdown flavors.

44
00:02:21.760 --> 00:02:24.330
This is not necessarily
GitHub Flavored specific.

45
00:02:25.600 --> 00:02:27.300
This will only crop up from time to time.

46
00:02:27.300 --> 00:02:31.400
But if I save,
I've just typed a web address.

47
00:02:31.400 --> 00:02:34.740
You're like, Justin,
that doesn't look like very much.

48
00:02:34.740 --> 00:02:39.924
But let's come here and open the preview
to the side, and look at that.

49
00:02:39.924 --> 00:02:44.460
Markdown, a lot of times will say hey,
this looks like a web address.

50
00:02:44.460 --> 00:02:46.790
Let's go ahead and
make that a hyperlink for you.

51
00:02:46.790 --> 00:02:48.770
And that's exactly what it does.

52
00:02:48.770 --> 00:02:49.620
And if I were to click this,

53
00:02:49.620 --> 00:02:53.780
this would open up a Chrome browser,
take me to GitHub, and it's all good.

54
00:02:55.310 --> 00:02:59.120
That's actually all you have to do,
Wes, to have external links.

55
00:02:59.120 --> 00:03:03.577
I will say though,
there's some issues, right?

56
00:03:03.577 --> 00:03:07.571
Do I always have to have www.github.com?

57
00:03:07.571 --> 00:03:12.940
What if I wanna link that just says,
GitHub, but it links to github.com?

58
00:03:12.940 --> 00:03:15.870
This is not the best way, but
you should be aware of this.

59
00:03:15.870 --> 00:03:18.380
Because if you type something
that looks like a web address

60
00:03:18.380 --> 00:03:21.940
inside of your Markdown file, you put
it on GitHub, put it on Bitbucket, or

61
00:03:21.940 --> 00:03:25.140
any of the other sites,
it will actually turn it into a link.

62
00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:26.710
So do keep that in mind.

63
00:03:26.710 --> 00:03:29.580
So this is our first way
to create an external link.

64
00:03:29.580 --> 00:03:32.320
It's just write the web address and
it happens.

65
00:03:32.320 --> 00:03:36.060
And you're like, well,
that's actually pretty easy, it is.

66
00:03:36.060 --> 00:03:40.530
But let's say that I wanna give
it a different name, okay?

67
00:03:40.530 --> 00:03:45.730
I want to send to GitHub, but
instead of it being www.github.com,

68
00:03:45.730 --> 00:03:48.900
I actually want the word, GitHub stylized.

69
00:03:48.900 --> 00:03:53.255
So if we make some square brackets here,
and I want to keep these side by side,

70
00:03:53.255 --> 00:03:55.065
because I think that's handy.

71
00:03:55.065 --> 00:03:58.294
But I'm gonna zoom in just for a moment,
so we can make sure we see all of this.

72
00:03:58.294 --> 00:04:03.390
Two [] and then,
I'm going to type here, all right?

73
00:04:03.390 --> 00:04:06.220
And I'm coming outside of
those square brackets.

74
00:04:06.220 --> 00:04:09.030
And then, I'm going to put ().

75
00:04:09.030 --> 00:04:12.170
Notice my editor auto-completes
left right parentheses.

76
00:04:12.170 --> 00:04:17.322
So I have square brackets,
what I'm trying to type,

77
00:04:17.322 --> 00:04:22.478
and then in here,
I'm gonna say www.github.com.

78
00:04:22.478 --> 00:04:28.150
That's it, and now, I have what's

79
00:04:28.150 --> 00:04:31.090
But it actually is a link to github.com.

80
00:04:31.090 --> 00:04:34.038
Now, because I'm using this
on a local file system,

81
00:04:34.038 --> 00:04:37.128
it's kind of like doing some
additional things for me.

82
00:04:37.128 --> 00:04:44.420
So if you do that, if I'm not mistaken,
if you put the full, there, wait for it.

83
00:04:44.420 --> 00:04:46.720
Now, it's not gonna give me the,
there we go.

84
00:04:46.720 --> 00:04:52.075
Notice, by putting the https:// it doesn't
assume that I'm talking about a folder or

85
00:04:52.075 --> 00:04:53.418
a file with that name.

86
00:04:53.418 --> 00:04:56.610
It actually says, that's a web URL.

87
00:04:56.610 --> 00:05:00.110
So do keep that in mind if

88
00:05:00.110 --> 00:05:02.620
And you should probably just go ahead and

00:05:02.620 --> 00:05:05.900
be very explicit about that,
instead of just leaving that off.

90
00:05:05.900 --> 00:05:08.560
Like sometimes, I admit that I do.

00:05:08.560 --> 00:05:11.180
And who knows where we end up, right?

92
00:05:11.180 --> 00:05:16.630
So I have this, if I want different text,
I can put that text here,

00:05:16.630 --> 00:05:21.080
and then in parenthesis following it,

94
00:05:21.080 --> 00:05:27.937
Now, there's additional
descriptors that I can put.

95
00:05:27.937 --> 00:05:30.950
No, I lied,
I'm thinking of something else.

96
00:05:30.950 --> 00:05:36.170
What I am gonna talk about is, let's say,
that now I wanna go to Google, right?

97
00:05:36.170 --> 00:05:37.760
There's Google, just like that.

98
00:05:38.890 --> 00:05:40.890
But I don't wanna put that link in line.

99
00:05:40.890 --> 00:05:47.045
Let's say that I want to reuse Google,
or the link for Google, multiple times.

100
00:05:47.045 --> 00:05:48.410
Well, you're like, that's easy.

101
00:05:48.410 --> 00:05:53.537
You just type it and
you say, www.google.com.

102
00:05:53.537 --> 00:05:56.050
And then, you just copy and
paste that everywhere, right?

103
00:05:56.050 --> 00:05:58.740
So this is some text.

104
00:06:00.360 --> 00:06:06.640
The following is the link to and
then, boom!

105
00:06:06.640 --> 00:06:08.930
Right, we can put that
in line just like that.

106
00:06:08.930 --> 00:06:10.560
But notice I have this duplication.

107
00:06:10.560 --> 00:06:13.696
That's kind of weird, right?

108
00:06:13.696 --> 00:06:17.060
Not necessarily what we want.

109
00:06:17.060 --> 00:06:21.480
It would be nice if instead of having to
put this parenthesis with the link to

110
00:06:21.480 --> 00:06:26.480
the web address, if we could just put the
square brackets, have it render the link,

111
00:06:26.480 --> 00:06:28.129
because it knows what it is.

112
00:06:29.730 --> 00:06:32.630
But you do still have to
send it to the web address.

113
00:06:32.630 --> 00:06:37.760
Now, what do I mean,
I want to just type this, like that.

114
00:06:37.760 --> 00:06:45.570
And then let's say, I wanted to say here's
another link To Google, just like that.

115
00:06:45.570 --> 00:06:46.650
You look at the preview.

116
00:06:47.890 --> 00:06:52.243
Because I do not have those parenthesis,
I don't have a link to that web address.

117
00:06:52.243 --> 00:06:54.470
I don't know what that is.

118
00:06:54.470 --> 00:06:59.420
Well, anywhere in your document, and
I like to kinda put these at the bottom.

119
00:07:00.820 --> 00:07:04.399
If we now type Google, and

120
00:07:04.399 --> 00:07:11.574
you say https://www.google.com, and boom!

121
00:07:11.574 --> 00:07:13.670
We got some weirdness here.

122
00:07:13.670 --> 00:07:20.231
So let's look, and we got Google, what?

123
00:07:20.231 --> 00:07:26.617
Well, let's go, I am sorry, not that.

124
00:07:26.617 --> 00:07:29.492
But instead, it should be.

125
00:07:29.492 --> 00:07:31.070
You know what, Wes?

126
00:07:31.070 --> 00:07:32.956
I think I'm missing
a couple of characters.

127
00:07:32.956 --> 00:07:36.780
So I wanna back up just to bring
some clarity to what I'm saying.

128
00:07:38.630 --> 00:07:43.090
Somewhere else in my document,
I can now write this link.

129
00:07:43.090 --> 00:07:46.680
So notice it's [Google],
just like I have up here.

130
00:07:46.680 --> 00:07:49.974
And let's move this over just
a little bit so we can see.

131
00:07:49.974 --> 00:07:51.360
So [Google], and

132
00:07:51.360 --> 00:07:55.910
then here's the difference, colon,
I'm essentially making a definition.

133
00:07:55.910 --> 00:07:58.320
What does [Google] mean?

134
00:07:59.370 --> 00:08:02.742
Well, it means everywhere
you see [Google],

135
00:08:02.742 --> 00:08:05.712
make sure that this link is there, right?

136
00:08:05.712 --> 00:08:11.450
Now, you'll notice, if I take this
colon off, I get this [Google], right?

137
00:08:11.450 --> 00:08:15.090
I feel kind of odd saying square
bracket Google, but that's all right.

138
00:08:15.090 --> 00:08:19.490
If I put the colon back on,
they now become links.

139
00:08:19.490 --> 00:08:25.440
Likewise, if I forget any piece of this,
they don't work anymore.

140
00:08:25.440 --> 00:08:26.619
This just doesn't work.

141
00:08:28.024 --> 00:08:31.500
And if I put them back, I do.

142
00:08:31.500 --> 00:08:36.718
Now, the following question to that is,
if it's so

143
00:08:36.718 --> 00:08:41.235
specific, what if I make
this a lower case g?

144
00:08:41.235 --> 00:08:44.652
I make this a lower case g,
that's kind of odd.

145
00:08:44.652 --> 00:08:49.116
So the delimitation, the bracket
delimitation, the colon, all of it,

146
00:08:49.116 --> 00:08:53.446
that's very specific, but
it looks like it's matching pretty good.

147
00:08:53.446 --> 00:08:56.043
And just to make sure,
let's close this out.

148
00:08:56.043 --> 00:09:00.954
We're just gonna make sure and
we're gonna, maybe,

149
00:09:00.954 --> 00:09:04.920
open preview to the side and
it still works.

150
00:09:04.920 --> 00:09:08.790
So this isn't as much,
it doesn't have to be a single word.

151
00:09:10.640 --> 00:09:15.240
But it doesn't look like case has
as much bearing as other times.

152
00:09:15.240 --> 00:09:20.515
But what if I want to do a multiple
phrase, like HERE IS GOOGLE.

153
00:09:20.515 --> 00:09:24.413
And apparently I wanna yell it.

154
00:09:24.413 --> 00:09:29.085
So HERE IS GOOGLE: and then https,

155
00:09:29.085 --> 00:09:32.200
I'm still yelling it,

156
00:09:32.200 --> 00:09:37.201
www.google.com, just like that.

157
00:09:37.201 --> 00:09:41.230
And notice that entire phrase has
been matched, has now been changed.

158
00:09:41.230 --> 00:09:47.370
And this is incredibly handy if I want to
reuse these links just by this little tag,

159
00:09:47.370 --> 00:09:50.330
right, this little shortened version.

160
00:09:50.330 --> 00:09:55.074
So I don't have to replicate
this portion over,

161
00:09:55.074 --> 00:09:58.207
and over, and over again, so,

162
00:10:00.204 --> 00:10:04.340
Here is now a fun time,
just to make sure, here is google.

163
00:10:05.530 --> 00:10:08.570
And notice, these are all lowercase
letters, these are all uppercase letters.

164
00:10:08.570 --> 00:10:12.430
It still matches those, case doesn't
match, but the syntax is very important.

165
00:10:12.430 --> 00:10:16.270
So if I wanna make external links,
I can do a couple of things.

166
00:10:16.270 --> 00:10:22.599
I can square bracket, the name,
square bracket, and then parenthesis,

167
00:10:22.599 --> 00:10:28.034
put the URL in those parenthesis
directly after, I can do that.

168
00:10:28.034 --> 00:10:30.220
I can actually just type the URL.

169
00:10:31.260 --> 00:10:38.020
It will not rename, but it will just
give me a link version of that URL.

170
00:10:38.020 --> 00:10:39.950
So it's looking for that.

171
00:10:39.950 --> 00:10:45.400
And then otherwise,
I can do this definition style, right?

172
00:10:45.400 --> 00:10:49.300
So if I have Google in square brackets,
and then a colon.

173
00:10:49.300 --> 00:10:52.530
And then what that means,
either the bottom, the top,

174
00:10:52.530 --> 00:10:56.130
somewhere in your document, it goes,
all right that's a definition.

175
00:10:56.130 --> 00:11:00.900
Everywhere I see [Google],
not case sensitive, replace that with

176
00:11:00.900 --> 00:11:05.680
the linked version, right, the linkified
version, if that's even a word.

177
00:11:06.710 --> 00:11:09.510
And now, that will work, okay?

178
00:11:09.510 --> 00:11:13.868
So that's how those things,
as far as external links, behave.

179
00:11:13.868 --> 00:11:17.991
And well, with those three you should
be have all of your bases covered,

180
00:11:17.991 --> 00:11:19.270
at least initially.

181
00:11:19.270 --> 00:11:23.070
Now, this is not a full deep dive but
this is to get you started.

182
00:11:23.070 --> 00:11:24.928
Here's a few things to take away.

183
00:11:24.928 --> 00:11:26.220
Start writing your Markdown files,

184
00:11:26.220 --> 00:11:28.440
especially if you need
links to external sites.

185
00:11:28.440 --> 00:11:31.780
Which, if you're writing documentation,
is typically the case.

186
00:11:31.780 --> 00:11:34.114
>> I could have used that advice, myself,

187
00:11:34.114 --> 00:11:36.174
in some of my Markdown documents and

188
00:11:36.174 --> 00:11:40.583
not littering the entire document up
with URLs and addresses galore there.

189
00:11:40.583 --> 00:11:43.106
So we appreciate that information,
there, Justin.

190
00:11:43.106 --> 00:11:43.845
Before we sign out,

191
00:11:43.845 --> 00:11:46.640
do you have any additional words maybe
you'd like to impart to our viewers?

192
00:11:46.640 --> 00:11:49.858
Cuz I know we got a lot more to come.
>> Over this course of this series,

193
00:11:49.858 --> 00:11:52.600
we're gonna see, I could do that, and
I could do that, and I could do that.

194
00:11:52.600 --> 00:11:55.940
My word of recommendation is
find the things like Wes just,

195
00:11:55.940 --> 00:11:58.800
I have URLs all over the place.

196
00:11:58.800 --> 00:12:02.570
Pick this one, use this one to clean
up your Markdown documents to make them

197
00:12:02.570 --> 00:12:07.180
a little more readable, a little
easier to go, that's how that works.

198
00:12:07.180 --> 00:12:10.330
And in that way, you become
a little more efficient with time.

199
00:12:10.330 --> 00:12:14.670
Don't try to do everything,
I figured out this little trick.

200
00:12:15.710 --> 00:12:17.340
Everything at once, don't do that.

201
00:12:17.340 --> 00:12:20.410
Pick up little snippets that you make
you more productive, more efficient.

202
00:12:20.410 --> 00:12:22.790
And then run with those until
you feel comfortable, and then,

203
00:12:22.790 --> 00:12:25.770
pick up the next one.
>> Well, time has come there, Justin,

204
00:12:25.770 --> 00:12:27.450
parting is such sweet sorrow.

205
00:12:27.450 --> 00:12:30.350
But it does look like we have come

206
00:12:30.350 --> 00:12:32.900
We appreciate having you,

Keep in mind that we've got plenty more

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrate how to create different sized of headings within a Markdown document.
episodes.title: Creating Headings
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.851 --> 00:00:17.320
Hello and thanks for tuning in to more
DevProTV, I'm your show host Wes Bryan.

3
00:00:17.320 --> 00:00:18.650
And in today's episode,

4
00:00:18.650 --> 00:00:21.860
well we are continuing through
our GitHub flavored markdown.

5
00:00:21.860 --> 00:00:25.505
And joining us back in the studios to
continue on in this endeavor is Mr.

6
00:00:25.505 --> 00:00:26.487
Justin Dennison.

7
00:00:26.487 --> 00:00:27.511
,Justin how we doing sir?

8
00:00:27.511 --> 00:00:29.410
>> I'm doing fantastic Wes,
and how are you today?

9
00:00:29.410 --> 00:00:32.590
>> Hey I'm doing great, we've been
talking about a lot of different topics,

10
00:00:32.590 --> 00:00:35.830
things like external links,
and some of the basics here.

11
00:00:35.830 --> 00:00:38.470
But we're gonna be talking
about creating headings.

12
00:00:38.470 --> 00:00:41.700
>> Yes, we are going to be talking
about creating headings, and

13
00:00:41.700 --> 00:00:43.360
what do I mean by headings?

14
00:00:43.360 --> 00:00:45.670
Well, for the most part,
we think of them as headers.

15
00:00:45.670 --> 00:00:48.470
But I'm using the word
headings specifically

16
00:00:48.470 --> 00:00:50.740
because of what they translate to,
all right?

17
00:00:50.740 --> 00:00:53.540
So if you come to a document whether
it's marked down or whatever.

18
00:00:53.540 --> 00:00:58.290
You have like these respective levels
of large text that is typically bold.

19
00:00:58.290 --> 00:01:02.564
And then if you have subsections you get a
little bit smaller text, it might be bold.

20
00:01:02.564 --> 00:01:06.213
Then if you have subsections in there,
you have a little bit smaller text and

21
00:01:06.213 --> 00:01:07.589
they're kind of bold also.

22
00:01:07.589 --> 00:01:09.790
And then after they may not be bold but

23
00:01:09.790 --> 00:01:12.945
essentially it's to set
off respective sections.

24
00:01:12.945 --> 00:01:17.560
It's to give tips to the hierarchical
structure of your document, right?

25
00:01:17.560 --> 00:01:20.502
So a chapter might have
very large heading text.

26
00:01:20.502 --> 00:01:24.323
But if there are subsections in the
chapter depending on what you're writing,

27
00:01:24.323 --> 00:01:27.030
you may need a little bit smaller texts,
right?

28
00:01:27.030 --> 00:01:32.510
And then inside of those if you have
little chunks that need to be set aside,

29
00:01:32.510 --> 00:01:35.000
you can have smaller sets of text.

30
00:01:35.000 --> 00:01:38.610
So how does one do this if you're in HTML?

31
00:01:38.610 --> 00:01:40.010
It's a little more involved.

32
00:01:40.010 --> 00:01:44.099
If you're in Word,
you gotta highlight and select it.

33
00:01:44.099 --> 00:01:46.960
However in markdown,
mmarkdown makes it easy actually.

34
00:01:46.960 --> 00:01:51.290
Let's take a look at the screen here and
see how it all comes into play.

35
00:01:51.290 --> 00:01:55.055
So we're gonna create a new document,
and let's just call it headings.

36
00:01:55.055 --> 00:01:59.462
And do keep in mind I'm
using that .md right?

37
00:01:59.462 --> 00:02:04.880
So make sure I have my markdown, I am
kind of gonna harp on that a great deal.

38
00:02:04.880 --> 00:02:08.558
Something you saw just flick out of
the way, I used a keyboard shortcut.

39
00:02:08.558 --> 00:02:12.310
You can always just click here in
your editor to hide and show that,

40
00:02:12.310 --> 00:02:14.280
so do keep that in mind.

41
00:02:14.280 --> 00:02:17.570
Now let's say that I'm building something,
right?

42
00:02:17.570 --> 00:02:20.080
And this is my first chapter,

43
00:02:20.080 --> 00:02:24.960
I'm building Chapter 1, so
Chapter 1 of a technical document.

44
00:02:24.960 --> 00:02:29.160
So Chapter 1, notice I put this hash,

45
00:02:29.160 --> 00:02:33.790
also known as an octothorpe, or
a pound sign out at the beginning.

46
00:02:33.790 --> 00:02:39.258
Let's remove that space, as long as I
have that, I get some highlighting here.

47
00:02:39.258 --> 00:02:46.230
So Chapter 1: Intro to Markdown,
all right, whatever it may be.

48
00:02:46.230 --> 00:02:49.740
Now, let's see how this
looks when I do a preview.

49
00:02:49.740 --> 00:02:53.972
So that's Cmd+Shift+ P or
Ctrl+Shift+P if you're not on a Mac.

50
00:02:53.972 --> 00:02:58.897
I'm gonna open the preview to the side,
notice that they're large and bold.

51
00:02:58.897 --> 00:03:03.166
This is a heading one,
a single pound sign, a single octothorpe,

52
00:03:03.166 --> 00:03:06.765
single hashtag depending on
what age group you're in.

53
00:03:06.765 --> 00:03:10.141
That means I have a level one heading,
okay?

54
00:03:10.141 --> 00:03:13.740
You also see these named headers, but

55
00:03:13.740 --> 00:03:17.120
because of my background
I get a little weird.

56
00:03:17.120 --> 00:03:19.060
If you were to talk to Vonne,

57
00:03:19.060 --> 00:03:23.766
well, she would probably say,
well actually it's this.

58
00:03:23.766 --> 00:03:25.750
So it kind of depends on the terminology.

59
00:03:25.750 --> 00:03:28.630
Just know this is top level section.

60
00:03:28.630 --> 00:03:31.860
Now, inside of this intro to markdown,
let's say I come in here and

61
00:03:31.860 --> 00:03:36.030
I'm like, this is my intro document.

62
00:03:37.660 --> 00:03:41.930
And then here I want to
talk about headings, right?

63
00:03:41.930 --> 00:03:43.460
So this is a subsection.

64
00:03:43.460 --> 00:03:48.950
Notice I put ## Headings in markdown.

65
00:03:50.830 --> 00:03:56.130
Okay, so Chapter 1: Intro to Markdown,
notice this is a little smaller.

66
00:03:56.130 --> 00:04:01.619
Notice, well it is still bold or it kind
of looks bold, a little bit smaller.

67
00:04:01.619 --> 00:04:04.579
But it does set off from
the rest of the text, and

68
00:04:04.579 --> 00:04:09.100
I'm going to remove that because
I want that immediately.

69
00:04:09.100 --> 00:04:11.380
And my editor's showing
some selections here.

70
00:04:11.380 --> 00:04:15.770
This is not always necessarily guaranteed,
depending on the renderer.

71
00:04:15.770 --> 00:04:19.720
So there's some differences there,
so Headings in Markdown.

72
00:04:19.720 --> 00:04:22.760
And I'm gonna say,
well there are several types of headings.

73
00:04:24.040 --> 00:04:28.300
There are several types of headings.

74
00:04:28.300 --> 00:04:32.490
And notice, that is a section,

75
00:04:32.490 --> 00:04:38.250
kind of this subsection heading, or
header, depending on your terminology.

76
00:04:38.250 --> 00:04:41.550
And then there's this remaining portion,
right?

77
00:04:41.550 --> 00:04:46.387
This is standard text,
and then if I wanna go,

78
00:04:46.387 --> 00:04:50.490
well, let me talk about heading ones.

79
00:04:50.490 --> 00:04:55.752
Or better yet, Headings Level 3, notice,

80
00:04:55.752 --> 00:05:01.151
if I scroll up here,
I know have a heading one,

81
00:05:01.151 --> 00:05:04.340
big, bold, in your face.

82
00:05:04.340 --> 00:05:06.450
This is to grab your attention.

83
00:05:06.450 --> 00:05:11.340
Within that section I have two pound
signs, Headings in Markdown, and

84
00:05:11.340 --> 00:05:14.090
then I'm going to talk
about Headings Level 3.

85
00:05:14.090 --> 00:05:17.000
I call it level 3 because
it has three pound signs.

86
00:05:17.000 --> 00:05:20.020
If you're from an HTML
background this is an H3,

87
00:05:20.020 --> 00:05:25.190
that's what these get translated to,
either respective H1, H2, H3s.

88
00:05:25.190 --> 00:05:27.170
And this is a little bit smaller.

89
00:05:27.170 --> 00:05:29.871
I am not even sure it is
still bold at this point,

90
00:05:29.871 --> 00:05:32.386
it is kinda hard to see
with that white text.

91
00:05:32.386 --> 00:05:37.920
And you continue on and now you want
to talk about heading fours, right?

92
00:05:37.920 --> 00:05:41.869
Headings Level 4, and
notice that is bold, so

93
00:05:41.869 --> 00:05:46.690
looking at that I can tell
this previous one is not bold.

94
00:05:46.690 --> 00:05:50.857
This one is bold but
the font size is smaller.

95
00:05:50.857 --> 00:05:56.066
So I got H1, H2, H3, H4 for
those from web development land,

96
00:05:56.066 --> 00:06:02.050
or a little bit of HTML knowledge or
top level heading, first subsection.

97
00:06:02.050 --> 00:06:07.150
A subsection within this subsection and
then a subsection within this subsection.

98
00:06:07.150 --> 00:06:11.930
So if I want to make this more clear,
hierarchical things to consider

99
00:06:13.430 --> 00:06:17.818
with heading 3, okay?

100
00:06:17.818 --> 00:06:20.230
So notice that this is now telling me,
hey,

101
00:06:20.230 --> 00:06:22.050
within this subsection I have this here.

102
00:06:23.230 --> 00:06:28.020
And, well, if you have to guess,
there's actually an H5.

103
00:06:29.380 --> 00:06:31.320
So, Heading 5.

104
00:06:32.620 --> 00:06:37.840
Tiny, tiny, and these are almost either
footnotes or I wanna draw your attention,

105
00:06:37.840 --> 00:06:42.180
but it's still within this,
maybe a caption or a little offset.

106
00:06:42.180 --> 00:06:47.190
And there is an H6, So Heading 6.

107
00:06:47.190 --> 00:06:51.670
Tiny font, still kind of bold,
and we have these respectively.

108
00:06:51.670 --> 00:06:56.368
Now if I were to take all of these and
just put them one right after the other.

109
00:06:56.368 --> 00:06:59.345
Then you could see the progression
of getting smaller,

110
00:06:59.345 --> 00:07:01.760
changing kind of the font weight so
to speak.

111
00:07:03.340 --> 00:07:08.787
Something to keep in mind when you're
using these chunks in markdown,

112
00:07:08.787 --> 00:07:15.531
people do not conform too much to, well,
you need to start with the first heading.

113
00:07:15.531 --> 00:07:17.689
And then add another heading, and

114
00:07:17.689 --> 00:07:22.960
then add another heading to actually
enforce that hierarchical structure.

115
00:07:22.960 --> 00:07:24.905
If you were doing this
in some other places,

116
00:07:24.905 --> 00:07:26.597
you wouldn't need to adhere to that.

117
00:07:26.597 --> 00:07:30.290
That's convention,
that's a recommendation.

118
00:07:31.340 --> 00:07:33.260
I have seen a great deal of people go,

119
00:07:33.260 --> 00:07:36.160
I don't really want this
large Chapter 1 intro.

120
00:07:36.160 --> 00:07:39.286
I actually want it to be
a little bit smaller, so

121
00:07:39.286 --> 00:07:42.190
they'll use an H2 because it's smaller.

122
00:07:42.190 --> 00:07:47.380
And you're not customizing the styling of
the render, you're just using this to go.

123
00:07:47.380 --> 00:07:49.390
I want this to kind of pop out.

124
00:07:49.390 --> 00:07:52.610
But maybe not quite as big as an H1 so
maybe I'll use an H2.

125
00:07:52.610 --> 00:07:57.501
So markdown does enforce some practices
that are not ubiquitous across

126
00:07:57.501 --> 00:07:59.139
all of the industries.

127
00:07:59.139 --> 00:08:03.660
But if I wanted headings with respective
subsections, I just need to remember,

128
00:08:03.660 --> 00:08:06.200
pound sign and how many pound signs?

129
00:08:06.200 --> 00:08:09.720
As I count up,
I get a little bit smaller, right, and

130
00:08:09.720 --> 00:08:13.350
that reflects the individual subsections.

131
00:08:13.350 --> 00:08:16.560
I could try an H7,
just to see if it works.

132
00:08:17.680 --> 00:08:22.500
