Heading 7, and notice in my renderer,
it doesn't even recognize that,

133
00:08:22.500 --> 00:08:28.790
because I only get one, two, three,
four, five, or possibly six.

134
00:08:28.790 --> 00:08:30.260
I don't get any more than that, and

135
00:08:30.260 --> 00:08:32.680
any less than that,
then it's just regular text.

136
00:08:32.680 --> 00:08:33.550
So do keep that in mind.

137
00:08:33.550 --> 00:08:36.240
So if you need headings
within your documents,

138
00:08:36.240 --> 00:08:40.010
It's just the matter of adding pound
signs to those respective lines.

139
00:08:40.010 --> 00:08:44.330
>> I always wondered at what point in
history would we find out that if you call

140
00:08:44.330 --> 00:08:46.900
it a pound symbol, nobody is going
to recognize what that means.

141
00:08:46.900 --> 00:08:50.310
And the moment you call it a hashtag
symbol, everyone is like, I know!

142
00:08:50.310 --> 00:08:53.830
So a lot of great information Justin,
we appreciate having you in the studio.

143
00:08:53.830 --> 00:08:56.240
Keep in mind out there viewers,
we have much more to go.

144
00:08:56.240 --> 00:09:00.470
But you're gonna have to stick around and
stay tuned to figure out what is next.

145
00:09:00.470 --> 00:09:03.920
So signing out here from DevProTV I
have been your host Wes Bryan.

146
00:09:03.920 --> 00:09:04.960
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

147
00:09:04.960 --> 00:09:06.691
>> We'll see you next time.

148
00:09:06.691 --> 00:09:11.239
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes explore creating a blockquote using Markdown syntax.
episodes.title: Creating a Blockquote
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:03.949
[SOUND Hello and

2
00:00:03.949 --> 00:00:09.211
welcome back to another

3
00:00:09.211 --> 00:00:16.581
great episode here at DevPro TV.

4
00:00:16.581 --> 00:00:18.839
I'm your host Wes Bryan and
in today's episode,

5
00:00:18.839 --> 00:00:21.756
we're continuing our series in
the GitHub flavored markdown.

6
00:00:21.756 --> 00:00:25.010
And joining us back in the studios is,
you know him, you love him, Mr.

7
00:00:25.010 --> 00:00:25.888
Justin Dennison.

8
00:00:25.888 --> 00:00:27.097
Justin, how are we doing today, sir?

9
00:00:27.097 --> 00:00:28.376
>> I am doing fantastic, Wes.

10
00:00:28.376 --> 00:00:29.036
And how are you?

11
00:00:29.036 --> 00:00:31.962
>> I'm doing great., we're gonna be
looking at things, like for instance,

12
00:00:31.962 --> 00:00:33.143
creating a Blockquote today.

13
00:00:33.143 --> 00:00:36.975
And I have to tell you, I'm not exactly
sure how we're gonna accomplish that.

14
00:00:36.975 --> 00:00:38.558
So, it's a good thing we have you here.

15
00:00:38.558 --> 00:00:41.752
>> Well, hopefully, I know what I'm doing
because I definitely thought you were

16
00:00:41.752 --> 00:00:42.966
gonna show us how to do it.

17
00:00:42.966 --> 00:00:44.313
>> [LAUGH], it's gonna be a short episode.

18
00:00:44.313 --> 00:00:45.545
>> But I've been put on the spot, so

19
00:00:45.545 --> 00:00:47.223
I guess I'm gonna just
gonna have to wing it.

20
00:00:47.223 --> 00:00:50.350
But before we do that, let's actually
talk about what is a Blockquote.

21
00:00:50.350 --> 00:00:51.043
Why would I care?

22
00:00:51.043 --> 00:00:52.540
When would I use it, right?

23
00:00:53.660 --> 00:00:57.940
Well, a lot of times you have some
kind of little inspirational quote or

24
00:00:57.940 --> 00:01:00.650
something that you want to set aside and
attribute to someone.

25
00:01:00.650 --> 00:01:03.220
And if you've ever seen
these hanging indents,

26
00:01:03.220 --> 00:01:05.160
I think that's what they're called.

27
00:01:05.160 --> 00:01:09.180
This is where I should have
consulted an additional expert here.

28
00:01:09.180 --> 00:01:12.900
So you bring it in, you have
a little bit different styling, and

29
00:01:12.900 --> 00:01:18.460
then you have a subquote,
like things are cool, said by Justin.

30
00:01:18.460 --> 00:01:24.900
So these individual Blockquotes
are nice to all to set aside a section

31
00:01:24.900 --> 00:01:30.960
to pull attention to a quote but also to
attribute it to someone else, all right?

32
00:01:30.960 --> 00:01:34.260
So you would use these in your documents
if you wanted to quote somebody.

33
00:01:34.260 --> 00:01:36.250
You're using an inspirational quote,

34
00:01:36.250 --> 00:01:41.430
or if you're telling a narrative,
you're using that as a starting point?

35
00:01:41.430 --> 00:01:46.050
Great to draw attention to those,
because those can be very important.

36
00:01:46.050 --> 00:01:49.037
It seems like that would be
really hard to do in Markdown.

37
00:01:49.037 --> 00:01:52.406
Indentation and and
I gotta hit tab and all that.

38
00:01:52.406 --> 00:01:56.810
Well, Markdown actually provides
that kind of out of the box and

39
00:01:56.810 --> 00:01:59.510
it's not too hard to accomplish.

40
00:01:59.510 --> 00:02:02.280
Couple of things we need to keep
in mind as we're using these but

41
00:02:02.280 --> 00:02:04.077
I think we'll see these as they come up.

42
00:02:04.077 --> 00:02:06.798
So let's go ahead and
take a look at the screen here and

43
00:02:06.798 --> 00:02:08.683
let's just make some Blockquotes.

44
00:02:08.683 --> 00:02:13.854
So if I open this up,
I'm going to say blockquote.md,

45
00:02:13.854 --> 00:02:18.150
as always making sure I
have that .md format.

46
00:02:19.700 --> 00:02:25.195
Lets say I'm writing along like stuff and
things.

47
00:02:25.195 --> 00:02:28.225
And then, I come down here and
I wanna quote.

48
00:02:28.225 --> 00:02:32.105
I'm telling a story and

49
00:02:32.105 --> 00:02:37.348
I wanna use this as a reference.

50
00:02:37.348 --> 00:02:40.324
As Gandhi said, and I make no hard,

51
00:02:40.324 --> 00:02:45.208
I have to mention that I'll
get all of these quotes right.

52
00:02:45.208 --> 00:02:49.216
So don't be like, actually so and so said.

53
00:02:49.216 --> 00:02:51.461
It's just for educational purposes.

54
00:02:51.461 --> 00:02:55.719
Notice I put this greater than sign, okay.

55
00:02:55.719 --> 00:03:00.160
Greater than sign at
the beginning of that line.

56
00:03:00.160 --> 00:03:06.780
Notice it turns green,
that is creating a line in a Blockquote.

57
00:03:06.780 --> 00:03:12.358
So, be the change you
want to see in the world.

58
00:03:12.358 --> 00:03:15.196
And I guess I should zoom out so
we can all that.

59
00:03:15.196 --> 00:03:19.109
So I had this single line,
as my Blockquote.

60
00:03:19.109 --> 00:03:22.798
That's just a simple quote, it doesn't
look too much different than just typing

61
00:03:22.798 --> 00:03:24.728
text, other than that single character.

62
00:03:24.728 --> 00:03:29.371
But as we've seen with markdown, that
sometimes provides a great deal of power.

63
00:03:29.371 --> 00:03:34.476
So if I open this up,
open it to the side, and you see here,

64
00:03:34.476 --> 00:03:41.278
it kinda offsets it a little bit, and
puts this kind of shaded border around.

65
00:03:41.278 --> 00:03:45.200
And usually, my text editor
is making this a little blue.

66
00:03:45.200 --> 00:03:47.345
There is usually a kind of dark line,

67
00:03:47.345 --> 00:03:51.166
either dark gray depending on
the style of what's rendering it.

68
00:03:51.166 --> 00:03:57.007
Puts this line at the beginning to say,
hey, this is a block of texts.

69
00:03:57.007 --> 00:04:01.607
So seeing that, okay,
that draws attention to without being

70
00:04:01.607 --> 00:04:05.329
a heading as we've seen
in the previous episode.

71
00:04:05.329 --> 00:04:09.200
I'm not sure I wanna this thing to be
giant, or bold or anything like that.

72
00:04:09.200 --> 00:04:12.398
I just want you to pay attention to it,
but also say,

73
00:04:12.398 --> 00:04:14.594
okay, this is just standard text.

74
00:04:14.594 --> 00:04:19.953
Now if I scroll out,
what if I came down here and I said,

75
00:04:19.953 --> 00:04:24.776
well, Justin says,
who knows who are right here.

76
00:04:24.776 --> 00:04:26.330
So I need another line.

77
00:04:27.850 --> 00:04:30.572
Markdown is awesome.

78
00:04:30.572 --> 00:04:33.588
And then, let's say there's
another part of the quote, but

79
00:04:33.588 --> 00:04:37.187
I don't want this all on a single line,
I kinda want this chunk together.

80
00:04:37.187 --> 00:04:41.807
Well, I can add another one of these, and

81
00:04:41.807 --> 00:04:44.844
say, it really really is.

82
00:04:44.844 --> 00:04:50.082
And not as your like what I figured
that will be on multiple lines, right.

83
00:04:50.082 --> 00:04:57.210
The block, this handles, irrespective
like how much is going on, right.

84
00:04:57.210 --> 00:04:58.126
What I mean is,

85
00:04:58.126 --> 00:05:02.504
the length of the line determines whether
it wraps to the next line or not.

86
00:05:02.504 --> 00:05:06.151
If, however, it's more readable for
you to do it on multiple

87
00:05:06.151 --> 00:05:10.710
lines than if you put the greater than
at the beginning of each of those lines,

88
00:05:10.710 --> 00:05:12.974
then it kind of puts them altogether.

89
00:05:12.974 --> 00:05:16.376
>> Now Justin, one of the things I've
noticed is unlike some of the other ways

90
00:05:16.376 --> 00:05:19.356
that you manipulate the text,
you're not closing this one off.

91
00:05:19.356 --> 00:05:22.012
Like, for instance,
you feel there's another episodes,

92
00:05:22.012 --> 00:05:24.926
that if you wanna do I italicized words so
I can use the underscore,

93
00:05:24.926 --> 00:05:27.962
you can use the asterisk symbol but
you've had to close the text off.

94
00:05:27.962 --> 00:05:31.778
So it kinda steers away from what
we've seen in other episodes.

95
00:05:31.778 --> 00:05:33.329
>> And this one very much does.

96
00:05:33.329 --> 00:05:36.146
This one works a little
more like a heading.

97
00:05:36.146 --> 00:05:40.050
Where I put it at the beginning of
a line and it affects the whole line.

98
00:05:40.050 --> 00:05:44.954
That has to do with a little bit behind
the scenes bolding, italicising,

99
00:05:44.954 --> 00:05:48.130
those, those are kind of
like an in line thing.

100
00:05:48.130 --> 00:05:52.619
So I have to close them off because
everything else kind of bundles up.

101
00:05:52.619 --> 00:05:57.419
Notice this block quote,
well these are all on one line,

102
00:05:57.419 --> 00:05:59.822
this affects this one area.

103
00:05:59.822 --> 00:06:03.311
The reason that doesn't have to
be closed is the assumption is,

104
00:06:03.311 --> 00:06:07.138
everything you type on this line is
going to be part of the block quote.

105
00:06:07.138 --> 00:06:13.742
If I wanted to Interestingly enough,
say really really is and make that.

106
00:06:13.742 --> 00:06:17.782
Let's see if some of our other
styling works internally.

107
00:06:17.782 --> 00:06:20.039
Notice I can kind of mix those together.

108
00:06:20.039 --> 00:06:24.196
Markdown is awesome,
it really really is, right?

109
00:06:24.196 --> 00:06:27.152
That bolding still works in
the context of the block quote.

110
00:06:27.152 --> 00:06:30.842
But for comparison as Wes said,
I have an open and

111
00:06:30.842 --> 00:06:34.536
a closed cuz I only want
this portion of the line.

112
00:06:34.536 --> 00:06:38.258
A small subsection of the line,
to be bolded but

113
00:06:38.258 --> 00:06:42.085
the entire line is still
part of the block quote.

114
00:06:42.085 --> 00:06:45.016
So just like headings,
it affects the whole line.

115
00:06:45.016 --> 00:06:49.840
Whereas italicizing and boldings are
subsections of respective pieces of text.

116
00:06:51.070 --> 00:06:54.833
So if I come here and I'm like, you know,
well that makes a block quote but

117
00:06:54.833 --> 00:06:57.589
what if I actually just want
the greater than symbol?

118
00:06:57.589 --> 00:07:00.604
Let's say I'm writing some
kind of math equation.

119
00:07:00.604 --> 00:07:04.813
And you might be writing
a technical document.

120
00:07:04.813 --> 00:07:10.499
And you say, well,
five is greater than four.

121
00:07:10.499 --> 00:07:13.729
Notice it's not at
the beginning of the line.

122
00:07:13.729 --> 00:07:15.025
That's all good.

123
00:07:15.025 --> 00:07:17.365
It doesn't need an escape.

124
00:07:17.365 --> 00:07:22.761
What happens if, well, you're just
trying to say greater than four.

125
00:07:22.761 --> 00:07:26.958
And just put that there,
this becomes a block quote and

126
00:07:26.958 --> 00:07:29.155
it renders as a block quote.

127
00:07:29.155 --> 00:07:34.694
We've seen before in a couple episodes
that we have the ability to escape right?

128
00:07:34.694 --> 00:07:39.060
What if I escape this with a backslash,
backslash?

129
00:07:39.060 --> 00:07:42.855
Pretty sure it's a backslash,
we'll consult on that later.

130
00:07:42.855 --> 00:07:47.710
But this slash, notice it changes
the color of this greater than symbol.

131
00:07:47.710 --> 00:07:51.739
The greater than symbol is rendered, it
does not render as a block quote anymore.

132
00:07:51.739 --> 00:07:55.346
So if you need, for some reason,
for a greater than symbol to be

133
00:07:55.346 --> 00:07:59.654
at the very beginning of the line,
you can still add the escape character.

134
00:07:59.654 --> 00:08:02.797
Make sure it renders and
does not apply the styles.

135
00:08:02.797 --> 00:08:06.029
So these are handy if you
want to draw attention, but

136
00:08:06.029 --> 00:08:11.332
not necessarily use headings, or headers
to really blow things up, make them bold.

137
00:08:11.332 --> 00:08:15.218
Maybe you don't even need bolding or
italicizing, you want to set them aside,

138
00:08:15.218 --> 00:08:19.470
add a little bit of style so people read
them but it's still like standard text.

139
00:08:19.470 --> 00:08:23.870
So those are pretty easy, be very
careful if you need a greater than sign

140
00:08:23.870 --> 00:08:27.930
at the beginning of the line, well you
just need to make sure you escape it.

141
00:08:27.930 --> 00:08:31.680
Cuz otherwise it accidentally becomes
a block quote with a number four in it.

142
00:08:31.680 --> 00:08:34.903
And that's all there really
is to block quoting.

143
00:08:34.903 --> 00:08:38.390
>> A lot of great information as we
continue on here in our GitHub flavored

144
00:08:38.390 --> 00:08:38.991
markdown.

145
00:08:38.991 --> 00:08:40.097
And Justin has been so

146
00:08:40.097 --> 00:08:43.613
kind to show us how we can do a little
bit of manipulation of our text.

147
00:08:43.613 --> 00:08:44.609
And I can tell you,

148
00:08:44.609 --> 00:08:48.596
I wish I was actually following some of
the advice, some of my markdown files

149
00:08:48.596 --> 00:08:52.736
would look like roadmaps to a downtown
major metropolitan area city, right?

150
00:08:52.736 --> 00:08:56.051
So Justin, as always, we appreciate
having you here and we appreciate you,

151
00:08:56.051 --> 00:08:57.026
the viewer watching.

152
00:08:57.026 --> 00:08:59.804
Signing out for DevProTV,
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

153
00:08:59.804 --> 00:09:00.488
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

154
00:09:00.488 --> 00:09:02.231
>> And we'll see you next time.

155
00:09:02.231 --> 00:09:07.748
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes explore how to add an underline to a heading in a file.
episodes.title: Creating a Heading with Underline
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.183 --> 00:00:10.183
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.965 --> 00:00:14.000
Hello everybody out there.

3
00:00:14.000 --> 00:00:17.380
Thanks for joining us here at DEVPRO.TV
where, well, the fun never stops.

4
00:00:17.380 --> 00:00:20.630
I'm your show host Wes Bryan, and in
today's episode we're coming back at you

5
00:00:20.630 --> 00:00:22.700
with more of that
GitHub Flavored Markdown.

6
00:00:22.700 --> 00:00:25.530
And joining us back in the studios is Mr.
Justin Dennison.

7
00:00:25.530 --> 00:00:26.640
Justin, how are we doing today, sir?

8
00:00:26.640 --> 00:00:28.100
>> I am doing fantastic, Wes, and

9
00:00:28.100 --> 00:00:30.730
we are continuing on with
GitHub-flavored markdown.

10
00:00:32.010 --> 00:00:35.540
It's going to be an interesting episode,
because well, you're like,

11
00:00:35.540 --> 00:00:37.480
we've already talked about headings.

12
00:00:37.480 --> 00:00:39.530
I wanted to keep this
one as a separate one,

13
00:00:39.530 --> 00:00:43.210
because well, there are other ways
to make headings in markdown, and

14
00:00:43.210 --> 00:00:45.700
particularly this works in
GitHub-flavored markdown.

15
00:00:45.700 --> 00:00:48.360
Can sometimes throw people for
a loop, right?

16
00:00:48.360 --> 00:00:51.510
So sometimes a heading has an underline,
right?

17
00:00:51.510 --> 00:00:55.150
I have this big old heading, or
header depending on your vernacular.

18
00:00:55.150 --> 00:00:59.220
And I'm sure there's a strict technical
differentiation between those just in

19
00:00:59.220 --> 00:01:00.570
case you're wondering.

20
00:01:00.570 --> 00:01:05.510
And then there's this subtle horizontal
line to break up the section,

21
00:01:05.510 --> 00:01:09.110
hey, you should keep this in your focus.

22
00:01:09.110 --> 00:01:13.000
And there is actually two ways
to accomplish similar things.

23
00:01:13.000 --> 00:01:16.850
And I've seen some people
who adopt one way and

24
00:01:16.850 --> 00:01:20.080
didn't even know about the second way,
or vice versa.

25
00:01:20.080 --> 00:01:23.440
So we want to explore those a little
more in depth in this episode.

26
00:01:23.440 --> 00:01:28.000
And well, interestingly enough, we learn
how to make horizontal rules to break

27
00:01:28.000 --> 00:01:32.300
up additional sections that do not
require us to have headings at all.

28
00:01:32.300 --> 00:01:37.810
So that's kinda handy, but let's go and
come into the screen here and get started.

29
00:01:37.810 --> 00:01:40.346
So I'm gonna make new a markdown file,
it's kinda par for

30
00:01:40.346 --> 00:01:42.092
the course at this time, right?

31
00:01:42.092 --> 00:01:49.760
Headings, headings-with-underlines,
I can't spell underlines.

32
00:01:49.760 --> 00:01:53.932
There we go, underlines, so
I'm just gonna flip that array.

33
00:01:53.932 --> 00:01:57.390
And well, let's just say
this is something important.

34
00:01:58.530 --> 00:02:01.990
And you're like, something important,
I really want that to stand out.

35
00:02:01.990 --> 00:02:08.180
I want that to have real big text,
right, top level heading.

36
00:02:08.180 --> 00:02:11.950
And I want it to be underlined so that
everything under it is kind of like, hey,

37
00:02:11.950 --> 00:02:14.310
this follows this section.

38
00:02:14.310 --> 00:02:17.547
Underlining, now you'll see
what I mean by underlining.

39
00:02:20.130 --> 00:02:22.930
Titling is hard, full disclosure.

40
00:02:22.930 --> 00:02:29.430
So if I come here and I put three dashes,
notice how those turn blue.

41
00:02:29.430 --> 00:02:35.244
And I open this up and I open the preview
and it's kind of hard to see.

42
00:02:35.244 --> 00:02:40.912
This actually makes an H1, so
this is an alternative one.

43
00:02:40.912 --> 00:02:46.280
Notice there's nothing that looks
like there's an underline there.

44
00:02:46.280 --> 00:02:52.280
So I come back over here and
I instead change these two equal signs.

45
00:02:52.280 --> 00:02:57.130
You'll notice that puts this kind
of underline to the heading.

46
00:02:57.130 --> 00:03:01.040
I'm not talking about
underlining the text per se, but

47
00:03:01.040 --> 00:03:04.860
it underlines the heading and
it kinda spans the entire document.

48
00:03:06.960 --> 00:03:09.340
One more time,
I just wanna make sure everything's good.

49
00:03:09.340 --> 00:03:11.880
Single dashes, three of them.

50
00:03:11.880 --> 00:03:16.350
They'll turn blue if you have an editor
that recognizes markdown syntax.

51
00:03:16.350 --> 00:03:22.010
That makes this, well let's just
compare Something Important.

52
00:03:22.010 --> 00:03:26.510
It doesn't quite make it in H1, but
it is kind of a top-level heading.

53
00:03:26.510 --> 00:03:29.770
Let's see what it actually provides us.

54
00:03:29.770 --> 00:03:33.410
A little bit different,
not quite an H1, not quite an H2, so

55
00:03:33.410 --> 00:03:37.460
it's a tiny bit different but
it is still a heading.

56
00:03:38.640 --> 00:03:43.070
But if I change these to equal signs well,
what is that?

57
00:03:43.070 --> 00:03:44.970
Notice that text gets
a little bit bigger and

58
00:03:44.970 --> 00:03:47.730
there's that horizontal
rule that comes across.

59
00:03:47.730 --> 00:03:53.800
So if we go something important,
like so, important.

60
00:03:54.810 --> 00:03:59.120
Now we can actually see,
well, # Something Important.

61
00:03:59.120 --> 00:04:03.870
These are the same size, you can kinda
see, I get that underline as well.

62
00:04:03.870 --> 00:04:07.858
Do want to clarify, my editor is
showing an underline in both of these.

63
00:04:07.858 --> 00:04:12.120
By and large, this syntax

64
00:04:12.120 --> 00:04:15.640
does not guarantee an underline
depending on the rendering agent.

65
00:04:15.640 --> 00:04:19.110
That has been my experience at
the time of this recording.

66
00:04:19.110 --> 00:04:23.690
Knowing my luck this will come out, you're
watching now and you go check it out and

67
00:04:23.690 --> 00:04:25.410
all of these have underlines.

68
00:04:25.410 --> 00:04:28.830
But when I do this on GitHub or
on Bitbucket,

69
00:04:28.830 --> 00:04:33.550
a single hashtag heading does not
necessarily mean it has an underline.

70
00:04:33.550 --> 00:04:38.170
If I do three equal signs but
I do have an underline.

71
00:04:38.170 --> 00:04:43.960
So we're good to go there, and
well that's all fine and good.

72
00:04:43.960 --> 00:04:47.500
But it doesn't look like I
have the ability to decide,

73
00:04:47.500 --> 00:04:48.590
well I do want an underline.

74
00:04:48.590 --> 00:04:50.639
But I don't want quite that large a text.

75
00:04:52.870 --> 00:04:58.090
So if I come back and I make these single,
you're like, well that's still a heading.

76
00:04:58.090 --> 00:04:59.600
This is what trips people up.

77
00:05:01.310 --> 00:05:05.160
On the very next line if I
come right after this text.

78
00:05:05.160 --> 00:05:09.990
And I put these three equal signs,
it turns blue, and that means something.

79
00:05:09.990 --> 00:05:12.690
And that says,
create a heading with an underline.

80
00:05:12.690 --> 00:05:17.550
And in particular, in this case,
the equals signs mean, create an h1 style,

81
00:05:17.550 --> 00:05:20.680
right, a level one heading.

82
00:05:20.680 --> 00:05:26.180
But if I hit Enter, that's no longer
the case, it's just three equals signs.

83
00:05:26.180 --> 00:05:30.080
So the placement of those
are definitely important.

84
00:05:30.080 --> 00:05:33.380
The very next line, it means the top
level heading with an underline.

85
00:05:34.430 --> 00:05:36.702
If I have a space between,
it's just three equal signs.

86
00:05:36.702 --> 00:05:44.440
And to further throw a wrench into things,
three dashes, not equal signs.

87
00:05:44.440 --> 00:05:47.310
And again, this is depending on
the renderer actually means,

88
00:05:47.310 --> 00:05:51.020
create a horizontal rule that
is not attached to a heading.

89
00:05:51.020 --> 00:05:56.560
So what that means is I can come here and
say ###.

90
00:05:56.560 --> 00:05:59.850
And I have a little bit smaller text,
a different level heading, but

91
00:05:59.850 --> 00:06:01.710
I still have the horizontal rule.

92
00:06:01.710 --> 00:06:04.040
The styling is a little bit
different because, well,

93
00:06:04.040 --> 00:06:07.860
I'm now creating the underline
separate from the heading.

94
00:06:07.860 --> 00:06:11.840
But I do have the ability
to pick my heading size and

95
00:06:12.840 --> 00:06:14.690
just to show you, there it is.

96
00:06:14.690 --> 00:06:19.220
So if we come over here and
we remove one of these, not there,

97
00:06:20.640 --> 00:06:24.360
and now if we just have two of those,
it's just two so I need the three.

98
00:06:24.360 --> 00:06:27.880
It can't be on the very next line
because that creates a heading.

99
00:06:27.880 --> 00:06:33.120
Instead if I just want a horizontal
rule or a line across the page.

100
00:06:33.120 --> 00:06:38.320
It's three dashes, not equal signs,
and they should be outside,

101
00:06:38.320 --> 00:06:42.870
kind of separated from
respective areas of text.

102
00:06:42.870 --> 00:06:44.540
That allows me to make decisions here.

103
00:06:45.630 --> 00:06:51.140
If I come back and
I view something like this, right?

104
00:06:51.140 --> 00:06:54.140
And you'll notice the styling's
a little bit different,

105
00:06:54.140 --> 00:06:56.780
that has to do with
necessarily my text editor.

106
00:06:56.780 --> 00:07:00.810
The rendering styles may be,
depending on where you're hosting this, or

107
00:07:00.810 --> 00:07:03.070
where it's being rendered to can change.

108
00:07:03.070 --> 00:07:06.220
This underlining is a little bit thinner
than this one because it's associated with

109
00:07:06.220 --> 00:07:07.250
this header.

110
00:07:07.250 --> 00:07:09.730
Because of these three equals signs here,
okay.

111
00:07:09.730 --> 00:07:13.930
Notice my editor didn't turn blue because,
well, it's helping me out and

112
00:07:13.930 --> 00:07:15.920
I had an extra space there.

113
00:07:15.920 --> 00:07:18.630
I come back over here,
H1 followed by a line,

114
00:07:18.630 --> 00:07:23.590
and then a little thicker line
which is the horizontal rule.

115
00:07:23.590 --> 00:07:29.532
If instead I go okay, well I still
want lines but I want a subheading

116
00:07:29.532 --> 00:07:35.370
like this Subheading, and I want 3.

117
00:07:35.370 --> 00:07:40.920
Notice I have Something Important,
thin line,

118
00:07:40.920 --> 00:07:44.370
Subheading, because I use
the standard heading syntax and

119
00:07:44.370 --> 00:07:48.000
then I created my
horizontal line separately.

120
00:07:48.000 --> 00:07:50.280
Not necessarily in a combined syntax.

121
00:07:50.280 --> 00:07:54.600
And really where it throws people off
is I've seen people use just this for

122
00:07:54.600 --> 00:07:58.730
headings, and
didn't necessarily use any of these.

123
00:07:58.730 --> 00:08:02.270
But when they use these, they're
like well, I'm missing my underline.

124
00:08:02.270 --> 00:08:06.912
Well you got to learn that it's
three minus signs, right, or dashes.

125
00:08:08.150 --> 00:08:12.910
And then they're like that's kind
of like this, except not really.

126
00:08:15.730 --> 00:08:18.030
By itself it just creates
a horizontal rule.

127
00:08:18.030 --> 00:08:22.110
So something to keep in mind when I need
headings with respective lines across

128
00:08:22.110 --> 00:08:22.860
the page.

129
00:08:22.860 --> 00:08:28.350
They can be together or separate depending
on which of the syntaxes that you choose.

130
00:08:28.350 --> 00:08:32.960
So hopefully, that gives you an idea
of how to separate your sections

131
00:08:32.960 --> 00:08:38.270
with headings and corresponding
horizontal rules if you so need them.

132
00:08:38.270 --> 00:08:41.340
>> Just another piece of that puzzle
when it comes to manipulation and

133
00:08:41.340 --> 00:08:44.880
changing around your
markdown documents there.

134
00:08:44.880 --> 00:08:48.080
So Justin, as always, we do appreciate
having you in the studio with us, and

135
00:08:48.080 --> 00:08:49.930
appreciate you the viewer watching.

136
00:08:49.930 --> 00:08:52.850
We're gonna go ahead and
take the time to sign out for DevProTV.

137
00:08:52.850 --> 00:08:54.220
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

138
00:08:54.220 --> 00:08:54.865
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

139
00:08:54.865 --> 00:08:56.772
>> And we'll see you next time.

140
00:08:56.772 --> 00:09:00.973
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Wes demonstrate creating a link to another document contained in the project.
episodes.title: Adding an Internal Link
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.673 --> 00:00:14.686
Hello and welcome back to DevPro.TV.

3
00:00:14.686 --> 00:00:16.288
I'm your show host Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.288 --> 00:00:16.861
In today's episode we are continuing
through our series in

5
00:00:16.861 --> 00:00:20.039
the Github Flavored Markdown.
And joining us back in the studios is Mr.

6
00:00:20.039 --> 00:00:21.396
Justin Dennison.

7
00:00:21.396 --> 00:00:25.603
Justin, how we doing today sir?
>> Well I am doing fantastic and

8
00:00:25.603 --> 00:00:27.268
hopefully you are doing well as well.

9
00:00:27.268 --> 00:00:29.186
Wow that was a lot of wells there.

10
00:00:29.186 --> 00:00:31.168
That was from the department
of redundancy department.

11
00:00:31.168 --> 00:00:34.349
And yeah we're continuing on
with Github Flavored Markdown.

12
00:00:34.349 --> 00:00:36.939
In particular we're gonna be
talking about internal links.

13
00:00:36.939 --> 00:00:40.680
And you're like internal links,
what are you talking about?

14
00:00:40.680 --> 00:00:44.022
Well we've actually seen external
links and then we kinda took a detour.

15
00:00:44.022 --> 00:00:48.762
We talked about headings and block
quotes and stuff, but there are times,

16
00:00:48.762 --> 00:00:50.200
let's set the scene.

17
00:00:50.200 --> 00:00:54.936
Let me paint you a picture of why you
should even care about internal links.

18
00:00:54.936 --> 00:01:00.530
So internal links allow you to link
within the document that you're in.

19
00:01:00.530 --> 00:01:04.023
Let's say you have a very long markdown
document that you're like wow,

20
00:01:04.023 --> 00:01:06.840
I've got this table of contents and
I just start writing.

21
00:01:06.840 --> 00:01:09.681
I've done this before because I
don't want to have to go ahead and

22
00:01:09.681 --> 00:01:12.900
split things up into individual
documents and kind of sift through them.

23
00:01:12.900 --> 00:01:15.370
I'll just start writing
from top to bottom, right?

24
00:01:15.370 --> 00:01:17.580
It's good for stream of consciousness.

25
00:01:17.580 --> 00:01:18.854
You start to clean it up a little bit.

26
00:01:18.854 --> 00:01:22.943
It's nice to have that one document
that can be changed into a PDF,

27
00:01:22.943 --> 00:01:26.240
that can be changed into
maybe other formats, HTML.

28
00:01:26.240 --> 00:01:30.797
And if it's all on a single document, you
just have to worry about maintaining that

29
00:01:30.797 --> 00:01:34.719
document either in Dropbox or
something like that, or well, GitHub.

30
00:01:34.719 --> 00:01:38.957
So having those documents, when they
really get long, you're like woah man,

31
00:01:38.957 --> 00:01:42.050
there's a section way
down there on the bottom.

32
00:01:42.050 --> 00:01:42.909
How do I get to those?

33
00:01:42.909 --> 00:01:45.988
Well, internal links allow us to do that.
>> I was gonna say,

34
00:01:45.988 --> 00:01:49.013
you might be helping save my thumb
from a little bit of arthritis, right?

35
00:01:49.013 --> 00:01:51.903
I'm sitting there thinking,
continue scroll, scroll, scroll, scroll,

36
00:01:51.903 --> 00:01:52.655
scroll, scroll.

37
00:01:52.655 --> 00:01:55.750
Boy it would be really nice to
have a way that, like you said,

38
00:01:55.750 --> 00:01:59.260
if you had some text, a paragraph of text.

39
00:01:59.260 --> 00:02:03.393
Couldn't I just jump right to that section
without having to scroll through five

40
00:02:03.393 --> 00:02:05.032
continuous pages of text?
>> And

41
00:02:05.032 --> 00:02:07.740
that is ultimately what we're gonna do.

42
00:02:07.740 --> 00:02:10.960
I'm gonna give you a nice
little starter here.

43
00:02:10.960 --> 00:02:13.700
Internal linking can get really crazy.

44
00:02:13.700 --> 00:02:17.507
So we're gonna take what we know from
external linking, try to apply it, and

45
00:02:17.507 --> 00:02:18.747
see where things break.

46
00:02:18.747 --> 00:02:20.204
Because I will forewarn you,

47
00:02:20.204 --> 00:02:23.320
there are times where it
doesn't behave quite the same.

48
00:02:23.320 --> 00:02:24.810
So do keep that in mind.

49
00:02:24.810 --> 00:02:26.966
But we’ve done enough talking,
I think it’s important to,

50
00:02:26.966 --> 00:02:28.301
well, maybe just create a document.

51
00:02:28.301 --> 00:02:32.568
So go ahead and
come to the computer screen here and

52
00:02:32.568 --> 00:02:38.480
et’s create a new file called,
internal-links.md, all right?

53
00:02:38.480 --> 00:02:43.409
So let's say that I have a section
here called Table of Contents.

54
00:02:43.409 --> 00:02:47.810
This is somewhere in a document and
there we go.

55
00:02:47.810 --> 00:02:50.895
So I have this heading, right, this H3.

56
00:02:50.895 --> 00:02:55.600
And here I'm gonna say I have Chapter 1.

57
00:02:56.820 --> 00:03:01.611
Chapter 1, Chapter 2, and Chapter 3.

58
00:03:01.611 --> 00:03:06.110
And then I continue
writing in the document.

59
00:03:06.110 --> 00:03:08.970
I have a little horizontal
line that says hey,

60
00:03:08.970 --> 00:03:11.520
this is the remaining of the document.

61
00:03:11.520 --> 00:03:16.210
And I go here is Chapter 1 and
then there is some text.

62
00:03:16.210 --> 00:03:20.771
Let's just use the word text,
and then copy and

63
00:03:20.771 --> 00:03:27.863
paste that several times, and then
copy and paste that a few other times.

64
00:03:27.863 --> 00:03:32.400
So boom, boom, boom, boom, boom, boom and
then now we're finished with chapter 1 and

65
00:03:32.400 --> 00:03:33.130
it's great.

66
00:03:34.540 --> 00:03:35.580
It's the best chapter I've ever written.

67
00:03:35.580 --> 00:03:39.262
I tell you what, I'm thinking about
just going ahead and packing this up,

68
00:03:39.262 --> 00:03:42.480
getting out of here,
selling this on the Internet.

69
00:03:42.480 --> 00:03:43.249
I jest, I jest.

70
00:03:43.249 --> 00:03:47.842
So I'm here and
I get to Chapter 2 and well,

71
00:03:47.842 --> 00:03:53.590
I have some more text here and
I'm writing Chapter 2.

72
00:03:53.590 --> 00:03:57.300
And Chapter 2 is a little bit longer and
we're down here.

73
00:03:57.300 --> 00:04:00.140
And notice Chapter 1 and
Chapter 2 have already run off the page.

74
00:04:00.140 --> 00:04:04.815
All right, this is a very small example
and to some extent, a very fake example.

75
00:04:04.815 --> 00:04:08.570
But I have seen incredibly long and
markdown document, right?

76
00:04:08.570 --> 00:04:16.110
So I'm now working on Chapter 3 and I
need to make that a heading, there we go.

77
00:04:16.110 --> 00:04:21.489
And I'm just pasting, pasting, pasting,
pasting, pasting, pasting and there we go.

78
00:04:21.489 --> 00:04:25.590
Okay, so I have Chapter 1, 2,
and 3, let's look at the preview.

79
00:04:25.590 --> 00:04:26.670
There's our preview.

80
00:04:26.670 --> 00:04:28.470
It's all good to go.

81
00:04:28.470 --> 00:04:30.983
Here's Chapter 1, 2, and 3, and
let me break these up just so

82
00:04:30.983 --> 00:04:32.145
they're on separate lines.

83
00:04:32.145 --> 00:04:33.580
So there's our Table of Contents.

84
00:04:33.580 --> 00:04:38.560
Now, not the most beautiful Table of
Contents, but it does work, right?

85
00:04:39.600 --> 00:04:41.622
And if we wanted to
create an external link,

86
00:04:41.622 --> 00:04:44.260
if these were in a different
document hosted somewhere.

87
00:04:44.260 --> 00:04:50.535
We could put square brackets
around these put parenthesis and

88
00:04:50.535 --> 00:04:54.291
put www.google.com, like that.

89
00:04:54.291 --> 00:04:58.277
And that is now a link to Google, right?

90
00:04:58.277 --> 00:05:03.809
And for further clarity,
we should probably put that https.

91
00:05:03.809 --> 00:05:07.200
So if we go there, it would actually take
me to Google from within this document.

92
00:05:08.570 --> 00:05:10.990
However, that's not what I want to do.

93
00:05:10.990 --> 00:05:13.745
I want to instead link to
the respective chapters,

94
00:05:13.745 --> 00:05:17.727
because if I'm looking at a table of
contents in a standard book, right?

95
00:05:17.727 --> 00:05:21.610
I look at the table of contents, that's
the chapter, I go flip to that page.

96
00:05:21.610 --> 00:05:22.139
I don't have any page numbers.

97
00:05:22.139 --> 00:05:25.339
I don't have any means of referencing.

98
00:05:25.339 --> 00:05:28.666
But here, when I make this H1, right?

99
00:05:28.666 --> 00:05:30.480
Or excuse me, H3.

100
00:05:30.480 --> 00:05:34.158
Behind the scenes,
this is where the trick comes in.

101
00:05:34.158 --> 00:05:38.250
Behind the scenes this becomes
an HTML element with a particular ID.

102
00:05:38.250 --> 00:05:42.928
The ID takes this text and
says lower case and

103
00:05:42.928 --> 00:05:46.730
put hyphens for the spaces, okay?

104
00:05:46.730 --> 00:05:51.620
So if I come here and I say,
hashtag, octothorp, pound sign,

105
00:05:51.620 --> 00:05:56.160
whatever it may be, that says look for
the ID on this page.

106
00:05:57.680 --> 00:06:00.856
chapter 1, notice lowercase letter, -1.

107
00:06:00.856 --> 00:06:06.155
All right, so it looks good and then boom!

108
00:06:06.155 --> 00:06:09.970
I can now click and
it will jump to that part of the document.

109
00:06:09.970 --> 00:06:13.799
Likewise I can do the exact same thing for
Chapter 2.

110
00:06:13.799 --> 00:06:18.422
So #chapter 2, just like so.

111
00:06:18.422 --> 00:06:24.525
And well just to fill it out, #chapter-3.

112
00:06:24.525 --> 00:06:26.296
So now I have links and

113
00:06:26.296 --> 00:06:31.224
I could have additional things
here like the actual title.

114
00:06:31.224 --> 00:06:36.420
Title and stuff, things of that nature,
but now this is the link.

115
00:06:36.420 --> 00:06:37.032
So do keep that in mind.

116
00:06:37.032 --> 00:06:42.737
We're not limited to making the entire
thing a link to somewhere else.

117
00:06:42.737 --> 00:06:46.138
But because I have those,
I can going to Chapter 1.

118
00:06:46.138 --> 00:06:46.963
I can go to Chapter 2.

119
00:06:46.963 --> 00:06:48.827
I can go to Chapter 3.

120
00:06:48.827 --> 00:06:53.049
And what's interesting about this
is if I need a way of navigating,

121
00:06:53.049 --> 00:06:58.010
I have a Table of Contents section at the
end of Chapter 1 or even below this, but

122
00:06:58.010 --> 00:06:59.510
I'll put it at the end.

123
00:06:59.510 --> 00:07:08.634
I can say [Return to
TOC](#table-of-contents),

124
00:07:08.634 --> 00:07:12.735
like that and there we go.

125
00:07:12.735 --> 00:07:15.136
So Return to TOC, boom.

126
00:07:15.136 --> 00:07:16.125
And now it makes me jump.

127
00:07:16.125 --> 00:07:19.250
So I can internally link
within the document.

128
00:07:20.260 --> 00:07:23.020
Now I'm keeping this
fairly kind of general,

129
00:07:23.020 --> 00:07:27.640
because we're just making use of some
behind the scenes render technology.

130
00:07:27.640 --> 00:07:32.730
I don't wanna get too very deep
because this is supposed to be easy.

131
00:07:32.730 --> 00:07:33.442
So this is all we need to know.

132
00:07:33.442 --> 00:07:37.241
If you really wanna dig deep,
get this rendered out into HTML,

133
00:07:37.241 --> 00:07:38.680
see how that plays out.

134
00:07:38.680 --> 00:07:42.963
And then if you know a little bit of HTML,
you can further refine this.

135
00:07:42.963 --> 00:07:48.559
Interestingly enough though,
if I come here and I'm like well,

136
00:07:48.559 --> 00:07:53.270
I know in external links I
can do named links, right?

137
00:07:53.270 --> 00:07:57.410
Let's say I want to link to chapter,
let's say this refers to Chapter 1.

138
00:07:57.410 --> 00:08:03.280
And I come down here and
I say, Chapter 1, like that.

139
00:08:03.280 --> 00:08:05.750
And you're like, well,
that doesn't make a link.

140
00:08:05.750 --> 00:08:10.290
And to provide some context, during
Chapter 2, I'm reading, I'm reading.

141
00:08:10.290 --> 00:08:13.083
And there's something I've talked
about that said hey, you should go and

142
00:08:13.083 --> 00:08:13.846
look at Chapter 1.

143
00:08:13.846 --> 00:08:18.160
It's kind of annoying to say chapter-1,
like that.

144
00:08:18.160 --> 00:08:22.080
When in external links,
we could make named links.

145
00:08:22.080 --> 00:08:29.246
We could come into the bottom of
the document and go Chapter 1 and then :.

146
00:08:29.246 --> 00:08:34.570
And yeah colon, sometimes I
forget that colon, not gonna lie.

147
00:08:34.570 --> 00:08:37.870
And then there we go.

148
00:08:37.870 --> 00:08:40.920
What does it go to, #chapter-1.

149
00:08:40.920 --> 00:08:45.990
I come up here, remove this, okay?

150
00:08:45.990 --> 00:08:49.007
And you're like that looks handy.

151
00:08:49.007 --> 00:08:55.860
And you'll notice that doesn't work.

152
00:08:55.860 --> 00:08:59.096
This is where from external links,
and actually let's go and

153
00:08:59.096 --> 00:09:00.348
look at external link.

154
00:09:00.348 --> 00:09:03.062
I'm gonna open that document,
close this one.

155
00:09:03.062 --> 00:09:07.623
This is from a previous
episode Well you're like,

156
00:09:07.623 --> 00:09:10.210
well Justin you put parentheses here for
that name.

157
00:09:10.210 --> 00:09:15.080
I did, let's go see if that's where
I messed up, which is very possible.

158
00:09:15.080 --> 00:09:18.630
And you go okay, well okay I messed up.

159
00:09:18.630 --> 00:09:21.060
And that's where you
go it should work now.

160
00:09:21.060 --> 00:09:23.980
Let's see if it in fact does work.

161
00:09:23.980 --> 00:09:27.225
So what I mean is this is
now kind of this named link.

162
00:09:27.225 --> 00:09:29.830
I can use Chapter 1 anywhere,
including right here.

163
00:09:29.830 --> 00:09:31.690
Notice this is Chapter 1.

164
00:09:31.690 --> 00:09:34.380
Let's click and it still doesn't work.

165
00:09:34.380 --> 00:09:38.010
This is one of those weird
nuances about internal linking.

166
00:09:38.010 --> 00:09:44.030
The named link doesn't work too well with
the same syntax that external links do.

167
00:09:44.030 --> 00:09:47.050
I'm not saying that you can't
get it to work at all, but

168
00:09:47.050 --> 00:09:50.560
it doesn't follow the same
kind of thought process.

169
00:09:50.560 --> 00:09:57.416
So unfortunately, to make things easy,
I recommend being explicit.

170
00:09:57.416 --> 00:10:03.895
chapter-1, right, and I go grab this,
okay and delete that.

171
00:10:03.895 --> 00:10:05.417
I'm not gonna put named links.

172
00:10:05.417 --> 00:10:09.411
You kinda just have endline them and boom.

173
00:10:09.411 --> 00:10:14.860
And then if I scroll down that takes me
back to Chapter 1 to the top of the page.

174
00:10:14.860 --> 00:10:17.964
So from the internal linking's
perspective there is a little bit of

175
00:10:17.964 --> 00:10:19.767
a difference between external links.

176
00:10:19.767 --> 00:10:21.210
This is just to get us started.

177
00:10:21.210 --> 00:10:26.230
There is a lot more power here,
but it's nice to have just this

178
00:10:26.230 --> 00:10:33.393
basic internal document navigation that is
also based on these heading names, right?

179
00:10:33.393 --> 00:10:36.709
So I've shown you for headings because
that's probably the most prominent

180
00:10:36.709 --> 00:10:40.032
way you're going to navigate,
instead of I wanna go look at a sentence.

181
00:10:40.032 --> 00:10:44.070
I wanna go look at this section, which
is going to have a heading of some sort

182
00:10:44.070 --> 00:10:47.540
that gets this special
ID based on the text.

183
00:10:47.540 --> 00:10:50.667
There's a the semi-practical limitation,
but

184
00:10:50.667 --> 00:10:53.500
there's nothing special about Chapter 1.

185
00:10:53.500 --> 00:11:00.330
If I made this Chapter One and made this
chapter-one like so, then it still works.

186
00:11:00.330 --> 00:11:05.684
If I say Chapter One and
Some Stuff, like that.

187
00:11:05.684 --> 00:11:08.945
I know, super original,

188
00:11:08.945 --> 00:11:14.290
and-some-stuff, well it still works.

189
00:11:14.290 --> 00:11:16.146
So it just follows that convention.

190
00:11:16.146 --> 00:11:20.550
Do keep in mind if you get really long
ones, it may be hard to maintain.

191
00:11:20.550 --> 00:11:24.917
So as I've said before in many
of my shows, titling is hard,

192
00:11:24.917 --> 00:11:27.584
keep it concise, yet descriptive.

193
00:11:27.584 --> 00:11:30.069
If it's Chapter One, say Chapter One and

194
00:11:30.069 --> 00:11:34.910
then create a subheading that provides
additional descriptions if you need so.

195
00:11:34.910 --> 00:11:39.284
And that way you can link to Chapter One,
the respective section,

196
00:11:39.284 --> 00:11:42.893
without having to type
a horrible long internal link.

197
00:11:42.893 --> 00:11:44.960
Especially if you're gonna reuse them.

198
00:11:44.960 --> 00:11:49.221
Cuz at it stands, this one doesn't work
anymore because I would have to go change

199
00:11:49.221 --> 00:11:50.610
that one endline as well.

200
00:11:50.610 --> 00:11:55.147
So there are some edge cases but
incredibly handy for creating navigation

201
00:11:55.147 --> 00:11:58.764
internal to a document.
>> Words of wisdom when it comes to using

202
00:11:58.764 --> 00:11:59.966
your markdown documents.

203
00:11:59.966 --> 00:12:03.036
Now it does look like we're coming
to the end of another episode.

204
00:12:03.036 --> 00:12:06.270
But before we sign out, Justin,
do you have anything else that you would

205
00:12:06.270 --> 00:12:08.872
like to impart to our viewers?
>> I just wanna say we're using

206
00:12:08.872 --> 00:12:11.901
GitHub Flavored Markdown because some
of the things we'll see here and

207
00:12:11.901 --> 00:12:13.430
there are very specific to GitHub.

208
00:12:14.540 --> 00:12:18.670
A lot of the things that we see
are actually just marked down in general.

209
00:12:18.670 --> 00:12:23.357
Will work regardless of whether
it's GitHub Flavored Markdown or

210
00:12:23.357 --> 00:12:24.710
a MultiMarkdown.

211
00:12:24.710 --> 00:12:26.413
Pick your poison on that deal.

212
00:12:26.413 --> 00:12:27.520
In addition to,

213
00:12:27.520 --> 00:12:32.594
this is not meant to go to super deep
behind the scenes how everything works.

214
00:12:32.594 --> 00:12:37.195
This is to little practical snippets
to help you go how do I make

215
00:12:37.195 --> 00:12:39.198
links internal in a doc?

216
00:12:39.198 --> 00:12:41.835
There I go, that's all I need know, right?

217
00:12:41.835 --> 00:12:45.931
These are reference materials instead
of all the inner workings of markdown.

218
00:12:45.931 --> 00:12:47.720
So do remember that.

219
00:12:47.720 --> 00:12:50.743
Do a quick search, see what you
need to get done, and get it done.

220
00:12:50.743 --> 00:12:52.025
>> All right, thanks Justin for

221
00:12:52.025 --> 00:12:53.980
being here, we appreciate having you here.

222
00:12:53.980 --> 00:12:55.602
And we appreciate, you,
the viewer watching.

223
00:12:55.602 --> 00:12:57.384
We're gonna go ahead,
sign out for DevProTV.

224
00:12:57.384 --> 00:12:59.805
I've been your host Wes Bryan.
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

225
00:12:59.805 --> 00:13:00.830
>> We'll see you next time.

226
00:13:00.830 --> 00:13:08.084
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee demonstrate creating a lists in markdown.
episodes.title: Creating Lists
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.825 --> 00:00:16.120
Welcome, everyone, to your learn
GitHub-flavored markdown series.

3
00:00:16.120 --> 00:00:18.120
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

4
00:00:18.120 --> 00:00:21.452
In this episode, we'll be taking a look
at creating lists and of course,

5
00:00:21.452 --> 00:00:24.160
with us today in studio's,
we have Mr. Justin Dennison.

6
00:00:24.160 --> 00:00:26.640
How's it going today, Justin?
>> It is going fantastic, Cherokee.

7
00:00:26.640 --> 00:00:28.212
How are you today?
>> I'm doing well.

8
00:00:28.212 --> 00:00:31.936
I've actually been working in markdown,
but I've never tried to create a lists, so

9
00:00:31.936 --> 00:00:34.527
I think I'm looking forward to this show.
>> Well, hopefully,

10
00:00:34.527 --> 00:00:37.387
you'll learn a little bit of something and
maybe you'll learn something as well.

11
00:00:37.387 --> 00:00:39.260
So list, what do I mean by lists?

12
00:00:39.260 --> 00:00:42.260
Well you've probably created
a number of lists in word or

13
00:00:42.260 --> 00:00:44.050
some other text editor, right?

14
00:00:44.050 --> 00:00:46.810
Where you go, all I need one,
two, three, four.

15
00:00:46.810 --> 00:00:48.350
That's an ordered list.

16
00:00:48.350 --> 00:00:51.900
That's important because the one,
the two, the three and the four.

17
00:00:51.900 --> 00:00:55.853
Those are kind of like this is first,
this is next, this is next.

18
00:00:55.853 --> 00:00:56.684
And then there's other lists that
are just kinda bullet points, right?

19
00:00:56.684 --> 00:01:01.860
You have some kind of rounded
bullet point, typically.

20
00:01:01.860 --> 00:01:06.220
I've seen really extravagant bullet
points that are images and stuff.

21
00:01:06.220 --> 00:01:10.800
But bullet points means, I need to
consider all of these four things, or

22
00:01:10.800 --> 00:01:12.750
five things, or six things.

23
00:01:12.750 --> 00:01:16.237
But it doesn't really matter which order,
per se, right?

24
00:01:16.237 --> 00:01:19.650
They're just all collected, and
I wanna see top level outline.

25
00:01:19.650 --> 00:01:24.583
In addition to, if you're in Word or
things like Word, you hit tab,

26
00:01:24.583 --> 00:01:27.573
a lot of times you get a different bullet.

27
00:01:27.573 --> 00:01:28.240
>> Mm-hm.
>> Right?

28
00:01:28.240 --> 00:01:29.610
Like an indented bullet?

29
00:01:29.610 --> 00:01:32.300
And that's like,
this is a sublist of this list.

30
00:01:32.300 --> 00:01:33.501
>> Well something I have noticed

31
00:01:33.501 --> 00:01:34.081
in markdown.

32
00:01:34.081 --> 00:01:37.370
If I go for
some bullet of sorts like an asterisk,

33
00:01:37.370 --> 00:01:41.542
maybe if I use an asterisk somewhere
else in that line of text,

34
00:01:41.542 --> 00:01:45.897
it totally changes the formatting and
I'm like, what did I do?

35
00:01:45.897 --> 00:01:48.040
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, that'll get you.

36
00:01:48.040 --> 00:01:51.317
And when we create lists, we're gonna
have to be careful because some of

37
00:01:51.317 --> 00:01:54.770
the characters that we've seen on
previous episodes are actually reused.

38
00:01:54.770 --> 00:01:57.410
Well, we've talked a little bit,
and let's go ahead and

39
00:01:57.410 --> 00:01:59.340
see how do we create lists?
>> Perfect.

40
00:01:59.340 --> 00:02:00.020
>> So if we come down

41
00:02:00.020 --> 00:02:01.000
to the computer here.

42
00:02:01.000 --> 00:02:07.499
And I'm just gonna create a new document
called creating-lists, creating-lists.md.

43
00:02:07.499 --> 00:02:11.393
Again, remember, .md is gonna help
you with syntax highlighting,

44
00:02:11.393 --> 00:02:13.160
keep things clean.

45
00:02:13.160 --> 00:02:17.230
So if I want a groceries list,
you're like, here's the groceries list.

46
00:02:18.440 --> 00:02:19.999
That's all I want.

47
00:02:19.999 --> 00:02:24.795
I can hit a minus sign or a dash, hit
a space, and notice that it turns blue,

48
00:02:24.795 --> 00:02:26.395
just like that.

49
00:02:26.395 --> 00:02:27.885
Well what do I need from the grocery?

50
00:02:27.885 --> 00:02:29.995
I need cheese and milk.

51
00:02:29.995 --> 00:02:32.295
Apparently I have an infatuation
with dairy products.

52
00:02:32.295 --> 00:02:32.855
>> So Justin,

53
00:02:32.855 --> 00:02:36.535
are you the type of person who reorganizes
their list once it's written and

54
00:02:36.535 --> 00:02:38.235
the order of where it is in the store so

55
00:02:38.235 --> 00:02:40.865
you can just go and?
>> No, Cherokee,

56
00:02:40.865 --> 00:02:43.071
I don' t have that kind of time in my day.
>> [LAUGH]

57
00:02:43.071 --> 00:02:44.736
>> So I just made a list and

58
00:02:44.736 --> 00:02:49.230
then I played it out in my mind and
I just check it off.

59
00:02:49.230 --> 00:02:52.648
We gotta figure out how our schedules
work cuz I ain't got that kind of time.

60
00:02:52.648 --> 00:02:54.404
And let's have a little bit of [INAUDIBLE]
>> I don't get out

61
00:02:54.404 --> 00:02:55.070
much, Justin.
>> [LAUGH]

62
00:02:55.070 --> 00:02:57.232
>> [LAUGH]

63
00:02:57.232 --> 00:02:57.829
>> Apparently not,

64
00:02:57.829 --> 00:02:59.548
when you get that excited
about the grocery store.

65
00:02:59.548 --> 00:03:03.500
[LAUGH] So we have these dashes, right?

66
00:03:03.500 --> 00:03:04.480
They've turned blue.

67
00:03:04.480 --> 00:03:07.780
That's an indicator, hey,
this is probably some balanced syntax.

68
00:03:07.780 --> 00:03:14.670
If I open up my preview to the side, I now
have this kind of indented, bulleted list.

69
00:03:14.670 --> 00:03:15.870
It's a simple bulleted list.

70
00:03:15.870 --> 00:03:20.960
This is an unordered list, and
I can use minus signs to do that.

71
00:03:20.960 --> 00:03:24.090
The tricky part is the minus or

72
00:03:24.090 --> 00:03:29.160
the dash is not the only character that
allows me to make a list like this.

73
00:03:29.160 --> 00:03:32.700
If I come back and I put an asterisk, and

74
00:03:32.700 --> 00:03:37.950
I put an asterisk, notice these are single
asterisks at the beginning of the line.

75
00:03:37.950 --> 00:03:43.070
Asterisks can also mean bold or
italicized, depending on how you use them.

76
00:03:43.070 --> 00:03:44.965
I get the exact same bulleted list.

77
00:03:44.965 --> 00:03:46.457
[SOUND] Well,

78
00:03:46.457 --> 00:03:50.685
I'm about to get crazy up in here.
>> [LAUGH]

79
00:03:50.685 --> 00:03:53.045
>> Well, if I put a plus sign,

80
00:03:53.045 --> 00:03:56.140
I still get the same bulleted list.

81
00:03:56.140 --> 00:04:00.010
So I have three characters that
allow me to make a bullet list.

82
00:04:00.010 --> 00:04:01.730
An asterisk, a minus sign or

83
00:04:01.730 --> 00:04:05.760
dash, or plus sign given at
the very beginning of a line.

84
00:04:05.760 --> 00:04:08.350
It's not wrapped in any sorts.

85
00:04:08.350 --> 00:04:11.100
If it's not at the beginning of a line,
right,

86
00:04:11.100 --> 00:04:15.550
notice my tab,
I start getting a different bullet.

87
00:04:15.550 --> 00:04:16.658
Well why is that?

88
00:04:16.658 --> 00:04:23.037
If I do a space, space doesn't quite
work like you would expect it to.

89
00:04:23.037 --> 00:04:24.840
I can create sublists.

90
00:04:24.840 --> 00:04:27.387
Lets say that I need a variety of cheeses,
right?

91
00:04:27.387 --> 00:04:28.381
>> [LAUGH]

92
00:04:28.381 --> 00:04:30.912
>> Of course because that's exactly what

93
00:04:30.912 --> 00:04:33.950
we need.
>> I need gouda, and feta, and

94
00:04:33.950 --> 00:04:36.310
gorgonzola, I need all of them.
>> So

95
00:04:36.310 --> 00:04:40.550
if I need that but I wanna keep a sublist
because I wanna look at my list.

96
00:04:40.550 --> 00:04:41.857
Maybe I'm not rearranging it-
>> [LAUGH]

97
00:04:41.857 --> 00:04:43.627
>> To see how I walk through the store,

98
00:04:43.627 --> 00:04:47.830
but maybe I'm rearranging it so,
that's the cheese top-level topic.

99
00:04:47.830 --> 00:04:49.160
And then check, check, check, check.

100
00:04:49.160 --> 00:04:52.170
I can get all of my cheeses because I
know the cheeses are grouped together

101
00:04:52.170 --> 00:04:52.920
in the store.

102
00:04:52.920 --> 00:04:54.168
Regardless of where-
>> [LAUGH]

103
00:04:54.168 --> 00:04:54.916
>> They are in the store.

104
00:04:54.916 --> 00:04:56.720
So, I'm gonna hit tab.

105
00:04:56.720 --> 00:05:00.870
And then, my recommendation,
you can use another plus sign and

106
00:05:01.890 --> 00:05:06.480
say, let's say feta, and then another
plus sign, and say gorgonzola.

107
00:05:08.190 --> 00:05:10.458
And maybe I'm exposing too
much about myself here.

108
00:05:10.458 --> 00:05:11.283
>> [LAUGH]

109
00:05:11.283 --> 00:05:12.610
>> So, cheddar, right?

110
00:05:12.610 --> 00:05:14.830
And then a little bit of gouda.

111
00:05:14.830 --> 00:05:17.231
So notice I've used plus signs, but

112
00:05:17.231 --> 00:05:19.400
I get this indented list.
>> Right.

113
00:05:19.400 --> 00:05:21.790
>> I can continue to do that more or

114
00:05:21.790 --> 00:05:24.400
less as much as I want.

115
00:05:25.470 --> 00:05:32.335
However if I look at this, for me, I'm
like, I came back to this a week later.

116
00:05:32.335 --> 00:05:34.220
I'm finally gonna go to the grocery store.

117
00:05:34.220 --> 00:05:35.151
I'm like, well how did I do that?

118
00:05:35.151 --> 00:05:36.925
So I'm like, [SOUND].

119
00:05:36.925 --> 00:05:41.661
And then I messed up my list because I
haven't given myself a hint that this is

120
00:05:41.661 --> 00:05:43.210
a sublist, right?

121
00:05:43.210 --> 00:05:44.860
So I'm gonna tab that back over.

122
00:05:44.860 --> 00:05:50.341
And instead my recommendation is for
each level of indentation,

123
00:05:50.341 --> 00:05:55.134
you pick a new character to
start your list with, right?

124
00:05:55.134 --> 00:06:00.161
So if I have cheddar, and
cheddar has sharp and mild,

125
00:06:00.161 --> 00:06:06.970
and I want an additional sublist,
I might use mild and sharp as such.

126
00:06:06.970 --> 00:06:09.940
And then I get an additional
level of indentation.

127
00:06:09.940 --> 00:06:12.560
So I would pick a different character
because it gives you a nice hint that your

128
00:06:12.560 --> 00:06:17.520
intentions in the markdown file were
to have these as a nested lists.

129
00:06:17.520 --> 00:06:19.970
Now I made a list like
this with groceries.

130
00:06:19.970 --> 00:06:22.860
But this could easily be-
>> Like a word breakdown structure.

131
00:06:22.860 --> 00:06:25.290
But then again, that would be ordered.

132
00:06:25.290 --> 00:06:28.220
So I think I might need to hang around for
some more shows.

133
00:06:28.220 --> 00:06:31.340
>> Well let's go ahead and say it's very

134
00:06:31.340 --> 00:06:38.210
important that you organize your groceries
based on where they are in the store.

135
00:06:38.210 --> 00:06:40.608
And so you're gonna order them like one.

136
00:06:40.608 --> 00:06:42.460
That's the first thing I'm gonna come to.

137
00:06:42.460 --> 00:06:44.880
Two, that's the next
thing I wanna come to.

138
00:06:44.880 --> 00:06:47.730
So let me make a little
horizontal rule here.

139
00:06:47.730 --> 00:06:50.478
And then well what's gonna
happen first in the store,

140
00:06:50.478 --> 00:06:52.168
given my grocery store?
>> It's aisle one.

141
00:06:52.168 --> 00:06:53.987
>> Yeah, aisle one, right?

142
00:06:53.987 --> 00:06:54.630
>> [LAUGH]

143
00:06:54.630 --> 00:06:56.590
>> So let's say it is aisle one.

144
00:06:56.590 --> 00:06:58.940
So I have bread in aisle one.

145
00:06:58.940 --> 00:06:59.735
If you're like,

146
00:06:59.735 --> 00:07:01.431
bread is not an aisle one in my store.
>> [LAUGH]

147
00:07:01.431 --> 00:07:02.050
>> That's because all

148
00:07:02.050 --> 00:07:03.380
grocery stores are different.

149
00:07:03.380 --> 00:07:09.530
And then I say well, here's the dairy and
then, aisle three, canned goods.

150
00:07:11.410 --> 00:07:17.189
Notice, I get a one, two,
three list just by using one, two, three.

151
00:07:17.189 --> 00:07:19.220
That's all I have to do.

152
00:07:19.220 --> 00:07:20.343
Now I used a period here.

153
00:07:20.343 --> 00:07:21.630
What if I take this period away?

154
00:07:24.300 --> 00:07:26.150
It's not quite the same.

155
00:07:27.370 --> 00:07:29.190
What about other separation characters?

156
00:07:29.190 --> 00:07:34.365
What if I've seen people do this, right?

157
00:07:34.365 --> 00:07:36.105
Still not formatting.

158
00:07:36.105 --> 00:07:40.046
For an ordered list, that means
there is an intrinsic order to it.

159
00:07:40.046 --> 00:07:43.352
The expectation is,
at least at the beginning,

160
00:07:43.352 --> 00:07:47.725
there's always fancy tricks
that you can pull, number, dot.

161
00:07:47.725 --> 00:07:51.705
Now if you're in the bread aisle,
and you need hot dog buns,

162
00:07:51.705 --> 00:07:56.210
and hamburger buns, and
you need some honey wheat bread.

163
00:07:56.210 --> 00:07:58.849
But you're like, I don't really
know the order down the aisle.

164
00:07:58.849 --> 00:07:59.559
I just know the-
>> [LAUGH]

165
00:07:59.559 --> 00:08:00.940
>> Aisle order.

166
00:08:00.940 --> 00:08:03.502
So if I tab over-
>> Don't get silly now,

167
00:08:03.502 --> 00:08:04.417
Justin.
>> [LAUGH] No.

168
00:08:04.417 --> 00:08:05.022
>> [LAUGH]

169
00:08:05.022 --> 00:08:07.440
>> I know, me being silly.

170
00:08:07.440 --> 00:08:08.560
Who would have thought?

171
00:08:08.560 --> 00:08:13.650
So, I know that in the bread aisle,
I have those respective things, right?

172
00:08:13.650 --> 00:08:18.789
So, hamburger buns, hot dog buns and

173
00:08:18.789 --> 00:08:23.628
well, honey wheat bread.
>> [LAUGH]

174
00:08:23.628 --> 00:08:26.270
>> Honey wheat bread.

175
00:08:26.270 --> 00:08:30.480
I wanted to show you this, because I
don't know the order in that sublist,

176
00:08:30.480 --> 00:08:32.240
that's not necessarily as important.

177
00:08:33.590 --> 00:08:37.070
But I can still maintain
the order at the top level topic.

178
00:08:37.070 --> 00:08:38.900
And then have a sublist
that is unordered so

179
00:08:38.900 --> 00:08:41.910
I can mix these as well
based on indentation.

180
00:08:41.910 --> 00:08:44.530
Further indentation,
I would still apply the same rules

181
00:08:44.530 --> 00:08:48.640
to an unordered list where I go,
well I need to talk about hamburger buns,

182
00:08:48.640 --> 00:08:52.570
whether I want potato bread hamburger buns
or white or wheat, whatever it may be.

183
00:08:52.570 --> 00:08:56.000
I would change that character so
I could get further divisions, and

184
00:08:56.000 --> 00:09:01.200
give me a visual cue in my markdown
file before I accidentally unindent and

185
00:09:01.200 --> 00:09:02.130
just jack stuff up.

186
00:09:02.130 --> 00:09:05.760
So creating lists is pretty easy, but
there are a few conventions that I

187
00:09:05.760 --> 00:09:09.260
recommend that maybe you find something
that works a little better for you.

188
00:09:09.260 --> 00:09:13.108
Just remember, ordered lists,
well, they're numbered, all right?

189
00:09:13.108 --> 00:09:14.798
About one, two, three, period.

190
00:09:14.798 --> 00:09:18.840
And then unordered list can either
use a plus sign, an asterisk,

191
00:09:18.840 --> 00:09:23.923
or a dash minus sign at the beginning
of the bulleted point, okay?

192
00:09:23.923 --> 00:09:26.590
Indentation, switch around,

193
00:09:26.590 --> 00:09:28.880
and you'll be good to go.
>> Awesome Justin.

194
00:09:28.880 --> 00:09:29.660
That was so helpful.

195
00:09:29.660 --> 00:09:33.425
I think I just may create a list of
all the things I learned in this show.

196
00:09:33.425 --> 00:09:36.890
[LAUGH] Hopefully you guys have
learned something as well, but for

197
00:09:36.890 --> 00:09:38.120
now let's sign out.

198
00:09:38.120 --> 00:09:40.520
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

199
00:09:40.520 --> 00:09:42.971
>> See you next time here at DevPro.

200
00:09:42.971 --> 00:09:46.869
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee add an image to a markdown document.
episodes.title: Adding an Image
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:10.025
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.848 --> 00:00:15.950
>> Welcome everyone to your
Learn GitHub-Flavored Markdown series.

3
00:00:15.950 --> 00:00:17.770
I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

4
00:00:17.770 --> 00:00:21.840
In this episode, we'll be taking a look at
how we can add images into our documents,

5
00:00:21.840 --> 00:00:25.290
and of course with us today, we have Mr.
Justin Dennison back in studio's.

6
00:00:25.290 --> 00:00:26.220
How's it going, Justin?

7
00:00:26.220 --> 00:00:27.550
>> It is going fantastic, Cherokee.

8
00:00:27.550 --> 00:00:28.290
How are you today?

9
00:00:28.290 --> 00:00:29.860
>> I'm good.
I'm super excited about learning

10
00:00:29.860 --> 00:00:31.980
how to add an image,
because I do use markdown, but

11
00:00:31.980 --> 00:00:35.520
I've never had the urge,
I've never felt compelled to add an image.

12
00:00:35.520 --> 00:00:37.560
So today's my day.

13
00:00:37.560 --> 00:00:40.744
>> Well maybe today is your day,
or maybe it's not, right?

14
00:00:40.744 --> 00:00:42.854
>> [LAUGH]
>> There are times where you may want

15
00:00:42.854 --> 00:00:43.690
to add an image.

16
00:00:43.690 --> 00:00:45.801
If you're building an open source project,
or

17
00:00:45.801 --> 00:00:47.816
maybe you're building it as a book, right?

18
00:00:47.816 --> 00:00:52.488
You're writing your book in markdown,
you're gonna have it put into PDF or

19
00:00:52.488 --> 00:00:55.320
ePub or .moby, whatever it may be.

20
00:00:55.320 --> 00:00:57.060
You may have images, right?

21
00:00:57.060 --> 00:00:58.000
Maybe you have diagrams.

22
00:00:58.000 --> 00:01:02.820
If you're running a technical document,
you have screenshots or actual drawings,

23
00:01:02.820 --> 00:01:04.210
right, architectural drawings.

24
00:01:04.210 --> 00:01:07.670
Whatever it may be,
those are times where you may have images.

25
00:01:07.670 --> 00:01:10.930
Now, we do use markdown internally here.

26
00:01:10.930 --> 00:01:13.220
We typically don't have
a lot of images in ours.

27
00:01:13.220 --> 00:01:15.530
It's just a very much text and lists.

28
00:01:15.530 --> 00:01:18.230
But it's more for
us than it is anything else.

29
00:01:18.230 --> 00:01:20.170
So if you haven't used an image,

30
00:01:20.170 --> 00:01:23.160
there's nothing wrong with that but
maybe one day you're like man,

31
00:01:23.160 --> 00:01:28.460
it would be real awesome if I just had
a png of a logo right here at the top.

32
00:01:28.460 --> 00:01:32.370
Well, you can do that in markdown and
it's actually pretty easy.

33
00:01:32.370 --> 00:01:36.126
Full disclosure,
because we don't do it a whole, whole lot.

34
00:01:36.126 --> 00:01:38.251
I sometimes get things backwards and well,

35
00:01:38.251 --> 00:01:40.490
you may get to watch me
struggle a little bit.

36
00:01:40.490 --> 00:01:43.570
But in order to get the struggling
started, let's go ahead and

37
00:01:43.570 --> 00:01:46.160
come into the screen here and
get things set up.

38
00:01:46.160 --> 00:01:49.950
First off,
I've just grabbed our logo, right?

39
00:01:49.950 --> 00:01:55.230
This is DevPro, but we're associated
with ITProTV, so here we go.

40
00:01:55.230 --> 00:01:58.010
ITProTV logo, all good.

41
00:01:58.010 --> 00:02:03.776
And let's create a new document called
adding images, just like that, .md.

42
00:02:03.776 --> 00:02:05.600
Again it's a markdown file.

43
00:02:05.600 --> 00:02:12.474
Now, in order to add images,
it's similar to creating links.

44
00:02:12.474 --> 00:02:16.380
But here's the general kind of an outlook.

45
00:02:16.380 --> 00:02:23.280
We have an alt text and
then we have the img link right here.

46
00:02:23.280 --> 00:02:25.230
So what is the image?

47
00:02:25.230 --> 00:02:28.660
Now because I'm not on the interweb.

48
00:02:28.660 --> 00:02:32.110
Or it's not being rendered through
a website, or it's not all being compiled.

49
00:02:32.110 --> 00:02:32.957
>> Ooh.
>> You may get

50
00:02:32.957 --> 00:02:36.780
some weirdness within the rendering
of the document in our text editor.

51
00:02:36.780 --> 00:02:41.260
>> So if you have it locally, the image,
and then you try to share it externally,

52
00:02:41.260 --> 00:02:42.840
will others be able to view that?

53
00:02:42.840 --> 00:02:46.250
>> They have to have the image kind of
shipped with it, unless you turn it into

54
00:02:46.250 --> 00:02:49.231
a PDF at which point it becomes
an embedded part of the document.

55
00:02:49.231 --> 00:02:52.100
>> Cool.
>> So that's our general rule.

56
00:02:52.100 --> 00:02:55.760
But let's see how that kinda works out,
right?

57
00:02:55.760 --> 00:02:58.630
So, if I exclamation point, what is our?

58
00:02:58.630 --> 00:03:00.240
This is just our logo.

59
00:03:00.240 --> 00:03:04.193
And then, well, hm,
let's itpro, all right,

60
00:03:04.193 --> 00:03:07.335
could have named that a little easier.

61
00:03:07.335 --> 00:03:09.987
itpro.tv.pgn.

62
00:03:09.987 --> 00:03:13.450
Let's see if we can get this to render,
and there it is.

63
00:03:13.450 --> 00:03:14.930
It's actually that easy.

64
00:03:14.930 --> 00:03:15.910
Now what is the alt text?

65
00:03:15.910 --> 00:03:20.060
That's an accessibility feature,
just in case you forget to send the image.

66
00:03:20.060 --> 00:03:22.990
It's actually gonna render that alt text,

67
00:03:22.990 --> 00:03:27.120
that alternate text,
to describe what the image should be.

68
00:03:27.120 --> 00:03:28.778
This should be the logo.

69
00:03:28.778 --> 00:03:33.230
Sometimes this alt text is probably
better to have a more descriptive image.

70
00:03:33.230 --> 00:03:39.062
Like itprotv-logo, right, just like that.

71
00:03:39.062 --> 00:03:41.870
It doesn't change anything when
the image actually renders, but

72
00:03:41.870 --> 00:03:44.695
if the image is not there,
it's gonna be a little more descriptive.

73
00:03:44.695 --> 00:03:48.360
Don't go crazy with that and
go I gotta do all these thing, no,

74
00:03:48.360 --> 00:03:50.270
that's not what I mean.

75
00:03:51.470 --> 00:03:55.420
And this looks very similar
to external links, right?

76
00:03:55.420 --> 00:03:57.360
And to some extent internal links.

77
00:03:57.360 --> 00:04:01.040
The only difference is this
exclamation point, and

78
00:04:01.040 --> 00:04:05.940
then here I'm not linking to a website,
I'm linking to an image.

79
00:04:05.940 --> 00:04:08.400
And that little change of
syntaxes bring this image in.

80
00:04:08.400 --> 00:04:09.950
So I'm gonna compare that.

81
00:04:09.950 --> 00:04:11.360
We come over to external links.

82
00:04:11.360 --> 00:04:12.980
This is from a previous episode.

83
00:04:12.980 --> 00:04:17.846
And I look, notice then, well,
there's Google and here's.

84
00:04:17.846 --> 00:04:22.162
But down here,
we had this ability to rename things.

85
00:04:22.162 --> 00:04:25.580
Right, we could have this name look up.

86
00:04:25.580 --> 00:04:28.700
That makes me think we
should try that with images.

87
00:04:28.700 --> 00:04:31.010
Because what if you have
very long image URLs?

88
00:04:31.010 --> 00:04:35.488
Maybe you're hosting all of your images
on s3, so you don't have to remember,

89
00:04:35.488 --> 00:04:39.480
well, did I put the images in
that zip file with that document?

90
00:04:40.670 --> 00:04:45.190
Your goal then is as long as I have
Internet connection, it can grab it and

91
00:04:45.190 --> 00:04:47.370
put it in the document, right?

92
00:04:47.370 --> 00:04:52.055
So let's go ahead and close out of that
and see if we can get a named image here.

93
00:04:52.055 --> 00:04:55.224
So we go here and now,

94
00:04:55.224 --> 00:05:00.155
I forgot that I'm not in Vim, and

95
00:05:00.155 --> 00:05:06.849
we come down here and
we say itprotv-logo and

96
00:05:06.849 --> 00:05:10.567
let's just img, okay?

97
00:05:10.567 --> 00:05:15.440
So we go here, and we take this,

98
00:05:15.440 --> 00:05:18.871
and we cut it and boom.

99
00:05:18.871 --> 00:05:21.391
>> It's almost like
creating an alias here.

100
00:05:21.391 --> 00:05:22.026
I don't know.

101
00:05:22.026 --> 00:05:25.574
>> Yeah, to some extent it is like
creating an alias, but it doesn't quite

102
00:05:25.574 --> 00:05:29.940
work yet, right, because the image has
to do a lookup internal to the document.

103
00:05:29.940 --> 00:05:36.527
This has disappeared, but now itpro.

104
00:05:36.527 --> 00:05:38.633
You know what, from here on out,
Cherokee, I'm gonna need-

105
00:05:38.633 --> 00:05:39.523
>> How do you spell it?

106
00:05:39.523 --> 00:05:40.856
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

107
00:05:40.856 --> 00:05:41.970
>> I don't know, I don't know.

108
00:05:41.970 --> 00:05:47.720
We're gonna have to logo-img and
uh-oh, here we go.

109
00:05:47.720 --> 00:05:48.830
We got something going on.

110
00:05:48.830 --> 00:05:51.720
It did the lookup but what's going on.

111
00:05:51.720 --> 00:05:52.320
>> Right.

112
00:05:52.320 --> 00:05:57.310
>> I'm pretty sure ITProTV, there we go.

113
00:05:57.310 --> 00:06:00.398
And if we come back and look at
external links, we need to make sure.

114
00:06:00.398 --> 00:06:01.998
Okay, this is like that, but

115
00:06:01.998 --> 00:06:05.977
we had some weirdness with internal
links where that didn't quite work.

116
00:06:05.977 --> 00:06:13.760
So hm, let's see here if we come back and
we put this square bracket.

117
00:06:13.760 --> 00:06:15.430
Still not working.

118
00:06:15.430 --> 00:06:16.810
Why is that?

119
00:06:16.810 --> 00:06:19.440
Well we gotta do a little
live action to bugging here.

120
00:06:19.440 --> 00:06:23.370
itprotv-logo, logo-img, logo-img.

121
00:06:23.370 --> 00:06:24.030
Looks good.

122
00:06:25.150 --> 00:06:27.950
Remove that, remove that, and

123
00:06:27.950 --> 00:06:31.600
that's where there's a little
bit of a difference here, right?

124
00:06:31.600 --> 00:06:34.570
So we tried external links,
cuz we were like, okay, well,

125
00:06:34.570 --> 00:06:36.332
this kinda looks like those links.

126
00:06:36.332 --> 00:06:38.740
I should be able to use
a named alias effectively.

127
00:06:40.260 --> 00:06:42.900
But there's a little bit different
syntax in the context of images.

128
00:06:42.900 --> 00:06:44.090
>> Drop those brackets?

129
00:06:44.090 --> 00:06:48.460
>> I have to use the brackets up
top before the URL or the link or

130
00:06:48.460 --> 00:06:50.860
the file path or whatever it may be.

131
00:06:50.860 --> 00:06:56.063
I do not have to put the parenthesis or
anything around it when I'm defining it.

132
00:06:56.063 --> 00:07:00.981
So that one's a little bit different, but
now you can just say, well, here's an alt

133
00:07:00.981 --> 00:07:04.986
tag and here's the named image
reference and everything is good to go.

134
00:07:04.986 --> 00:07:05.820
All right, so

135
00:07:05.820 --> 00:07:09.858
those are two ways that we can add
images to our document pretty easy.

136
00:07:09.858 --> 00:07:13.070
And if I had a whole bunch of them, I
would probably put aliases at the bottom.

137
00:07:13.070 --> 00:07:16.220
Pick a naming convention that's
not hard to type or super long.

138
00:07:16.220 --> 00:07:19.220
And then you can just kind of
use them as you need them.

139
00:07:19.220 --> 00:07:22.310
If you only need them one or two times,
I would probably do them inline,

140
00:07:22.310 --> 00:07:27.510
and you're not limited
to just local images.

141
00:07:27.510 --> 00:07:31.730
You can actually put a full web URL and
everything will still work.

142
00:07:31.730 --> 00:07:35.420
Now because I'm not rendering this online,
I haven't done that.

143
00:07:35.420 --> 00:07:39.807
Because my editor and Internet being
a little flakey here and there.

144
00:07:39.807 --> 00:07:41.280
I didn't wanna risk it.

145
00:07:41.280 --> 00:07:44.989
It is capable if you're using like GitHub,
or Bitbucket, or anything to markdown.

146
00:07:44.989 --> 00:07:48.416
Or excuse me, to render, or
if you're actually running it through

147
00:07:48.416 --> 00:07:51.844
a transformation process where
you're getting a PDF, an ePub, or

148
00:07:51.844 --> 00:07:55.200
something like that, and
you have active Internet connection.

149
00:07:55.200 --> 00:07:59.144
So you can use full URLs for
a web based resource.

150
00:07:59.144 --> 00:08:02.530
I've just used mine locally so
either one works.

151
00:08:02.530 --> 00:08:05.239
>> Pretty cool.
Well now I'm gonna turn my notes in with

152
00:08:05.239 --> 00:08:10.100
all sorts of little bells and whistles now
Justin, so thank you so much for that.

153
00:08:10.100 --> 00:08:12.908
I know you're shaking your head at me
like I'm just crazy, but that's okay.

154
00:08:12.908 --> 00:08:14.558
>> [LAUGH]
>> You know that too.

155
00:08:14.558 --> 00:08:16.059
Thank you so much for joining us though.

156
00:08:16.059 --> 00:08:17.120
We're gonna sign out now.

157
00:08:17.120 --> 00:08:18.690
I've been your host Cherokee Boose.

158
00:08:18.690 --> 00:08:19.430
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

159
00:08:19.430 --> 00:08:21.050
>> See you next time here at DevProTV.

160
00:08:21.050 --> 00:08:26.427
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee create an image that is also a link.
episodes.title: Creating an Image with a Link
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.560 --> 00:00:16.300
Welcome, everyone, to your
Learn GitHub-Flavored Markdown series.

3
00:00:16.300 --> 00:00:18.090
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

4
00:00:18.090 --> 00:00:21.150
In this episode we'll be taking a look
at how we can add an image, but

5
00:00:21.150 --> 00:00:23.580
then also creating a link to that image.

6
00:00:23.580 --> 00:00:26.881
And with us today in studios we have Mr.
Justin Dennison.

7
00:00:26.881 --> 00:00:28.170
Thanks for stopping by, Justin.

8
00:00:28.170 --> 00:00:28.860
How are you?

9
00:00:28.860 --> 00:00:30.180
>> I am doing fantastic, Cherokee.

10
00:00:30.180 --> 00:00:30.840
How are you?

11
00:00:30.840 --> 00:00:31.820
>> I'm doing wonderful.

12
00:00:31.820 --> 00:00:36.100
I've had a lot of caffeine and
we just watched our last show about

13
00:00:36.100 --> 00:00:38.930
adding an image, but
this one's a little bit different, right?

14
00:00:38.930 --> 00:00:41.540
>> Right, so there are times,
especially if you're building something.

15
00:00:41.540 --> 00:00:45.430
Maybe you have a project
where you have a logo.

16
00:00:45.430 --> 00:00:49.340
You want the image in your README or
maybe it's part of pamphlet or a book, and

17
00:00:49.340 --> 00:00:50.880
you're using markdown.

18
00:00:50.880 --> 00:00:54.140
But also, if it's in a digital
format you're like, this logo,

19
00:00:54.140 --> 00:00:55.697
I want it to lead to my website.

20
00:00:55.697 --> 00:00:58.402
Maybe it's a marketing website or a
landing page or additional documentation.

21
00:00:58.402 --> 00:00:59.220
>> Click here.

22
00:00:59.220 --> 00:01:00.580
>> Yeah, something like that.

23
00:01:00.580 --> 00:01:01.755
I don't know if it's gonna blink.

24
00:01:01.755 --> 00:01:03.148
>> [LAUGH]
>> I make no promises about that.

25
00:01:03.148 --> 00:01:04.666
>> I told you it's the caffeine, Justin.

26
00:01:04.666 --> 00:01:06.171
You gotta-
>> Wee, [LAUGH] but

27
00:01:06.171 --> 00:01:09.627
it would have been nice if when
you hover over that image,

28
00:01:09.627 --> 00:01:13.030
it becomes a clickable
link instead of just text.

29
00:01:13.030 --> 00:01:16.080
And you may have seen this on websites,
but

30
00:01:16.080 --> 00:01:17.990
you could actually do that in markdown.

31
00:01:17.990 --> 00:01:21.613
Forewarning, we're kinda combining
two elements, and it gets a little,

32
00:01:21.613 --> 00:01:23.379
you're like, that's [NOISE].

33
00:01:23.379 --> 00:01:25.100
I need a nap after that.

34
00:01:25.100 --> 00:01:27.390
But it will be okay, all right?

35
00:01:27.390 --> 00:01:29.150
So let come down into the computer here.

36
