00:01:29.150 --> 00:01:34.750
And well, let's just create a new,
let's say images with links.

37
00:01:34.750 --> 00:01:36.330
Images with links.

38
00:01:37.480 --> 00:01:40.360
Now when I say links,
I'm talking about hyperlinks,

39
00:01:40.360 --> 00:01:43.760
not the linking to a file necessarily
because we've already done that.

40
00:01:43.760 --> 00:01:46.610
And unfortunately in technology,

41
00:01:46.610 --> 00:01:49.660
a lot of times there are-
>> Duplicate terminology?

42
00:01:49.660 --> 00:01:53.170
>> There are duplicate terminologies,
like the word server.

43
00:01:53.170 --> 00:01:57.210
In my world, server means something
different than maybe in your world, right?

44
00:01:57.210 --> 00:02:00.550
Physical architecture versus
application architecture.

45
00:02:00.550 --> 00:02:02.600
So just keep that in mind.

46
00:02:02.600 --> 00:02:04.610
And we have images with links.

47
00:02:04.610 --> 00:02:08.816
So just as a quick reminder,
if we go [SOUND] and

48
00:02:08.816 --> 00:02:13.042
say, ITProTV like so,
that is the alt text.

49
00:02:13.042 --> 00:02:17.213
And then if we put ITProTV.png like so,
and

50
00:02:17.213 --> 00:02:22.720
make a preview,
it pulls that image into our document.

51
00:02:22.720 --> 00:02:25.180
Notice it is still the same click.

52
00:02:25.180 --> 00:02:28.020
And let me make this a little larger here.

53
00:02:28.020 --> 00:02:31.890
This is just a standard pointer,
it's not a click to anywhere.

54
00:02:33.320 --> 00:02:36.600
But if I come out here and
I think about it,

55
00:02:36.600 --> 00:02:42.580
this is almost like the text
part of a hyperlink.

56
00:02:42.580 --> 00:02:47.087
So remind ourselves about external links,
and we come here and

57
00:02:47.087 --> 00:02:49.988
we say google, like so, google.com.

58
00:02:49.988 --> 00:02:54.666
And notice, actually let me just make
google because if I put google.com it

59
00:02:54.666 --> 00:02:57.233
already goes yeah, that's a link.

60
00:02:57.233 --> 00:03:01.644
But if I say https://www.google.com,

61
00:03:01.644 --> 00:03:07.420
like so,
this becomes a link that links to Google.

62
00:03:07.420 --> 00:03:12.890
But let's say for ITProTV, the image
should also link back to the home page.

63
00:03:12.890 --> 00:03:17.270
>> Okay.
>> All right, so if I look here, eh,

64
00:03:17.270 --> 00:03:23.400
if I take this and I were to put
it in here instead of the text,

65
00:03:23.400 --> 00:03:25.930
I may actually get
a clickable linked image.

66
00:03:27.100 --> 00:03:29.680
Well, let's see if we can accomplish that.

67
00:03:29.680 --> 00:03:33.269
And I'm gonna remove this,
and come here, and

68
00:03:33.269 --> 00:03:38.113
I'm gonna wrap all of this, right,
all of our image markup, or

69
00:03:38.113 --> 00:03:44.180
markdown, or eh, markdown,
it's not a markup language, but kinda is.

70
00:03:44.180 --> 00:03:46.080
Anyway, and then-
>> Yeah,

71
00:03:46.080 --> 00:03:48.940
it's like a little play on words
they've got going on here.

72
00:03:48.940 --> 00:03:51.002
>> Yeah, they're a shifty bunch.

73
00:03:51.002 --> 00:03:51.799
>> So punny!

74
00:03:51.799 --> 00:03:54.450
>> [LAUGH] I see what you did there.

75
00:03:54.450 --> 00:03:58.190
I'm not sure, anywhere I can
go with it but it's all right.

76
00:03:58.190 --> 00:04:01.440
So if I move this back over and

77
00:04:01.440 --> 00:04:06.597
I say https://itpro.tv.

78
00:04:06.597 --> 00:04:08.990
Okay, and there we go.

79
00:04:08.990 --> 00:04:14.865
Notice this now changes to the actual
little clicking finger and

80
00:04:14.865 --> 00:04:19.216
then actually sends us
to the ITProTV website,

81
00:04:19.216 --> 00:04:26.090
assuming that I haven't messed up in
my haste with the actual domain name.

82
00:04:27.160 --> 00:04:29.440
So let's click it.

83
00:04:29.440 --> 00:04:30.240
Let's see what happens.

84
00:04:30.240 --> 00:04:32.470
So I click it, and, boom, there we go.

85
00:04:32.470 --> 00:04:34.680
It actually takes us to that site,
it'll open it up.

86
00:04:34.680 --> 00:04:35.470
This is a document.

87
00:04:35.470 --> 00:04:38.160
If this was online,
it would just kind of redirect you.

88
00:04:38.160 --> 00:04:43.030
If I'm not mistaken, it opens a new
tab by default when it renders.

89
00:04:43.030 --> 00:04:45.140
So do keep that in mind.

90
00:04:45.140 --> 00:04:50.840
But I've done that by nesting two elements
that I already knew how to use, right?

91
00:04:50.840 --> 00:04:56.960
If I instead wanted to, if I come back and
look, and I look at creating images.

92
00:04:56.960 --> 00:04:57.610
Where'd you go?

93
00:04:58.660 --> 00:05:00.346
Adding images, excuse me.

94
00:05:00.346 --> 00:05:07.360
I can do this named portion,
right, just like here, or here.

95
00:05:07.360 --> 00:05:11.910
What if the source of the image was
actually somewhere on the page?

96
00:05:13.810 --> 00:05:17.350
So you go, okay, well,
I want a link to ITProTV, but

97
00:05:17.350 --> 00:05:21.363
I want to use the image from their page
because I don't wanna download it.

98
00:05:22.420 --> 00:05:26.170
Or maybe you're doing this internally and
this is your logo, right?

99
00:05:26.170 --> 00:05:27.580
It's on S3.

100
00:05:27.580 --> 00:05:33.870
If I come to adding images,
I actually have our image URL.

101
00:05:33.870 --> 00:05:39.670
And in a previous episode I didn't
wanna complicate things, but

102
00:05:39.670 --> 00:05:42.610
I can just put that right in line,
and it still renders.

103
00:05:42.610 --> 00:05:46.860
This is reaching out to the Internet,
in an S3 bucket in this case,

104
00:05:46.860 --> 00:05:49.600
grabbing the image, and it's there, okay?

105
00:05:50.850 --> 00:05:57.372
This is kind of messy, so
if I wanted to instead grab this and,

106
00:05:58.994 --> 00:06:03.502
Say logo, just like that,

107
00:06:03.502 --> 00:06:09.349
paste, boom, and then-
>> Maybe make something a little shorter.

108
00:06:09.349 --> 00:06:10.288
>> Logo.

109
00:06:10.288 --> 00:06:15.490
So the itpro.tv,
that is the alt text for this image.

110
00:06:15.490 --> 00:06:19.320
The logo actually looks up for this URL.

111
00:06:19.320 --> 00:06:23.100
This is all wrapped with that
exclamation point at the front,

112
00:06:23.100 --> 00:06:24.500
which creates the image.

113
00:06:24.500 --> 00:06:30.560
But then I wrap the image again,
and send it this link, this href.

114
00:06:30.560 --> 00:06:33.520
So now I have a clickable link that
actually loads the image from a remote

115
00:06:33.520 --> 00:06:34.680
resource.

116
00:06:34.680 --> 00:06:38.564
And I've done that by taking the
individual pieces that I already knew in

117
00:06:38.564 --> 00:06:41.313
markdown, and
kind of composing those together.

118
00:06:41.313 --> 00:06:43.630
>> It's pretty cool, and I mean,
you got a nice little workable.

119
00:06:43.630 --> 00:06:48.240
I mean, I don't know exactly what
I'll be adding into my documents, but

120
00:06:48.240 --> 00:06:49.970
now I know I have the option to do so.

121
00:06:49.970 --> 00:06:51.250
So thank you, Justin.

122
00:06:51.250 --> 00:06:55.784
>> Not a prob, and just as a quick
reminder, where are we gonna put these?

123
00:06:55.784 --> 00:06:57.130
This might be in Dropbox.

124
00:06:57.130 --> 00:07:01.590
These images could be hosted in Dropbox,
Google Drive, Clicker, Instagram,

125
00:07:01.590 --> 00:07:04.290
depending on how you share those.

126
00:07:04.290 --> 00:07:08.480
So if you wanted to build a document
that sourced those images,

127
00:07:08.480 --> 00:07:12.270
maybe you're building a little flyer or
all of your icons are there, or

128
00:07:12.270 --> 00:07:15.900
you have a design team that's
putting images into Dropbox.

129
00:07:15.900 --> 00:07:19.220
You can continue writing,
just update the links, and

130
00:07:19.220 --> 00:07:23.243
then when you export this to a PDF,
it pulls those either remotely, right,

131
00:07:23.243 --> 00:07:26.560
from Dropbox, from that shared link,
puts them in there.

132
00:07:26.560 --> 00:07:29.450
Or if you put on Github, Bitbucket or

133
00:07:29.450 --> 00:07:33.875
any other hosting service, it pulls those
but also creates a link that is clickable.

134
00:07:33.875 --> 00:07:37.190
If I'm not mistaken, pdf still has
clickable links in them as well, so

135
00:07:37.190 --> 00:07:40.180
if you export it as a pdf you
kinda get all of that in one.

136
00:07:40.180 --> 00:07:42.230
Interesting, well, thank you so
much for your time today, Justin.

137
00:07:42.230 --> 00:07:43.690
And thank you for your time as well.

138
00:07:43.690 --> 00:07:45.310
But we're gonna go ahead and sign out.

139
00:07:45.310 --> 00:07:46.820
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

140
00:07:46.820 --> 00:07:47.610
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

141
00:07:47.610 --> 00:07:49.717
>> See you next time here at DevProTV.

142
00:07:49.717 --> 00:07:55.007
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee leverage the GitHub flavor to arrange information in a table.
episodes.title: Creating a Table
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC].

2
00:00:12.719 --> 00:00:16.189
Welcome everyone to your
Learn GitHub-Flavored Markdown series,

3
00:00:16.189 --> 00:00:17.753
I am your host Cherokee Boose.

4
00:00:17.753 --> 00:00:20.991
In this episode, we'll be taking a look
at how we can create tables, and

5
00:00:20.991 --> 00:00:24.080
of course with us back in the studios,
we have Mr. Justin Dennison.

6
00:00:24.080 --> 00:00:25.730
Thanks for dropping in,
Justin, how are you?

7
00:00:25.730 --> 00:00:27.170
>> I am doing fantastic, Cherokee,

8
00:00:27.170 --> 00:00:28.410
how are you?
>> I'm doing well,

9
00:00:28.410 --> 00:00:31.200
I'm looking forward to learning
how to create tables, and

10
00:00:31.200 --> 00:00:34.330
maybe even some ASCII hearts and
stars and smiley faces.

11
00:00:34.330 --> 00:00:37.201
Are we gonna do that today, Justin?
>> Well, I might be

12
00:00:37.201 --> 00:00:41.290
able to deliver all but one of those and
it is not the ASCII hearts or stars.

13
00:00:41.290 --> 00:00:45.081
I will say, ASCII heart is kind of
hard actually, you're like all right,

14
00:00:45.081 --> 00:00:48.170
I gotta put all these characters together.
>> I have seen some really

15
00:00:48.170 --> 00:00:51.180
intricate things out there.
>> I have as well, like people's faces.

16
00:00:51.180 --> 00:00:52.503
[LAUGH]
>> It is crazy but

17
00:00:52.503 --> 00:00:55.385
that is not what we are going to do but
it does tie in,

18
00:00:55.385 --> 00:00:59.360
because well there are times where
you want to have like tabular data.

19
00:00:59.360 --> 00:01:05.020
I want rows and columns for arrangements,
and maybe its just check boxes or

20
00:01:05.020 --> 00:01:09.490
maybe it's checklists or maybe it's
a feature comparison between two products.

21
00:01:09.490 --> 00:01:15.650
And your well I could do that as
an image and then bring it in, but

22
00:01:15.650 --> 00:01:19.680
I really just need more or less a simple
table, well, if I do that in Markdown when

23
00:01:19.680 --> 00:01:24.820
I export it I get decently rendered
tables and if it's on the web it ends

24
00:01:24.820 --> 00:01:27.895
up becoming a nicely styled HTML table.
>> Well,

25
00:01:27.895 --> 00:01:32.515
also, I know just from personal
experience, if I'm in an area with poor

26
00:01:32.515 --> 00:01:36.755
network bandwidth, like a highly NC
environment maybe it's just more

27
00:01:36.755 --> 00:01:39.585
beneficial to have a table instead
of trying to bring in an image and

28
00:01:39.585 --> 00:01:43.347
waiting for that to load also.
>> Exactly if you have something that's

29
00:01:43.347 --> 00:01:47.047
rendering it for you kind of on the fly
on a local machine you're more or less

30
00:01:47.047 --> 00:01:52.237
transmitting text or markdown and then
what you're seeing is the rendered output.

31
00:01:52.237 --> 00:01:55.097
So, it’s just saying well you
follow this convention boom,

32
00:01:55.097 --> 00:01:57.267
here's the rendered output,
and we're all good to go.

33
00:01:57.267 --> 00:02:02.260
So, very nice, now, we're gonna see
how tables work it's a little more

34
00:02:02.260 --> 00:02:05.420
complicated than some of the things
we've seen in Markdown thus far.

35
00:02:05.420 --> 00:02:11.680
So do kind of buckle up, hold on, and take
a look at some of these small details,

36
00:02:11.680 --> 00:02:14.510
I still mess them up from time to time,
so no worries.

37
00:02:14.510 --> 00:02:16.400
So if we come into the screen here and,
well,

38
00:02:16.400 --> 00:02:18.870
let's just start creating some tables.

39
00:02:18.870 --> 00:02:23.510
And, well, let's just call it tables.md,
there we go so

40
00:02:23.510 --> 00:02:27.570
in order to create tables we
need a variety of characters.

41
00:02:27.570 --> 00:02:33.680
The table columns are divided
by a vertical pipe, so this

42
00:02:33.680 --> 00:02:38.362
vertical pipe, unfortunately it's usually-
>> Underneath here.

43
00:02:38.362 --> 00:02:40.100
>> Right above, it's below delete or

44
00:02:40.100 --> 00:02:42.450
backspace, depending on your computer, or

45
00:02:42.450 --> 00:02:46.830
right above your enter key and you have
to hold shift, so with a back slash.

46

to you in your editor.

80
00:04:15.599 --> 00:04:20.710
If you open this up in Notepad or
TextEdit, it's not going to show that.

81
00:04:20.710 --> 00:04:23.680
It'll show just this portion.

82
00:04:23.680 --> 00:04:26.240
But now I have syntax highlighting.

83
00:04:26.240 --> 00:04:27.750
This function is a keyword.

84
00:04:27.750 --> 00:04:29.612
This return is a keyword.

85
00:04:29.612 --> 00:04:33.950
add, that's the function name,
x and y are parameters.

86
00:04:33.950 --> 00:04:35.800
And it's not perfect all the time.

87
00:04:35.800 --> 00:04:40.140
This comma really shouldn't be orange,
I don't think.

88
00:04:40.140 --> 00:04:43.699
But it's better,
it helps provide the visual cues.

89
00:04:43.699 --> 00:04:45.680
I wrote the language, right?

90
00:04:45.680 --> 00:04:48.696
What if I change this language to Python?

91
00:04:48.696 --> 00:04:51.020
It goes, the only thing I
recognize is the return keyword,

92
00:04:51.020 --> 00:04:53.820
cuz that's the only thing that's
similar between the two languages.

93
00:04:53.820 --> 00:04:55.657
So you have to be careful there.

94
00:04:55.657 --> 00:04:59.046
Now on GitHub,
if you use GitHub or Bitbucket or

95
00:04:59.046 --> 00:05:01.504
anything like that to host these,

96
00:05:01.504 --> 00:05:06.900
a lot of times if you do not put the
language type, it does some fancy ticks.

97
00:05:06.900 --> 00:05:08.940
And it'll kinda go
>> Assume it?

98
00:05:08.940 --> 00:05:13.000
>> It'll assume or try to make the best
guess at what the language type is.

99
00:05:13.000 --> 00:05:14.681
So Javascript is this one,

100
00:05:14.681 --> 00:05:19.226
but if we had another code block where
you wanted to compare Java, right?

101
00:05:19.226 --> 00:05:22.707
And you wanted to compare method, so

102
00:05:22.707 --> 00:05:27.220
public static void main|string[|args).

103
00:05:27.220 --> 00:05:28.889
Yeah, you're like what?

104
00:05:28.889 --> 00:05:36.050
And then System.out.println("Hello").

105
00:05:36.050 --> 00:05:40.495
Just like that,
it still uses the same color set.

106
00:05:40.495 --> 00:05:43.768
But it's recognizing different keywords
based on the language that you've

107
00:05:43.768 --> 00:05:45.320
picked for them.

108
00:05:45.320 --> 00:05:48.630
So you can do this for
crazy esoteric languages,

109
00:05:48.630 --> 00:05:53.550
but I think the best support is going
to be for languages that you know.

110
00:05:53.550 --> 00:05:56.050
>> Pretty common
>> Yeah, pretty common languages.

111
00:05:56.050 --> 00:06:02.950
So if we do the corollary to the Python
one, this add is the same function.

112
00:06:02.950 --> 00:06:06.254
Notice it now has Python syntax
highlighting because it's Python

113
00:06:06.254 --> 00:06:08.560
syntax versus JavaScript's highlighting.

114
00:06:08.560 --> 00:06:11.411
And I could do the same thing for Java but

115
00:06:11.411 --> 00:06:16.865
I would have to write a lot more code for
an add function so I'm not going to.

116
00:06:16.865 --> 00:06:18.060
>> [LAUGH] Quitter.

117
00:06:18.060 --> 00:06:21.613
>> I know, I know, guilty as charged.

118
00:06:21.613 --> 00:06:22.664
I'm not gonna lie.

119
00:06:22.664 --> 00:06:27.440
There's a reason I kinda strayed from
the Java world a little bit there.

120
00:06:27.440 --> 00:06:31.701
But having the syntax highlighting is very
helpful, especially if things like hey,

121
00:06:31.701 --> 00:06:35.449
I wanna show Cherokee, hey,
here's this nice little PowerShell cmdlt.

122
00:06:35.449 --> 00:06:38.590
I'm not even sure I could say that with
a straight face and be serious about it.

123
00:06:38.590 --> 00:06:41.294
But if I wanted to show her some Bash,
right?

124
00:06:41.294 --> 00:06:43.650
Cherokee wants to learn more about Linux.

125
00:06:43.650 --> 00:06:46.311
And I'm like,
well here's some common Bash commands.

126
00:06:46.311 --> 00:06:49.929
Or here's a Bash script that
accomplishes the following.

127
00:06:50.980 --> 00:06:54.840
And I want to comment it, and annotate
it and put all it on a Markdown file so

128
00:06:54.840 --> 00:06:57.354
it looks nice in a PDF that
I can just hand to her.

129
00:06:57.354 --> 00:06:58.771
And maybe she reads on her phone or

130
00:06:58.771 --> 00:07:00.850
something like that then
this would be helpful.

131
00:07:00.850 --> 00:07:03.464
>> I have it like taped up all
in my bedroom and living room.

132
00:07:03.464 --> 00:07:07.710
>> Yeah, I mean, she studies like that.

133
00:07:07.710 --> 00:07:10.983
But this is helpful,
instead of having it in another editor and

134
00:07:10.983 --> 00:07:15.387
trying to take pictures of it and things
like that, it just renders appropriately.

135
00:07:15.387 --> 00:07:20.440
And luckily, most Markdown renderers,
GitHub-Flavored in particular,

136
00:07:20.440 --> 00:07:23.820
the ones that support it, almost always.

137
00:07:23.820 --> 00:07:25.693
There are a few exceptions.

138
00:07:25.693 --> 00:07:32.360
Have a syntax highlight feature that will
highlight based on the language type.

139
00:07:32.360 --> 00:07:36.443
They always have the triple tick code
blocks that will provide formatting so

140
00:07:36.443 --> 00:07:38.815
you don't get weird squished formatting.

141
00:07:38.815 --> 00:07:42.343
There's no guarantee based on the style
sheets that this will always work for

142
00:07:42.343 --> 00:07:44.560
everything, so do keep that in mind.

143
00:07:44.560 --> 00:07:45.412
>> Awesome, Justin.

144
00:07:45.412 --> 00:07:48.470
There you have it, no more smushing.

145
00:07:48.470 --> 00:07:51.179
I appreciate your knowledge today,
and thank you guys for joining us.

146
00:07:51.179 --> 00:07:52.960
But we're gonna go ahead and sign out.

147
00:07:52.960 --> 00:07:54.500
I've been your host, Cherokee Boose.

148
00:07:54.500 --> 00:07:55.450
>> And I'm Justin Dennison.

149
00:07:55.450 --> 00:07:56.890
>> See you next time here at DevProTV.

150
00:07:56.890 --> 00:08:02.367
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Cherokee demonstrate some of the more powerful portions of GitHub Markdown to create a task list that can be used to keep track of all of the things to get done.
episodes.title: Creating a Task List
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.152 --> 00:00:10.152
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.790 --> 00:00:16.690
Welcome, everyone, to your learn
GitHub-Flavored Markdown series.

3
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:18.710
I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

4
00:00:18.710 --> 00:00:22.650
In this episode, we'll be taking a look
at how we can create a task list,

5
00:00:22.650 --> 00:00:25.060
which is totally different than a list.

6
00:00:25.060 --> 00:00:27.280
And of course,
with us today in studios, we have Mr.

7
00:00:27.280 --> 00:00:30.120
Justin Dennison to explain the difference.

8
00:00:30.120 --> 00:00:30.925
How's it going, Justin?

9
00:00:30.925 --> 00:00:33.405
>> It is going fantastic here,
how are you?

10
00:00:33.405 --> 00:00:36.265
[LAUGH]
>> I am doing great.

11
00:00:36.265 --> 00:00:39.735
But I do recall in a previous show, we did
get together, and we talked about how to

12
00:00:39.735 --> 00:00:43.975
create a list, an ordered list, and you
showed us all these cool little tricks.

13
00:00:43.975 --> 00:00:45.552
What will we be looking looking at here?

14
00:00:45.552 --> 00:00:49.792
>> Well, you might oversold how
different they are, actually.

15
00:00:49.792 --> 00:00:51.672
They're not wholly different.

16
00:00:51.672 --> 00:00:54.486
But this is one of those extensions
that we get that is guaranteed in

17
00:00:54.486 --> 00:00:59.182
GitHub-Flavored Markdown, where a lot of
times when I'm making a list, I go, well,

18
00:00:59.182 --> 00:01:03.062
I need to do x, y, and z,
whether it's ordered or not, right?

19
00:01:03.062 --> 00:01:05.572
If I need to do something first,
I'll put that as a number one.

20
00:01:05.572 --> 00:01:09.320
But if I just need to accomplish, you've
heard these called honey-do lists or

21
00:01:09.320 --> 00:01:11.530
just to-do lists whatever they may be.

22
00:01:12.670 --> 00:01:18.590
But a lot of times you're like, well,
did I do that or did I do this other one?

23
00:01:18.590 --> 00:01:21.855
You either mark them off, if you're
physically writing them on paper or

24
00:01:21.855 --> 00:01:23.200
you'll check them, right?

25
00:01:23.200 --> 00:01:28.220
>> It creates a sense of accomplishment,
a feeling, that good warm fuzziness.

26
00:01:28.220 --> 00:01:29.620
>> It's either warm, and

27
00:01:29.620 --> 00:01:32.395
fuzzy or you look at how many
things that you have unchecked.

28
00:01:32.395 --> 00:01:35.900
[LAUGH] Or marked off, and you go,
I'm not gonna do any of those.

29
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:40.940
But associated with a project or maybe
a checklist for setting up infrastructure.

30
00:01:40.940 --> 00:01:43.330
You're like,
I need to accomplish these things.

31
00:01:43.330 --> 00:01:46.030
And you wanna keep track
of it in documentation,

32
00:01:46.030 --> 00:01:48.020
especially when you're using
version control systems,

33
00:01:48.020 --> 00:01:52.330
like GitHub, or BitBucket or well, when
I say that, that's where they're stored.

34
00:01:52.330 --> 00:01:55.600
You're using Git in
those common instances.

35
00:01:55.600 --> 00:01:58.670
Then it would be nice if you could keep,
hey,

36
00:01:58.670 --> 00:02:01.120
this is true, this is a roadmap, right?

37
00:02:01.120 --> 00:02:02.560
These are the things that I have done.

38
00:02:02.560 --> 00:02:04.800
Here are the things that I plan to do.

39
00:02:04.800 --> 00:02:06.775
And those are either checked off or not.

40
00:02:06.775 --> 00:02:09.175
>> Great for shared documents too,
and shared projects,

41
00:02:09.175 --> 00:02:12.715
because then you know who's done what,
you're not reworking things.

42
00:02:12.715 --> 00:02:14.245
>> Exactly right.

43
00:02:14.245 --> 00:02:17.325
Actually, I use these in my
internal documentation for

44
00:02:17.325 --> 00:02:22.395
the courses that I prepare, so I know
what I have done for respective episodes.

45
00:02:22.395 --> 00:02:24.145
So I just try to keep those as my outline.

46
00:02:25.400 --> 00:02:29.490
This is by and large not available
in all flavors of Markdown.

47
00:02:29.490 --> 00:02:32.000
I'm not gonna say the one you're
using doesn't support it, but

48
00:02:32.000 --> 00:02:36.110
with GitHub-flavored, it is supported,
and it's pretty handy.

49
00:02:36.110 --> 00:02:37.640
So let's go ahead, and
come to the screen here,

50
00:02:37.640 --> 00:02:42.400
and see how we make a task list
that is not wholly different

51
00:02:42.400 --> 00:02:48.070
than a regular list, but it does have,
typically, a different use.

52
00:02:48.070 --> 00:02:52.656
I'm keeping a running total, instead
I'm just kinda brain spurting onto the,

53
00:02:52.656 --> 00:02:55.006
brain spurting, I don't even know.

54
00:02:55.006 --> 00:02:56.158
>> Gosh.
>> I don't even know why I said that, woo.

55
00:02:56.158 --> 00:02:58.612
>> [LAUGH]
>> That escalated quickly.

56
00:02:58.612 --> 00:03:01.165
>> What kind of task list
are we working with here?

57
00:03:01.165 --> 00:03:01.924
>> I don't know.

58
00:03:01.924 --> 00:03:03.470
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think we should keep

59
00:03:03.470 --> 00:03:05.270
the theme, right?

60
00:03:05.270 --> 00:03:08.240
>> Food?
>> Food, and groceries, right?

61
00:03:08.240 --> 00:03:11.250
And let's say that you have
some kind of digital processor,

62
00:03:11.250 --> 00:03:16.140
maybe you have your tablet, or
your phone, and you're typing, and

63
00:03:16.140 --> 00:03:20.260
you want to keep track of
the groceries that you've bought.

64
00:03:20.260 --> 00:03:23.810
So if I come here, and I say,
well I need some carrots,

65
00:03:26.220 --> 00:03:28.660
and I need some bread, and I need some-
>> Ice cream.

66
00:03:28.660 --> 00:03:29.660
>> Ice cream.

67
00:03:29.660 --> 00:03:31.320
>> Always.
>> [LAUGH]

68
00:03:31.320 --> 00:03:34.235
>> I don't keep any ice cream in my house.

69
00:03:34.235 --> 00:03:36.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> Ice cream, steak.

70
00:03:36.560 --> 00:03:42.860
Meats, steak, maybe steak again just for
the niceness, right?

71
00:03:42.860 --> 00:03:47.797
So I have this list, and if I render this,
and I open the render, gotta actually,

72
00:03:47.797 --> 00:03:49.470
boop, there we go.

73
00:03:49.470 --> 00:03:51.400
Then I just get a a regular list.

74
00:03:51.400 --> 00:03:54.200
Now, some of the things that we've
learned in a previous episode,

75
00:03:54.200 --> 00:03:59.090
if you wanted to mark this off and
say, I've got all the carrots, right?

76
00:03:59.090 --> 00:04:02.060
I could do this, and
that will actually strike this out.

77
00:04:02.060 --> 00:04:05.910
But now, I don't have anything that kinda

78
00:04:05.910 --> 00:04:09.070
reminds me that I'm doing this
check off process versus not.

79
00:04:09.070 --> 00:04:09.960
>> Strike it out.

80
00:04:09.960 --> 00:04:11.780
I might just be blind again here, but

81
00:04:11.780 --> 00:04:14.430
you mean just having a line
through the actual word carrots?

82
00:04:14.430 --> 00:04:16.540
>> Yep, the strike through, strike it out.

83
00:04:16.540 --> 00:04:19.659
[SOUND] If you were writing this,
that's probably what I-

84
00:04:19.659 --> 00:04:20.161
>> [SOUND]

85
00:04:20.161 --> 00:04:20.883
>> Line through,

86
00:04:20.883 --> 00:04:24.165
and I feel like Cherokee's making
fun of me, and I'm not aware of it.

87
00:04:24.165 --> 00:04:25.752
But that's all right, that's all right.

88
00:04:25.752 --> 00:04:30.140
So what if instead, I wanted to say,
hey, there's a little checkboxes, and

89
00:04:30.140 --> 00:04:33.370
I want to know whether I have
accomplished those things.

90
00:04:33.370 --> 00:04:36.230
Now, this is a grocery list,
I would probably use this more for

91
00:04:36.230 --> 00:04:39.730
technical documentation,
features that I'm doing or

92
00:04:39.730 --> 00:04:43.600
if I'm trying to set up a process or
plan something.

93
00:04:43.600 --> 00:04:46.390
What stages have I accomplished?

94
00:04:46.390 --> 00:04:53.145
If I come here, and I put empty square
brackets, and then a space, right?

95
00:04:53.145 --> 00:04:56.790
[COUGH] And
I got some weird rendering here.

96
00:04:57.810 --> 00:04:59.160
But that's all right.

97
00:04:59.160 --> 00:05:03.960
So if I come here, and there we go, and

98
00:05:03.960 --> 00:05:10.000
then come here, and
come here, and come here.

99
00:05:10.000 --> 00:05:10.590
There we go.

100
00:05:10.590 --> 00:05:18.015
So if I put these here, and it looks good,
it doesn't quite do this checkbox, right?

101
00:05:18.015 --> 00:05:20.738
>> So
this is actually what I do personally, and

102
00:05:20.738 --> 00:05:25.697
then I'll just put a capital x in the
brackets whenever I finish something, but-

103
00:05:25.697 --> 00:05:27.476
>> Yeah, so this is not,

104
00:05:27.476 --> 00:05:33.440
this editor is not providing a render
that is compatible with this.

105
00:05:33.440 --> 00:05:37.420
So I wanted to show you that in case
you're using Visual Studio Code,

106
00:05:37.420 --> 00:05:40.502
this capital x is exactly what you do,
this is a checkbox.

107
00:05:40.502 --> 00:05:45.400
In GitHub-flavored Markdown for full
compliance, if you put this on GitHub or

108
00:05:45.400 --> 00:05:51.380
use another editor, then this becomes
a checkbox here, and then the X.

109
00:05:51.380 --> 00:05:52.440
>> Sweet.
>> Actually checks it.

110
00:05:52.440 --> 00:05:53.360
>> I like that.

111
00:05:53.360 --> 00:05:57.980
>> And to show you that, we've been using
Visual Studio Code this entire time.

112
00:05:57.980 --> 00:06:02.240
I'm gonna hop over, and I'm gonna open
another editor that maybe you've used, and

113
00:06:02.240 --> 00:06:02.990
it works for you.

114
00:06:02.990 --> 00:06:06.410
I'm gonna open up Atom, and there we go.

115
00:06:06.410 --> 00:06:09.029
I don't want to consent
to any telemetry stuff.

116
00:06:10.350 --> 00:06:11.050
And here we go.

117
00:06:11.050 --> 00:06:13.510
Let's open or add project folder.

118
00:06:15.000 --> 00:06:17.140
And I'm going to come to my Desktop.

119
00:06:17.140 --> 00:06:22.440
And I'm just gonna open the same folder
that I have open in Visual Studio Code,

120
00:06:22.440 --> 00:06:23.860
and task list.

121
00:06:23.860 --> 00:06:27.170
So here's my task list,
it's exactly the same, and

122
00:06:27.170 --> 00:06:29.560
I forget all the keyboard
shortcuts are a little different.

123
00:06:29.560 --> 00:06:31.080
That's all right.

124
00:06:31.080 --> 00:06:39.920
And then, notice down here, no, down here,
this actually says GitHub Markdown.

125
00:06:39.920 --> 00:06:41.780
This is behind my head here, there we go.

126
00:06:41.780 --> 00:06:46.840
It actually says GitHub Markdown
because Atom is produced by GitHub.

127
00:06:46.840 --> 00:06:49.100
So you may get a more feature full,

128
00:06:49.100 --> 00:06:50.730
kind of-
>> More rich.

129
00:06:50.730 --> 00:06:55.960
>> Rich support for GitHub Markdown,
because this is a GitHub product.

130
00:06:55.960 --> 00:06:57.050
>> Cool.

131
00:06:57.050 --> 00:07:02.520
>> Likewise, if I come back,
and I save, and let's see here,

132
00:07:02.520 --> 00:07:08.770
I want to mark down,
I want to preview, toggle to preview.

133
00:07:08.770 --> 00:07:09.966
So here we go.

134
00:07:09.966 --> 00:07:17.270
And notice, the bullets for
this list are now check boxes.

135
00:07:17.270 --> 00:07:20.830
I can actually check them
because they are HTML rendered.

136
00:07:20.830 --> 00:07:24.290
That's not always the case in
every document, if it's in a PDF,

137
00:07:24.290 --> 00:07:26.660
it just looks like an empty check box.

138
00:07:26.660 --> 00:07:30.840
But notice here, I get a bullet with an x.

139
00:07:30.840 --> 00:07:33.455
And this is what a lot of people do
because you don't get necessarily

140
00:07:33.455 --> 00:07:35.400
rendering, it's just a reminder.

141
00:07:35.400 --> 00:07:39.200
If I instead come here, and
I move this over, and I save,

142
00:07:39.200 --> 00:07:41.510
it doesn't look like it does anything.

143
00:07:41.510 --> 00:07:44.890
If I change this to lower case x,
it doesn't do anything.

144
00:07:44.890 --> 00:07:47.550
If I move it back, there we go.

145
00:07:47.550 --> 00:07:48.410
That's kind of odd, right?

146
00:07:48.410 --> 00:07:51.500
>> What do you mean odd?

147
00:07:51.500 --> 00:07:53.680
>> That I can't check it.

148
00:07:53.680 --> 00:07:56.180
>> That it's a solid-
>> It's a solid box.

149
00:07:56.180 --> 00:07:57.810
>> Okay.
>> Because if this is rendered

150
00:07:57.810 --> 00:08:02.880
to a document, then I'm not going to be
able to click this, and have it stay.

151
00:08:02.880 --> 00:08:03.850
>> Okay.

152
00:08:03.850 --> 00:08:11.700
>> But if I now, hopefully, nope,
hopefully, it's being finicky on me.

153
00:08:11.700 --> 00:08:16.190
And this is something that I had trouble
with, getting this to render to show you.

154
00:08:16.190 --> 00:08:18.630
You put this on GitHub with a lowercase or

155
00:08:18.630 --> 00:08:23.180
an uppercase x,
you should get a rendered checked box.

156
00:08:25.180 --> 00:08:25.950
Having this local,

157
00:08:25.950 --> 00:08:29.740
I didn't want to get into using Git, and
putting stuff on GitHub, and things.

158
00:08:29.740 --> 00:08:32.250
This will give you
a checked box that looks,

159
00:08:32.250 --> 00:08:34.580
by default, like this checked box here.

160
00:08:36.560 --> 00:08:39.530
If you instead,
there's a couple of things to remember.

161
00:08:39.530 --> 00:08:46.540
If you move these to the end, which kind
of makes sense to me, it doesn't work.

162
00:08:46.540 --> 00:08:50.040
Because what it's doing is it's
replacing the bullets with a checkbox

163
00:08:50.040 --> 00:08:52.020
in order to make your task list.

164
00:08:52.020 --> 00:08:54.320
So if you separate those two,

165
00:08:54.320 --> 00:08:57.760
the positioning of those
open brackets do matter.

166
00:08:57.760 --> 00:09:00.380
So don't do that,
put them at the beginning.

167
00:09:00.380 --> 00:09:02.810
And wait for it, wait for it.

168
00:09:02.810 --> 00:09:04.910
Here we go, aha, there we go.

169
00:09:04.910 --> 00:09:06.140
I finally get it to work.

170
00:09:06.140 --> 00:09:08.860
I like the spaces around it,
but depending on your render,

171
00:09:08.860 --> 00:09:14.490
as we've seen, We can get a nice little
checkbox if we just put an X in there.

172
00:09:14.490 --> 00:09:18.260
Now, Cherokee said she put a capital x,
I wonder if that matters, and

173
00:09:18.260 --> 00:09:19.040
it does matter.

174
00:09:19.040 --> 00:09:22.580
>> Ooh, so all of my work that I've
done just wouldn't render properly.

175
00:09:22.580 --> 00:09:25.200
>> Yeah, and that is ultimately
dependent on the renderer.

176
00:09:25.200 --> 00:09:27.260
>> Okay.
>> I have used capital x's, and

177
00:09:27.260 --> 00:09:28.176
had it work.

178
00:09:28.176 --> 00:09:32.430
Not 100% sure that it was GitHub,
it might have been on another

179
00:09:32.430 --> 00:09:36.450
version control system that rendered this,
so don't quote me on that.

180
00:09:36.450 --> 00:09:40.960
But if we put a lower case x in these,
right, I backspace, I lower case x, and

181
00:09:40.960 --> 00:09:44.980
now, as I write that it,
my rendered document gives a check.

182
00:09:46.000 --> 00:09:48.450
I would probably not use this for
a grocery list, right?

183
00:09:48.450 --> 00:09:51.430
Actually, I would probably write it down,
and strike through it.

184
00:09:51.430 --> 00:09:55.881
But if I was creating a project or there
were steps that I need to accomplish in

185
00:09:55.881 --> 00:10:00.612
the creation of a project, and I need to
maintain documentation, I very well may

186
00:10:00.612 --> 00:10:04.742
create a Markdown document that has
all the things that I needed to do.

187
00:10:04.742 --> 00:10:10.481
And as I accomplish them, go back, put
an x, save, so I can keep track of where I

188
00:10:10.481 --> 00:10:17.050
was, especially if it's going to take a
long time in order to complete said thing.

189
00:10:17.050 --> 00:10:19.490
So task lists are available to you.

190
00:10:19.490 --> 00:10:24.970
Just remember, the placement isn't
important, and spacing is important.

191
00:10:24.970 --> 00:10:28.980
One final thing, if I come here, and

192
00:10:28.980 --> 00:10:33.170
I change all of these to asterisks,
it still renders.

193
00:10:33.170 --> 00:10:37.279
So it's still just a list, but
if right after the list character I

194
00:10:37.279 --> 00:10:41.960
put square brackets, and
then if I have an x in it, it's checked.

195
00:10:41.960 --> 00:10:44.630
If I don't then it's not.

196
00:10:44.630 --> 00:10:45.270
And furthermore,

197
00:10:45.270 --> 00:10:49.980
because it is just a list character,
then some of our other things also work.

198
00:10:49.980 --> 00:10:52.370
I dunno, like baby carrots.

199
00:10:53.510 --> 00:10:55.945
>> If I come over here,
notice, I've gotten carrots.

200
00:10:55.945 --> 00:10:59.270
There's no relationship,
it's not anything fancy.

201
00:10:59.270 --> 00:11:03.280
There's no relationship between sublists,
and particularly,

202
00:11:03.280 --> 00:11:04.880
we check boxes versus not.

203
00:11:04.880 --> 00:11:08.000
So if you need to keep
track of to do things,

204
00:11:08.000 --> 00:11:10.150
this is a great way inside
of your Markdown documents.

205
00:11:10.150 --> 00:11:11.570
>> Perfect, now, I can just go ahead, and

206
00:11:11.570 --> 00:11:14.400
check this off my list of
things to learn for the day.

207
00:11:14.400 --> 00:11:15.760
So thank you for that Justin.

208
00:11:15.760 --> 00:11:16.890
Hopefully, you guys did too.

209
00:11:16.890 --> 00:11:18.420
But for now, let's sign out.

210
